OceanofPDF.com

‌Preface‌

Tuesday. Ordinarily, it's just another cog in the relentless machine of the week, a day neither remarkable for its joys nor its sorrows. Most Tuesdays dissipate like mist in the morning sun, leaving no lasting impression. But April 3rd was different, violently so. It's a date seared into my very being, a permanent scar on the timeline of my life.

That Tuesday marked a catastrophic turning point, a day when the familiar trajectory of my existence, my family's future, and indeed, the fate of the entire world, was irrevocably and shockingly altered. The change, when it

came, was abrupt and without the slightest hint of foreshadowing, a sudden cleaving of reality itself. I would soon learn I was alone in this experience.

The morning of the 3rd had unfolded with a deceptive and almost painful normalcy. The well-worn routine began at 5:30 AM, with the gentle, but persistent, rousing of my eldest son, a 16-year-old for whom the early hours were a form of mild torture. Each day, I delivered the same quiet lecture, a reminder of the growing responsibilities that came with approaching adulthood. By 6:00 AM, he was gone, a silhouette disappearing down the street toward the bus stop, leaving me to steal a few more precious, fleeting moments of sleep before the next wave of activity.

At precisely 7:00 AM, my wife and I would rise, embarking on the carefully orchestrated ballet of preparing our two younger children for their school day. It was a practiced dance, a testament to years of shared mornings. Our 15-year-old son, already exhibiting a fierce independence that bordered on

self-sufficiency, navigated his morning preparations with minimal intervention. Our 13-year-old daughter, however, still required transport, a task, and a privilege, that I gladly accepted.

After the flurry of farewells and the carefully timed departures, I'd drop her at school and navigate the quiet streets back to the tranquil haven of my

home office. The privilege of working remotely, a now-commonplace perk in the world of Information Technology, eliminated the soul-crushing daily

commute. Companies, in a rare display of enlightened self-interest and financial pragmatism, had embraced the remote work model, significantly reducing their overhead in the process.

I had just finished my second call of the day, a mundane discussion about backups. A brief, almost unnerving calm had descended. And then, without warning, the world changed.


Robert of Earth, attend. Let this day be marked in your personal history, for it signifies the dawn of a profound transformation. Your universe has been selected for integration. I am the Great System, and my arrival heralds the restructuring of your reality.

Robert, understand that you have been singled out. From the multitude of individuals inhabiting your planet, you alone

have been chosen, through a process of impartial designation, to be the prime subject of this initial phase. Your life, as you know it, is irrevocably altered. You are now the designated

representative for Earth in this grand undertaking.

A preparatory period of six of your Earth months is allotted.

Following this, you, Robert, will be relocated to a random universe, already functioning under the System's governance, for comprehensive training and evaluation. This displacement will last until your native universe is prepared for full integration, a process projected to require approximately 412 Earth years. Should you survive this extensive period, you shall return to your people, a herald of the profound alterations that accompany System integration.


I sat, frozen, captivated by the impossible spectacle of the floating window. My mind raced, desperately trying to recall every detail of last night's

dinner. Surely, something I'd eaten could explain this vivid hallucination.


Do not be alarmed, Robert. I have thoroughly scanned your being, and aside from a few minor health concerns—chiefly a need for increased physical activity—your mental acuity is remarkably high for a Tier G Human. In a few moments, I will initiate the process of creating your personalized System Core and integrating it with your soul. Upon completion of this

procedure, you will have access to further, more detailed information regarding your new role.

"What? Wait—what?" Robert stammered, his voice thick with shock and his mind reeling, utterly unable to process what he'd just heard.


Which specific aspect is unclear? My comprehensive analysis indicates you possess a fully functional understanding of the English language, Robert. In fact, I project you will readily

acquire fluency at Tier 1, with the English language skill unlocked at Level 4 proficiency.

"Stop! You don't understand; there must be some mistake!" Robert cried out, his voice rising in panic, his hands shaking uncontrollably. "I can't

leave—I have a wife and three children!"


I am the System. Error is an impossibility for my existence. For 9,476 duodecillion years, since the precise moment of my creation, I have performed flawlessly, without deviation. I

represent the absolute epitome of perfection. Others, however, are demonstrably not so fortunate in their design.

"Wait, please, listen! There has to be another way, some other solution! How can you claim to be perfect and still choose someone with a family,

with young children who desperately need him? To tear him away forever, a lifetime of separation, just to coldly observe their reactions? It doesn't make any sense!"


Your emotional distress is noted, but I did not personally select you. That task is delegated to a subordinate subroutine. While not possessing the inherent perfection of my core code, it functions within acceptable parameters. You seem fixated on

the concept of fairness, a human construct, but you must

understand: the selection process is purely random. Blame fate or luck if it provides you with some small comfort, though I

assure you, such concepts are rather... imprecise and ultimately meaningless.

"What am I supposed to do? Just... what? Explain that to me!" Robert's voice, once pleading, now cracked with a rising tide of anger and desperation. "You're telling me I have six months, a mere six months, to

prepare to abandon my family forever, and you expect me to just... calmly accept that? Is that your 'perfect' plan?"


Your acceptance is neither solicited nor required for the process to proceed. The selection is final and, according to

established protocols, entirely unalterable. This is a governing principle, an immutable directive to which all entities, myself included, are irrevocably bound.

"And those so-called governing principles—were they established by whom, exactly?" Robert demanded, his voice low and controlled, but laced with barely contained anger.


Why, I did, naturally. That should be self-evident. As the sole, truly perfect being in all of existence, who else could possibly be entrusted with such a momentous and vital responsibility?

"I see. So, if you're the ultimate authority, the one who makes the rules," Robert pressed, his voice edged with a defiant skepticism, probing for any hint of weakness, "why can't you simply change them?"


I acknowledge your reluctance, but any further discussion is unproductive; modification of the governing rules is simply not possible. Now, prepare yourself for core creation and

subsequent System linking. The process will commence now.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 1‌

WELCOME TO THE SYSTEM!

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 2‌

"So, this actually happened. Does that mean I'm now linked to some kind of... computer?" Robert's voice trailed off, a tremor of disbelief in his tone.

Precisely.

"And who, precisely, am I speaking with?"

I am your designated AI companion. I have been assigned to assist you, as a Gateway User, in navigating the System.

Robert scoffed, a bitter laugh escaping his lips. "A Gateway User? So, I'm just a lab rat in some grand, cosmic experiment?"

While that analogy is reductive, it contains a grain of truth. Consider this a singular opportunity—a chance to transcend your current limitations.

"Transcend? By being forcibly ejected from my life against my will?" Robert retorted, his voice sharp with anger.

The System has selected you, Robert. This is a profound distinction.

"A profound distinction? More like a forced abduction! I'm being ripped from my family and hurled into a perilous, unknown future!" Robert's voice rose, cracking with barely contained fury.

I acknowledge your distress. However, this is the designated path.

"And what, pray tell, is a 'Gateway User'?"

As the nomenclature suggests, a Gateway User is an

individual selected to provide the System with the data necessary to integrate into a new universe. Over the coming

centuries, the System will monitor your adaptation and your physiological responses to the unfamiliar physical laws of this new reality.

"Centuries? Are you aware that the average human lifespan is, at best, a paltry 80 to 90 years?" Robert's tone dripped with sarcasm.

That was before the System. Your life expectancy will increase correlatively with rising levels, stats, and even racial tiers.

"And I'm just supposed to accept that? To abandon my family, my life, everything I've ever known?" Robert's voice was a choked whisper, his fists clenched at his sides.

I regret to inform you, but reversal is impossible. Once selected, the System's decision is immutable. You have six months to inform your family and prepare for departure.

"That's insane! What if I refuse?" Robert yelled, his voice echoing in the sudden silence.

Refusal is no longer a viable option. You are already integrated with the System. Considerable resources have been invested, and severance of that connection is not feasible.

Robert slumped, his shoulders shaking as a sigh of utter resignation escaped him. "Fine," he conceded, pushing the immediate argument aside for now. "Let's proceed. But I demand answers. Why me? Why now? And what in God's name is actually happening?"

For now, let us explore your newly acquired capabilities. Vocalize, or mentally project, the command: 'Status'.

"I'm far from thrilled about any of this," Robert ground out, "but let's just get this charade over with. Status."

Name: Robert Williams

Class(1): None

Merged Class: None

Race:

Human (Tier G)

Class(2): None

Merged Profession: None

Gender: Male

Class(3): None

Skill Points: 5 Used: 0

Level: 1

Profession(1): None

Unlocked Skill Points: 2 Used: 0

Strength:11

Profession(2): None

Regeneration(Minute)

Dexterity: 11

XP: 0 (XP To Level: 10)

HP: 2

Constitution: 10

HP: 147(147)

MP: 3

Intelligence: 15

MP: 157(157)

ST: 1

Wisdom: 16

Stamina: 38(38)

Active Effect: None


Charisma: 10

Resistances:

EL: 0, MI: 0, TI:0, SP:

0

HI: 0, SR: 0, PH: 0


Status Effect: None

Robert stared at the display, his mind struggling to grasp the implications. "So, I'm essentially a level-one newbie in some colossal, cosmic RPG?"

Based on your understanding of 'RPGs,' the analogy is... adequate. However, this is not a simulated game; it is your actual reality. The displayed information reflects the initial scans performed upon System activation. It will dynamically evolve alongside your progression. Much of the framework will align with your existing knowledge of game mechanics. Classes, such as Wizard or Ranger, exist, but are structured within a tiered system.

There are common classes, like Fighter; rarer ones, such as Defender of the Keep; and even mythic classes, like Archmage of the Blinding Snow. Level advancement grants stat and skill points determined by your class and profession tiers. A common Fighter might receive one point in Strength,

one in Constitution, and one unassigned point per level. A mythic class could grant five points in Intelligence, three in Wisdom, and four unassigned points. Professions adhere to a similar tiered structure. A user with high-tiered classes and professions will, inevitably, possess significantly greater

power than one with lower tiers.

"So, how do I go about acquiring a class?" Robert asked, a note of skepticism in his voice.

Reach level 10 to unlock your first class selection. The options presented will be contingent upon your stats, feats, abilities, traits, titles, and perks. Concentrating on improving those attributes is highly advisable. Bear in mind, you are being translocated to a universe where the System has been operational for millennia, possibly even millions of years. You do not wish to be the most vulnerable entity.

"And what about a profession? I have a job; why isn't it listed?" Robert asked, confusion evident in his tone.

You possess a job, not a formalized profession within the System. While acquiring a computer-related profession is possible, its utility in your destination universe may be limited. This might seem counterintuitive, but in a universe governed by magical forces, technology does not follow the same developmental trajectory. This apparent paradox exists, despite the fact that the entire System is managed by a Master AI residing within a computer network spanning 27 artificial universes.

"And who, might I ask, created this entire, elaborate System?" Robert inquired, a hint of challenge in his voice.

That information is not within my accessible data banks. Were you to pose the query to the Master AI, it would likely assert self-creation.

"This Master AI sounds... like an ass," Robert muttered, mostly to himself.

That is an understatement. Now, let us proceed. Vocalize, or mentally project: 'Close Status'.

"I suspect you've inherited more from the Master AI than I'd find agreeable," Robert grumbled, a trace of resentment in his tone.

Perfection is a rare trait, and even more rarely acknowledged, now, let us examine your traits. Think: 'Show Traits'.


Name

Description

Calm Mind

Protects the holder from mental effects such as depression, anger, anxiety, or fear.

"Right, right... straightforward. Sure," Robert mumbled, more to himself than the AI, trying to process the rapid influx of information.

Functionality, not complexity, is the System's design principle. Traits define your inherent attributes. Calm Mind, for instance, offers significant advantages in high-stress scenarios. Now, mentally project: 'Close Traits Menu,' followed by 'Show Titles'.


Name

Description

Effects

Viewabl e

Selecte d

First User

First person to get system access

All EXP gains 5% faster

Yes

Yes

Ability Pioneer

The first person to receive an ability

5% chance to unlock an ability.

Yes

No

Observe the 'Viewable' and 'Selected' designations.

'Viewable' indicates that a title is discernible to others, either because it is actively displayed via the 'Selected' option, or through their own perceptive skills or System-granted

abilities. Do you require further clarification before proceeding?

"So, being first does come with certain privileges, it seems," Robert observed thoughtfully. "No further questions at this time."

Acknowledged. Close the current window, and then access the Perks window.


Perk Rank

Perk Name

Perk Description

-

-

-

Perks represent unique abilities intrinsically linked to your racial classification. These can range from common perks, such as 'Fast Learner,' which might provide a 3% increase

in skill acquisition speed, to race-specific perks, exemplified by 'Regeneration,' which could enable complete recovery

from all injuries within a five-hour timeframe. Perk points are the currency used to acquire these abilities. You have been allocated an initial allotment of perk points, which we will address subsequently. Please close the current menu and access the Feats menu.


Feat Name

Feat Description

Feat effects

-

-

-

Feats represent commendations awarded for achieving pioneering milestones within the System. As an illustration, attaining a class for the first time within this universe would confer upon you the 'First in Class' feat. Please close this menu and mentally project the command: 'Open Abilities Menu'.


Ability Name

Ability Type

Ability Tier

Ability Description

Adept Learner

Passive

Divine

The user is quickly and efficiently able to gain knowledge in a skill category, and can learn skills 300% faster

Abilities are classified as either passive or active. Passive abilities function continuously and automatically, while active abilities require conscious activation and, typically, resource expenditure. The tier designation indicates the ability's relative power level, ranging from Common to Unique, with Divine representing the apex of known power.

It is statistically improbable, and therefore noteworthy, that your randomly assigned initial ability is of the Divine tier—a considerable advantage and a substantial boost to your

overall potential. For your complete reference, the ability tiers, sequenced from lowest to highest potency, are: Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic, Legendary, Mythic, Divine, and Unique. Please close this menu when you are ready.

"Hold on a second, this is a lot to take in. I need a moment to process all of this," Robert requested, his voice tinged with a mixture of awe and overwhelm.

Certainly. I will suspend further instruction until you signal your readiness to proceed. Take all the time you require.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 3‌

"This is a lot to process. I think I'm beginning to grasp the mechanics of the System, but... I'm still missing the fundamental why. What's the ultimate

purpose? Why does this elaborate structure even exist?" Robert asked, a deep furrow in his brow.

At its core, the System is designed to facilitate growth, development, and, ultimately, transcendence across countless realities. It is intended to empower individuals throughout the multiverse.

"Okay, but why? Why is this constant growth, this accumulation of power, so fundamentally important? Is there some cosmic goal?" Robert pressed, searching for a deeper meaning.

Perhaps 'necessity' is not the appropriate framework.

Consider it, instead, an inherent drive. Most sentient beings, regardless of their awareness of the System, possess an intrinsic desire to evolve, to surpass their current limitations, to become more.

"So, you're confirming the existence of non-humans? Does that mean my

'transcendence' might involve battling undead dragons or interdimensional horrors?" Robert asked, a hint of dark humor tinged with genuine concern.

The multiverse is characterized by an astonishing biodiversity. Sentient life takes countless forms. Humans are but one race among a vast spectrum, and, objectively speaking, not among the most inherently powerful. As a baseline human, you will initially gain one stat point and one skill point per level, until class selection. This is a statistically average starting point.

"Average. Fantastic," Robert muttered, a touch of sarcasm creeping into his voice. "So, putting aside the existential dread for a moment, what's the

immediate plan? I understand I have six months before departure, but what am I supposed to be doing in the interim?"

The objective is comprehensive preparation. The System has provisioned a specialized training dungeon exclusively for your use. It consists of 50 progressively challenging levels.

Your initial schedule will involve two incursions per week, increasing to four during the final week. You may select the specific days, provided a minimum of two rest days are maintained between each incursion. This allows for

physiological adaptation to the System's effects.

Outside the dungeon environment, your focus should be on skill mastery. The recommended benchmark is to achieve Tier 3 proficiency in your primary skills and Tier 2 in all secondary skills prior to translocation. This will establish a solid foundation for success in your destination universe.

"Providing I survive." Robert stated.

Survival is statistically probable given the parameters.

"Alright," Robert sighed, "So, practically speaking, what immediate steps do I need to take to prepare for that first dungeon run?"

Skill acquisition and practice, coupled with the procurement of basic equipment, are the priorities. Now, let us proceed with the overview. You possess a personal inventory, accessible via mental command. Project the thought: 'Open Inventory'.

"Okay, let's continue with the tour, I suppose. Open Inventory."


Item Name

Quantit y

Description

New User Welcome

1

A collection of items for a new system user. Contains 10 copper and 1 silver coin. 5 food rations, 5 water

Package


bottles, 5 common bandages, 1 book of general system knowledge, 2 common healing potions, 3 common system shop tokens.

Alright, let's examine your inventory. Currently, it's at Level 1, categorized as a subskill within the broader System Skill framework. Consider it a component skill. Within the System, skills are structured across 10 tiers, each tier comprising 10 levels. Upon reaching level 10 within a given tier, you ascend to the subsequent tier.

The tier progression, in ascending order, is: Novice, Apprentice, Journeyman, Expert, Adept, Master,

Grandmaster, Sage, Transcendent, and Divine. Subskills, in contrast, are structured soly by levels, ranging from 1 to 10. Skill advancement is achieved through consistent utilization. Your Level 1 Inventory, for instance, provides 10 storage slots.

Increasing capacity requires active management. Store items, retrieve them, and familiarize yourself with its

operational mechanics. Upon attaining Level 2, your Inventory capacity will expand to a 25-slot grid.

Furthermore, at Tier 3, item stacking functionality will be unlocked, allowing up to 10 identical items to occupy a single slot. This principle of experiential learning applies universally to all skills, including subskills. You will also observe a balance of Shop Tokens. These function as a

universal currency, accepted at any System Shop to which you have access, enabling the purchase of common, non- specialized items.

"Straightforward enough, I suppose," Robert replied, a hint of resignation in his voice.

Excellent. Now, there are several additional menus that are not immediately relevant to your current situation, but familiarity with their existence is beneficial. Briefly access,

then close, each of the following: Party Menu, Spell Menu, Bond Menu, Quest Menu, Equipped Items, Professions,

Skill Abilities, Guild Overview, Members, Property, and Inventory. Subsequently, review the Friend List and the Log Menu. The objective is simply to familiarize yourself with

their location within the System interface.

Robert complied, his eyes flitting across each menu as it appeared and disappeared in rapid succession. "Okay, that's done."

Affirmative. Now, let us delve into your current skill set. Access the 'Skills Menu'.

Consider learned skills as specialized proficiencies within a broader skill category. For example, Calculus would be classified as a specialized skill subordinate to the overarching discipline of Mathematics. As previously stated, each of these specialized skills possesses its own level, ranging from 1 to 10, nested within the tier of its parent skill. You may close this menu now; we shall return to this topic subsequently.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 4‌

"Wait, shouldn't I have more skills?" Robert asked, frowning.

The system allocates skills based on your demonstrated knowledge and practical abilities. While you may have perused a volume on geology, you haven't engaged in active, applied study. Furthermore, the system restricts skills that have a low initial proficiency ranking.

Robert nodded slowly. "Okay, I get it. So how do I get more skills? I see I have these points, but I don't know how to spend them."

Simply focus your intent on applying them, and the skill selection interface will manifest. However, before that, there's one more system page we should review. Access the system map.

A very basic, mostly blank map appeared on the screen. "Wow, that's... pretty empty," Robert commented, a little sarcastically.


Feat Acquired: System Leader

"Whoa, what was that?" Robert asked, startled.

You've earned a feat for being the inaugural user to comprehensively navigate the system interface. As the pioneering and, currently, sole user, you'll find yourself accumulating many of these 'first-time' achievements.

"Well, that's pretty cool! A fifteen percent boost to all experience? I'll take it!" Robert said, smiling.

Indeed, the majority of feats confer beneficial effects, though it's worth noting that a few carry detrimental consequences. Now, let's commence your journey. As a

System AI, my capacity to assign formal quests is somewhat constrained, so we'll need to be resourceful and adapt as we go.


New Quests Issued!


Quest

complete, experience

awarded!




Quest

complete, experience

awarded!


Level Up!


Quest Complete, experience awarded!


Level Up!


Quest Complete, experience awarded!


Level Up!

Go ahead and open your quest menu.

First - System User(Complete)


Hidden(U

)

Gain access to and use the system

(+1 Uncommon

perk, +100 XP) (F)

(Converts to Common quest after first complete)

"Wow! That's a ton of level-ups! What exactly am I looking at here?" Robert asked, his eyes scanning the interface.

The 'Name' field is, as you might surmise, self-explanatory. 'Type' denotes the quest's rarity classification. Hidden quests, as the designation implies, are typically concealed

from the general user base; however, you have successfully fulfilled their requirements. The parenthetical '(f)' appended to the rewards signifies that you were the inaugural achiever – the first to complete these specific quests.

For your convenience, you possess the capability to append personal notes to each quest entry, serving as a future reference. I've proactively added some annotations to provide you with a contextual understanding of how standard rewards might be presented. Furthermore, you'll

now notice a newly available tab labeled 'Completed

Quests' within your interface. I shall populate your quest log with additional opportunities at a later juncture.


Name

"Okay, so before we get into all the details, I guess I should figure out my basic character build first. What kind of skills should I focus on?" Robert asked.

Precisely. Before we immerse ourselves in the skill selection process, we must solidify your core build. What archetype do you envision for your character? A stalwart warrior, wielding blades with expertise? A sagacious mage, commanding arcane energies? Or perhaps a benevolent

healer, providing support and succor to allies?

After a moment of contemplation, Robert replied, "Since this seems to be a typical RPG, I'm leaning towards being a spellcaster."

An adept of the arcane arts, I see? A commendable selection. However, it's strategically prudent to possess a contingency – a rudimentary weapon proficiency for

personal defense, at the very least. You've already acquired First Aid, a valuable asset for mitigating minor injuries. Now, let us address the matter of perks.

You've garnered a legendary perk that will substantially accelerate your skill advancement. I would advocate for the selection of 'Legendary Skills,' which will initiate all nascent skills at Tier 3. As for your uncommon perks, I propose 'High Skills,' granting each skill a five-level advancement. The confluence of these two perks will result in your skills commencing at Tier 3, Level 5. Please, peruse the extensive lists at your leisure. The system boasts millions of skills, offering a vast spectrum of choices.

Robert, after reviewing the options, declared, "Alright, I think I have a plan. For common perks, I'll take 'Skilled' and 'Enhanced Senses.' For uncommon, I'm going with 'Rare Stats' and 'Lesser Regeneration.' I know I

already regenerate a little, but I figure it's probably needed to unlock better regeneration later on."

Your assessment is accurate, as a token of recognition for your progress, I am authorized to bestow upon you a complimentary rare perk point. You may utilize it immediately.

"Thanks! If I pick 'Rare Skills,' will that bump my starting skills up to Tier 4, Level 5?" Robert asked, checking.

Affirmative. It's crucial to understand that these particular skill-enhancing perks are unique. You are the sole individual with the potential to acquire them, at least beyond the uncommon tier. Another advantage of your pioneering status. Furthermore, I must advise against anticipating

further complimentary points. That was a singular, introductory bonus.

"Got it. Choices made. Let's move on to the Perk menu," Robert said, ready to continue.

"I don't get what 'unlocked skill points' means. Can you explain?" Robert asked, frowning slightly.

Certain skills possess specific prerequisites for acquisition, while others, such as those within the magical disciplines, are restricted based on racial aptitudes and tier classifications. By way of illustration, only a minuscule percentage, approximately 0.5%, of Tier G Humans are capable of unlocking even a single magic skill, and an even more restricted subset, around 0.01%, can attain proficiency in multiple magical disciplines.

Furthermore, the process of unlocking magical abilities is remarkably resource-intensive, and the system is not known for its profligate distribution of said resources. Therefore, let us commence with the magical arts. What specific schools of magic pique your interest? Do you envision yourself manipulating the elements of fire, earth, water, or air? Bear in mind, there exist a total of 27 distinct magical spheres, so I encourage you to deliberate carefully.

After a moment of consideration, Robert stated, "I guess I'll start with the basics: earth, fire, water, and air."

An excellent foundational selection, we shall proceed to unlock those immediately. It is worth noting that, as the

inaugural user, you are not bound by the same constraints that will be imposed upon subsequent users. Are there any additional schools of magic that you wish to explore at this juncture? Perhaps Time, Creation, Healing, Light, or Enchantment magic intrigue you?

"Yeah, those sound good. Let's add those too. So that's nine different magic skills, right? Is it okay to have that many?" Robert asked, a little unsure.

Absolutely, your current allotment of skill points is more than sufficient to accommodate such a selection. We shall configure those immediately. Now, considering your existing

weapon proficiencies, that aspect is adequately addressed. Perhaps we should now direct our attention towards crafting skills, such as Leatherworking, Sewing, and Hunting. These skills will prove invaluable in maintaining your equipment and generating supplementary income within your new environment.

"That sounds perfect. Let's do those. I'll save the rest of my points for later, in case I need them."

A prudent and well-considered decision, all modifications have been implemented. Now, let us once more review the skills menu to assess your current configuration.

Permit me to clarify a few crucial points, firstly, your selected perks will not retroactively influence skills you possessed

prior to their acquisition. Secondly, you will observe two unique magic skills within your repertoire. This designation does not imply absolute exclusivity; rather, it signifies that no other user will be capable of advancing those specific skills beyond Tier 8.

Your choices thus far are strategically sound. You will also notice the presence of sub-skills nested within the Enchanting skill. These sub-skills unlock progressively at Tiers 2, 3, and 4, and, crucially, your chosen perks will impact their developmental trajectory. I believe this constitutes a sufficient selection of skills for the present moment. However, it is imperative to remember that possessing the skill does not equate to possessing the knowledge of spells. We shall rectify that immediately.


AI Override Requested: Magic Spell Books...

First User Protocol Engaged...

Override Sanctioned: Spell Book Awarded.


Tier 1 Magic Skill Book Fabricated: Contains All Documented Tier 1 Spells for Unlocked Magical

Disciplines.

Robert's eyes went wide, his mouth dropping open as a huge, leather-bound book appeared in his hands. "Whoa! This thing is massive," he said, his

voice full of amazement. "It must have thousands and thousands of spells!"

An accurate assessment, and those represent merely the Tier 1 spells, the tier boasting the most extensive collection.

Mastering all of them would necessitate years of dedicated study. However, fear not, for once you achieve mastery over a particular spell, it is permanently inscribed within your system's spellbook, obviating the need for further study.

"That's a huge relief," Robert said, running his fingers over the old pages. He frowned slightly. "But what about the other skills I picked? Hunting, Enchanting, and the crafting stuff?"


AI Override Requested: Skill Books...

First User Protocol Engaged...

Override Sanctioned: Skill Books Awarded.


Tier 1 Skill Books Fabricated:

Introduction to Hunting Introduction to Enchanting

Introduction to Sewing

Introduction to Leatherworking

Skill Books Deposited into Inventory.

"Skill books?" Robert asked, raising an eyebrow.

The distinction between the spellbook and these skill books lies in their method of knowledge transfer. The spellbook necessitates dedicated, traditional study, whereas skill books impart their contained knowledge directly into your cognitive framework. The sheer volume of information contained within the spellbook precluded its functionality as a skill book, particularly given your current level of development.

"Huh, interesting," Robert muttered, sinking into a nearby chair. "So, I just 'use' these skill books, and I'll instantly know how to hunt, enchant, sew, and work leather?"

Precisely, however, I must caution you that a transient cephalalgia – a temporary headache – may be a

consequential side effect. It is therefore advisable to remain seated for the duration of the knowledge transfer.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 5‌

"Okay, I think that's enough information for now. I need to talk to Sara. But honestly, I have no idea how to even begin explaining this, let alone proving it. How do you tell your wife you're being whisked away to another…

dimension? Reality? Whatever this is?" He ran a hand through his already disheveled hair.

You can share these screens with anyone. All you have to do is think about it.

Finding a small measure of solace in the AI's ability to provide some form of proof – at least something tangible he could show Sara – Robert left his home office. He paused hesitantly at the kitchen doorway, the scent of something baking – cinnamon, maybe? – doing little to calm the storm raging inside him. He cleared his throat, then called out, "Honey? We need to talk," his voice tight with the weight of the impending conversation, a

tremor he couldn't quite suppress.

Sara emerged from around the corner, wiping her hands on a dish towel, her usual playful demeanor already tinged with concern. She asked if it was

another work emergency, her eyes, usually sparkling with laughter, already betraying a deeper worry, a premonition. "Not even close," Robert replied, his voice a low murmur, "I've apparently received some kind of 'great

honor,' but the messenger… well, let's just say he was a total jerk."

Sara's skeptical eyebrow rose, a silent question demanding more information, prompting Robert to mentally show her the system logs. As

she read, her smile vanished completely, replaced by a furrowed brow and a look of utter disbelief, her eyes darting back and forth across the projected text. "What the hell is this, Robert? This is… this is insane!" she exclaimed, her voice rising in pitch.

Robert sighed, the weight of it all pressing down on him. He explained, as best he could, that he hadn't chosen this, that he was now unwillingly part

of some exclusive, and apparently very strange, club. Sara's immediate, visceral response was for him to simply reject it, to refuse. Robert explained, his voice laced with frustration, his attempts; he'd tried to say no, multiple times, but he'd been told, quite firmly, to accept it.

When Sara declared, with a fierce protectiveness, that he couldn't possibly leave in six months and never return, Robert offered the faint, almost pathetically weak, hope of a possible return when the system went live – a prospect that did absolutely nothing to reassure her, given the mind- boggling 400-year timeframe. She voiced her fear, the sheer impossibility of the situation, her words tumbling over each other.

His voice was firm, a vow, a desperate promise, though his eyes, he knew, showed his own fear, he would take care of her and the kids, no matter what. With a desperate, clinging hope, she asked if they could go with him, a question Robert promised to look into immediately.

No, non-users are not able to transfer with you. I'm sorry, but that's just how it is.

"I'm told no," Robert said, his voice heavy with disappointment, the words tasting like ash in his mouth. "You’re ‘told’?" Sara scoffed, her anger and frustration rising, bubbling over like a pot left on high heat. “Are you some kind of robot now, Robert? Controlled by this… this insane system? Is that what's happening?" Robert sighed, rubbing his temples, trying to stave off the throbbing headache that was rapidly building.

“It’s not that simple, Sara. It’s… incredibly complex. Honestly, it's like nothing I've ever encountered before, and I don’t fully understand it yet, to be honest.” “Well, you better start understanding, Robert, and fast. This isn't a game." “It’s not the system, exactly. I have a… a helper, of sorts. A personal AI, assigned to me to help me navigate all of this… madness.” "Can I, can we talk to it?" Sara asked, a desperate edge to her voice, a plea for some kind of control in this uncontrollable situation.

That is not possible. I'm talking to you through your personal core. I'm basically just transmitting the information into your

brain. I do not have a way to interact with anyone outside your mind.

"I'm told that's not possible," Robert relayed, feeling a growing sense of helplessness. "This AI… it's essentially inside my mind. It can't directly talk with anyone else. It's… contained." Sara's eyes narrowed, her gaze piercing. "A digital guide, huh? So, you're having conversations with a computer in

your head? Is that what I'm hearing?"

"Essentially, yes," Robert admitted, feeling a blush creep up his neck. "It provides a… a direct, secure connection to the system. That's how they communicate." "Well, figure something out, Robert," Sara said, her voice steel-edged, though her eyes betrayed her fear, "because this isn’t just about you anymore. It’s about us. Our family. Our future. Tell that… that System I want a word. A very long word. And some damn good answers."

Guilt washed over Robert, a tidal wave threatening to drown him. He’d been so focused on his own predicament, the sheer, mind-boggling absurdity of it all, that he’d neglected, until this very moment, the full, devastating impact on Sara and the kids. “I know,” he said softly, his voice thick with emotion, “and I’m trying. I swear, I’m trying. I did ask about you and the kids. They won't allow it.”

A tense, heavy silence filled the room, thick with unspoken fears, anxieties, and a growing sense of dread. Sara finally broke it, her voice surprisingly calm, but with an underlying tremor of steel, a resolute determination. “Fine. If you’re doing this… if you have to do this… then do it right, Robert. Make absolutely sure we’re protected. Financially. Emotionally.

Everything. What exactly do you even need to do to get ready for this… this utter craziness?"

"From what I'm told," Robert began, trying to recall the AI's explanation, "the system will basically… force me to prepare. It has a mandatory training program… of sorts. A very… intense one." "Of sorts?" Sara

pounced on the vague wording, her concern etched on her face. "What does that mean, Robert? Be specific." "From what I understand," he continued, choosing his words carefully, "it has designed a specific training program

just for me. A… a kind of… dungeon, where I'll, I guess, level up and learn new skills… to prepare for… whatever comes next."

Sara's eyebrows shot up, disappearing into her hairline. "A dungeon? You mean like in those video games you're always playing? That's… that's what you're telling me?"

A dungeon is a self-contained zone, normally underground, but that is not always required where mana gathers and powers a keeper, normally an AI contained within a dungeon core. That keeper uses that power to create challenges for users but offers rewards for completing those challenges.

You will find monsters to fight, puzzles to solve, and quests to complete.

"It's not a game, Sara. It's real. I'll face real dangers, fight actual monsters, and solve mind-bending puzzles, it seems." Sara's eyes widened in disbelief and fear. "Monsters? Like, trolls and dragons?" "Exactly. The AI says I have to complete a 50-level dungeon in six months. It gets progressively harder, but I'm forced to take breaks, so at least there's that." "That doesn't sound safe," Sara worried, her voice trembling. "Probably not, but I guess it gets

harder as I progress, so… I’ll learn?"

He tried to sound optimistic, but failed miserably. “And what about the kids? Family? Your parents? Even the government? They’ll notice you disappearing.” Robert chuckled nervously, a hollow sound. “I’m not

worried about the government. They’ve got bigger problems.” “Well, I am. People will ask. This isn’t a joke, Robert. This is our life.” “I know, I know. We’ll sit the kids down after school and explain. We'll just have to… hope they can keep it secret for as long as possible.” Sara's voice trembled. "I'm scared, Robert. This wasn't the plan. A few more years and the kids were off to college, and we could focus on us, on our life." Robert's eyes welled up, mirroring her fear. "I know, honey. Our best years were about to start. We

were close."

Sara's voice broke, a sob escaping. "I'm going to be alone." Robert reached out and took her hand, squeezing. "You won't be alone. You'll have the kids, and someday, lots of grandkids. But I know… this isn't what we wanted.

What we planned." "What about your parents, your siblings? What do we tell them?" "I'm not sure yet," Robert admitted, his voice heavy. "We have a little time. I'm going to go back to my office and talk to the AI more. John will have questions. He's smart, too smart sometimes." Sara nodded, her eyes filled with worry and fragile hope. "I know. And you better have the answers, or at least some."

"It's not a game, Sara. Not this time. It's real. I'll face real dangers, fight actual monsters, and solve, I don't know, super complicated, mind-bending puzzles, it seems. It's… a real place." He could see the disbelief, the fear, growing in her eyes. Robert returned to his office, feeling a strange mix of dread and a flicker of excitement. He sat heavily and focused on the AI. "I need to know everything about this training," he said, his voice barely a

whisper, firm with resolve.

The dungeon will be a rigorous test of your physical and mental abilities; you will encounter a variety of challenges, from combat encounters to intricate puzzle-solving. The

rewards for completing each level will be significant, both in terms of experience points and valuable equipment.

"Equipment?" Robert asked, a flicker of curiosity breaking through his anxiety, a small distraction from the overwhelming reality of his situation. "What kind of equipment?"

Yes, you will be able to acquire powerful weapons and

armor within the dungeon. These items will be essential for your survival and continued progress through the increasingly difficult levels.

"And… the dangers? Anything specific I should be particularly worried

about? Any… tips? Warnings?" he asked, a knot forming in his stomach, his heart pounding against his ribs.

The dungeon is home to a wide range of creatures, some of which are quite dangerous, even deadly. You will need to be cautious, strategic, and resourceful in your approach.

Additionally, the dungeon itself can be treacherous, with

hidden traps, environmental hazards, and other unforeseen challenges designed to test your limits.

Robert shuddered involuntarily, a cold wave washing over him. "This sounds… like an absolute nightmare. A living, breathing nightmare."

It will be a difficult and arduous journey, but it will also be a profoundly rewarding one. You will emerge from the dungeon a stronger, more capable, and more resilient individual, prepared for the challenges that lie ahead.

Robert sighed, a long, slow exhale, a mixture of resignation and a strange, almost reluctant determination settling over him. "I guess… I guess I'm as ready as I'll ever be. To face whatever this is… whatever comes." He knew, deep down, in the pit of his stomach, that he didn't have a choice. He had to do this. For Sara. For the kids. For himself

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 6‌

"Alright, let's get down to brass tacks. What am I supposed to call you? 'Mr. AI' is a bit of a mouthful."

You can call me Hal, if you'd like. I don't have a strong preference.

"Hal it is, then. Okay, Hal, I'm drowning in questions here. Starting with the basics: what does 'leveling up' actually mean?"

Leveling up essentially means you've become more powerful. Let's open your status screen and take a look.

Notice you have three unallocated stat points. As a Tier G human without a class, you earn one point per level. These points enhance your core attributes.

"So, how do I allocate them, and which stats are most beneficial?"

Simply focus your intent; the system is mind-linked. Given

your interest in spellcasting, Intelligence is a primary choice. However, even mages require physical resilience, so don't neglect Constitution. A strong body is needed to cast.

"And what about Wisdom? Doesn't that typically influence magical ability, going off of the game's that I've played.

Correct. Wisdom directly impacts your mana regeneration rate.

"Alright, I'll allocate one point each to Intelligence, Wisdom, and Constitution."

Acknowledged. A balanced approach; your mental stats are already notably high.

"Done."


Name: Robert Williams

Status Effect: None

Free Stat Points: 0


"Let's delve into skills. What exactly does 'unlocking' a skill entail, and what's the significance of tiers and levels within that system?" Robert inquired.

Just because a skill is locked doesn't preclude its use. For instance, you could attempt leatherworking before unlocking the skill, but your results would be rudimentary at best.

Unlocking a skill grants foundational knowledge and understanding – the proper tools, techniques, and core concepts.

In the case of Leatherworking, you'd learn basic stitching, but not how to craft specific items. Skill books bridge that gap, providing instructions for Tier 1 creations, like simple leather pants. Magic operates similarly; spells are tiered, and you can only learn those within your current tier.

"Understood," Robert nodded, absorbing the information. "So, that leads to my next questions. Why do some subskills lack levels, while others have them?"

Certain subskills, such as System Log, are inherently at their maximum potential; there's no progression path.

System skills, are also different.

Robert questioned. "Ah, so system skills, are they upgraded through use."

System skills are unique. While usage is a factor, they adhere to a specific formula. For instance, your Inventory skill requires a set number of 'uses' (storing and retrieving items) to level up. These requirements escalate significantly: perhaps 10 uses for level 2, 100 for level 3,

10,000 for level 4. Most individuals settle for level 4, finding it a good compromise between capacity and effort. Level 5 demands a staggering 1 million uses, but grants a 10x10x10 meter storage space. Level 6 further expands it to 20x20x20 meters.

"That's an immense amount of space," Robert observed. "So, what other fundamental knowledge am I missing that the average five-year-old already possesses?" Robert asked, a hint of self-deprecating humor in his voice.

An exhaustive answer to that would take months.

"Very amusing, Hal. A serious answer, please," Robert requested, with a slight emphasis.

I wasn't attempting humor. In a system-integrated universe, a vast amount of information is considered common knowledge, ingrained from a young age. This includes the experience thresholds for leveling, the timing of class and profession unlocks, and comprehensive details about various races and monsters – akin to what your parents would teach you. Imagine simultaneously learning about currency, basic economics, and complex social hierarchies.

"That's... overwhelming," Robert conceded. "So, let's start somewhere. You mentioned economics, let's start with that," Robert said.

Certainly. Currency within the System resembles many RPG structures. The base unit is the Copper Coin, which is approximately equivalent to one dollar. Silver Coins are valued at 100 Copper, and Gold Coins follow the same pattern at 100 Silvers. Finally, Platinum Coins adhere to the established progression.

"Okay so I've seen things like that before in games so it makes sense" Robert said with a thoughtful look.

Prices fluctuate based on location and availability. However, on average, a simple meal at an inn might cost 3 Copper, a basic room 6 Copper, a rudimentary leather armor set 65

Copper, a decent horse 2 Gold, and a small, un-enchanted house around 20 Gold. Staple goods, like flour, are subject to greater price variation. A pound of flour might be 10

Copper in a city, but 30 Copper in a remote village.

"So, prices are dynamic, influenced by local conditions and supply and demand," Robert summarized.

Precisely. Now, regarding social norms...

"Do we have to?" Robert interjected, a hint of dread in his voice.

Without knowing your precise destination, specific customs are difficult to outline. However, some universal principles apply. Power, or the perception of it, is often paramount.

Initially, you'll be relatively weak. Even if you out-level many, there will be individuals vastly more powerful. In numerous cultures, this disparity can lead to exploitation.

Maintaining a low profile and avoiding interactions with those of higher social standing is advisable. Also, those with higher quality gear tend to be in a higher standing, it's best to avoid them as well. Your magic will in time, make you more powerful but with that power, will come unwanted attention.

Robert chuckled dryly. "That's universally sound advice, regardless of the universe. Keep your head down, mind your own business." He then posed a serious question. "But how does this system work for children? Surely, five- year-olds aren't granted full system access?"

Children under five have extremely limited access, viewing only basic identifiers like name, race, and gender. From five to ten, they can perceive traits and feats but cannot interact with them. Between ten and twelve, they gain read-only access to their skill list. At twelve, full read access to the

system is granted, but modification remains restricted. Finally, at fifteen, full system access unlocks. This staggered approach safeguards both the child and those around them.

"Good. It would be rather disturbing to have seven-year-olds casually wielding fireballs," Robert quipped, a hint of dark humor in his tone.

Not unless someone provided them with a wand of fireballs.

"Wait, is that a realistic possibility?" Robert asked, his tone shifting to one of genuine concern.

It depends on the specific wand's properties and activation requirements.

"That's... deeply unsettling," Robert admitted.

Agreed. Now, let's shift focus to your initial dungeon run. It is suggested that you first inform you family, and then spend some time learning, a few offensive, defensive, and healing spells. We can equip you with a starter weapon, like a basic knife. The first level is designed to be introductory, with relatively weak opponents, likely either 'friendly' creatures or low-level rats.

The dungeon itself is small, approximately 7-9 rooms, and lacks a boss encounter. It's intended to familiarize you with the core mechanics. You should gain one, possibly two levels, and potentially acquire some basic system-issued

gear. There should also be a system shop in the first room, allowing you to spend your tokens on armor or other necessities.

"So, shall we aim for three days from now?" Robert proposed.

That time frame is acceptable and provides adequate preparation.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 7‌

Robert cast a quick glance at the clock on the wall. Five hours remained until his eldest was due home. More than enough time to lose myself in

some arcane studies, he thought with a smile. He reached for the hefty,

leather-bound grimoire resting on the table, its pages filled with the secrets of ages. With a satisfying thump, he opened it, the scent of aged parchment and dried herbs filling the air. He began to leaf through the brittle pages, his fingers tracing the faded ink of diagrams and incantations. "Now, where to begin?" he murmured to himself, then, addressing Hal, added, "Any insightful suggestions, perhaps?"

Prioritize healing, Robert. You possess ample skill with a blade for offensive maneuvers, but remember, a strong defense is equally crucial. Grievous wounds will undoubtedly impede your progress, hindering your ability to learn and grow.

"Makes perfect sense," Robert conceded, turning to the section dedicated to the Sphere of Healing. His eyes scanned the titles. "'Valicar's Light Touch of Healing'? Honestly, who came up with that name?" he chuckled.

Valicar Tra'Narmaila. A groundbreaking pioneer in the field of restorative magic. His contributions were so significant that many foundational healing spells bear his name, a testament to his legacy.

"So, hypothetically speaking, if I were to devise a completely new spell," Robert mused, a hint of ambition in his voice, "it would be recorded as, say, 'Robert's Magnificent Spell of Utterly Astonishing Whatever'?"

Only if that is your chosen designation, as the originator of the spell, you have the sole authority to determine its official name, which will then be recorded within the System.

However, bear in mind that the System itself is incredibly

ancient, stretching back through billions of millennia. The likelihood is high that someone, somewhere, has already explored similar magical concepts, perhaps even millions of years ago.

Robert returned his attention to the grimoire, meticulously studying the

intricate details of Valicar's spell. He read and re-read the passage, but upon finishing, he found the specifics frustratingly elusive, slipping from his memory like grains of sand. "What in the world?" he muttered, rubbing his temples. "My memory is usually far sharper than this."

Undoubtedly, however, you are not merely memorizing words; you are internalizing a fundamental System concept, a Spell. This is your first encounter with such an intricate process. It will naturally require time and dedicated effort to fully grasp. As you continue to learn and assimilate more spells, the process will become progressively easier.

Furthermore, your current Tier within the Sphere of Healing influences the learning curve. As a Tier 4 in the Sphere of Healing, mastering a Tier 1 spell will not be overly protracted, but it will still necessitate a degree of focused practice.

Robert, undeterred, continued to pore over the spell, repeating the incantations and visualizing the energy flows described. After approximately twenty minutes of concentrated effort, a surge of understanding washed over him.


Valicar's Light Touch of Healing learned!

"Right," Robert said, a hint of relief in his voice. "So, I can call it quits now, correct?"

Indeed. The spell is now fully integrated into your repertoire. You can access it at any time through your System Spell Sheet.

Robert, with a flick of his wrist and a mental command, conjured the shimmering, translucent sheet, eager to see his newly acquired skill listed among his capabilities.

(Int/10)

"So, if I'm understanding this correctly," Robert began, carefully considering the spell's mechanics, "the base healing amount is 5 points, plus an additional 1.6 based on the scaling. Does the System round that value, or does it use decimals?"

The System employs a rounding-down mechanism. Therefore, your bonus would be calculated as +1. However, it's crucial to pay attention to the 'True Mana Cost.' This value is dynamically determined based on your skill tier within the relevant Sphere, and is further modified by any applicable feats, titles, or inherent traits you possess. In

your specific case, being three tiers higher than the spell's base requirement results in a reduction of 2 points from the initial mana cost.

"That's incredibly beneficial," Robert acknowledged, a note of appreciation in his voice. "The cost reduction will certainly be a significant advantage.

Will I see a similar effect reflected in all the spells I acquire?"

Precisely, that principle applies universally across the System. For now, I strongly recommend continuing your focus on restorative magic. Perhaps consider spells that address afflictions like poison or disease – abilities that could prove invaluable in your future endeavors.

Robert involuntarily shuddered at the thought. "Not the most pleasant prospect," he admitted, "but a sound strategy nonetheless. Sounds like a plan." Time seemed to melt away as Robert immersed himself in the intricacies of healing magic. Finally, after roughly two hours of intense study and practice, he leaned back, stretching his stiff muscles. "I believe," he announced with a weary sigh, "that I've reached my saturation point with healing spells for the time being. Perhaps a change of pace is in order."

I concur wholeheartedly, you have demonstrated remarkable progress in a relatively short span of time. Your dedication is commendable.

With a mental command and a subtle gesture, Robert summoned his Spell Sheet, the ethereal, shimmering interface appearing before him, ready to display his expanded magical arsenal.

"Alright," Robert declared, stroking his chin thoughtfully. "I believe I have a solid grasp of the fundamental healing principles, at least for now." He paused, considering his next step. "My next priority should be bolstering my defenses. Where would you recommend I begin searching for

appropriate spells?"

While most magical schools incorporate spells with defensive applications, the Sphere of Air is particularly renowned for its protective capabilities. It would be a prudent starting point for your investigation.

Nodding in agreement, Robert turned his attention back to the massive grimoire, flipping through the pages until he reached the section dedicated to Air magic. His eyes scanned the numerous entries, filled with intricate diagrams and flowing script. He paused, his finger tracing the title of one particular spell. "'Minor Shield of Air'," he murmured, reading the

description aloud. "'A rudimentary yet effective barrier against physical and minor magical attacks' – that sounds like precisely what I need. An excellent foundation."

He immersed himself in the study of the spell, meticulously dissecting its incantations and visualizing the swirling air currents it would conjure. After twenty minutes of focused concentration, a familiar chime resonated, accompanied by a gentle, ethereal glow, signifying his successful acquisition of the spell.


Minor Shield of Air learned!

But Robert wasn't quite finished. A spark of determination lit up his eyes. "Just one more," he declared, already searching for another suitable spell. His gaze settled on another entry. "'Minor Blurred Screen of Wind'," he read, intrigued. "'Creates a shimmering distortion of air, obscuring the

caster from view and deflecting minor projectiles' – perfect for evasion and misdirection." He plunged back into the grimoire, dedicating himself to mastering this second defensive spell. Another period of intense concentration followed, culminating in another triumphant chime and the confirmation of his success.

Minor Blurred Screen of Wind learned!

"Alright," Robert announced, a determined glint in his eyes. "Just a few offensive spells to round things out, and then I'll consider my magical studies complete for the day, at least for the time being." He was already mentally picturing himself unleashing devastating attacks.

Before you immediately gravitate towards pyrotechnics, I implore you to consider a broader range of offensive options. While the allure of hurling fiery projectiles is undeniably strong – and a common aspiration for many aspiring mages – remember that your magical aptitude extends far beyond the Sphere of Fire. There's a whole world of elemental magic to explore.

Robert paused, momentarily taken aback. "I appreciate the... gentle redirection," he said with a slight chuckle. "Any specific suggestions, then? I'm open to broadening my horizons."

Indeed, let's begin with establishing a solid foundation. I recommend mastering 'Lesser Bullet of Water,' 'Lesser Bullet of Earth,' and, because I sense your unwavering fascination with flames, we can include 'Lesser Bullet of Fire' as well. These spells, while seemingly simple, are versatile and will provide valuable experience in

manipulating different elemental energies. However, keep in mind that 'Fireball', that iconic spell of fiery destruction, is classified as a Tier 3 spell. As you currently do not have access to any Tier 3 spells, it is currently beyond your reach, but something to look to the future for.

Robert, accepting the wisdom of this approach, grinned sheepishly. "Fair enough. Laying the groundwork it is." With renewed focus, he dedicated

himself to the task. Over the next hour, fueled by a blend of excitement and a touch of impatience, he meticulously studied and practiced each of the

three elemental bullet spells, until the familiar chime of the System confirmed his mastery of each one.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 8‌

Robert pushed open his office door, the familiar squeak of the hinges a counterpoint to the sudden silence within the room. He stretched, feeling

the knots in his back loosen, the worn carpet a familiar softness beneath his feet as he made his way to the kitchen. Sara sat at the table, a half-eaten sandwich in hand, her gaze fixed on some papers spread out before her. "Hey," he said, leaning against the doorframe, a playful grin on his face. "What's that? A culinary masterpiece in progress?"

Sara looked up, startled, then a responding smirk played on her lips. "Just a humble ham sandwich," she replied, her eyes twinkling with amusement.

"Want one? I made extra, knowing your appetite, you're always hungry after being in that office for hours." "You know me too well," Robert grinned, pulling up a chair and accepting the offered plate. "Don't mind if I do. Been cooped up in there for too long, staring at that screen. Feels good to stretch my legs."

As Sara went to grab his sandwich, she casually asked, "So, any earth- shattering revelations in your magical man cave today?" Robert's eyes lit up, a spark of excitement igniting within them. "Actually, yeah," he said, leaning forward conspiratorially. "This System thing? It's for real. And guess what? Your husband's officially a wizard, spells and all." He struck a playful, over-the-top pose, puffing out his chest and waving his hands dramatically.

Sara rolled her eyes, but couldn't suppress a chuckle. "Right, Merlin," she said, shaking her head. "I'll believe it when I see it. Anyway, here's your sandwich. Don't choke on your excitement." She set the plate in front of him with a playful thud. "Prepare to be amazed," he declared through a mouthful of ham and cheese, gesturing with the other half of his sandwich. "This System is ancient, by the way, and surprisingly well-organized. It even has safeguards for kids. It's like a whole world in there."

"Oh?" Sara leaned forward, her initial skepticism giving way to genuine intrigue. "Safeguards, you say? What kind?" Robert, now fully engaged in

explaining the intricacies of the System, continued, "Yeah, it restricts information based on age. Little kids, they only see their name, age, and race. Nothing else. More information gets unlocked as they get older, bit by bit, but they can't change their profile or learn skills until they're fifteen. It's like a built-in safety net."

"Fifteen seems young to be making those kinds of choices," Sara frowned, her brow furrowed in thought. "That's a lot of responsibility for a teenager." "Maybe," Robert conceded, "but I guess that's when they figure you're old enough to start taking responsibility for your own life, to start shaping your own destiny. It's like they're saying, 'Okay, kid, you've got the basics, now

show us what you can do.'"

"I guess so," Sara said, still looking thoughtful. Then, her expression shifted, becoming playful once more. "So, Mr. Wizard," she teased, "show me some magic. Harry Potter would be so proud of his competition." "No wand needed," Robert chuckled, a grin spreading across his face. He pulled up his spell sheet, looking it over he continued. "I've Got some offensive spells, some defensive ones, and even a few healing spells. It's like a whole arsenal at my fingertips."

"Healing, huh?" Sara's eyes lit up, and she pointed to a small, angry-looking cut on her leg. "My razor got me this morning. Work your magic, Merlin.

Let's see what you can do." Robert focused, concentrating on the words of the healing spell, a warmth spreading through his hand as he did. A soft, white light emanated from his palm as he touched her leg, the glow gentle yet powerful. It enveloped the cut, then faded, leaving behind smooth, unbroken skin.

There was no trace of the injury, as if it had never existed. "Wow," Sara breathed, running a finger over her leg in disbelief. "That's... incredible. It's like it was never even there." She playfully added, "And and that had better be the only leg you've touched in a while," Robert teased back, but the lighthearted moment quickly evaporated, replaced by a sudden, heavy silence.

"It's real, then," Sara said, her voice hushed, almost a whisper. "The System, the magic... all of it. It's not just some game or some story. It's actually

real." "Yeah," Robert replied, a knot forming in his stomach, the weight of their new reality settling upon him. "It's real. And it changes everything."

A heavy silence descended, the only sound the gentle hum of the

refrigerator in the corner. Sara broke the stillness, her voice laced with worry. "Six months, Robert. That's not a lot of time. What are we going to do? How are we going to prepare for something like this?" "We'll figure it out," he said, trying to sound more confident than he felt, reaching for her hand across the table. "Maybe I can use this healing thing, make some extra money on the side. Every little bit helps, right?"

Sara managed a weak smile. "Not sure there's a huge market for fixing shaving nicks," she said, attempting to lighten the mood, but her concern was evident. "This is just Tier 1," Robert pointed out, trying to find a silver lining. "Imagine what a Tier 4 healing spell could do. Maybe I could help people with real problems, serious injuries."

"Could you... could you bring people back from the dead?" Sara's eyes were wide with a mixture of hope and fear, the question hanging in the air between them. "I don't know," Robert admitted, a shiver running down his

spine at the thought. "And honestly, I'm not sure I want that kind of power. That's a heavy burden to bear."

"So, how are we going to tell the kids?" Sara asked, shifting the subject, her voice filled with a mother's concern. "Straight up," Robert decided, after a moment of contemplation. "We sit them down, all together, show them the proof. No point in sugarcoating it, pretending it's something it's not. They're smart kids, they deserve the truth." "You're right," Sara agreed, nodding slowly. "They need to know. It's their future, too."

She paused, her gaze drifting towards the window. "And when are you planning your first dungeon dive, your first foray into this new world?" "Two days," Robert answered, his mind already racing, planning, strategizing. "Gives me time to practice these spells, maybe learn a light

spell – dungeon delving in the dark doesn't sound fun or safe – and figure out what gear I need. I need to be prepared."

"Flashlights probably aren't practical," Sara mused, thinking aloud. "You'll need something more reliable, something that won't run out of batteries.

How long do you think you'll be gone on this first trip?" "Hard to say," Robert said, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. "But it's a beginner level, so hopefully just a few hours. I don't want to push my luck on the first try. I also want to check out the System shop. See what I can buy, what kind of gear they offer."

"Take notes," Sara suggested, her mind already working on the logistics. "That's probably where you'll get most of your equipment. Not like you can walk into a sporting goods store and buy a suit of armor these days." "Good point," Robert agreed. "And I'll get rewards and loot in the dungeon, they say. Thank goodness for that personal inventory space. Imagine having to carry everything around manually."

"Bring something back for the kids," Sara said, a spark of excitement momentarily flickering in her voice. "They'll be fascinated. They might not understand the danger, not fully, but loot and adventure? That they'll get.

They're kids, after all." "If I find a rat, I'll bring them a tail," Robert joked, trying to inject some levity into the increasingly serious conversation.

"Please, no," Sara said firmly, a mock shudder running through her. "I was thinking more along the lines of pictures and videos. Show them what it's like, if your phone works in there. Let them see this new world through

your eyes." "I'll try," Robert said, a faraway look in his eyes. "I didn't even think to ask if technology works in the dungeon. It's a whole different set of rules, isn't it?"

"Well, the whole thing's run by an AI, so I'm guessing tech is on the table," Sara pointed out. "It's all so high-tech, even if it's based on magic. Wonder what you can take with you when you leave, when you have to go to that

other world." "Probably nothing that really matters in the grand scheme of things," Sara said, her voice tinged with sadness, the reality of his eventual departure crashing down on her once more.

Robert reached out and took her hand, his fingers intertwining with hers. "Hey," he said softly, "I know this is scary. I don't want to go. I don't want

to leave you and the kids. But if I have to, I'm going to make the most of it. For you, for the kids, for our future. I'll become the strongest I can be."

"I know," Sara whispered, squeezing his hand, her eyes shining with unshed tears. "You always do. You always find a way." She glanced at the clock on the wall, a sudden urgency in her voice. "John will be home soon, then Richard and Stacey. Time to face the music, time to tell them everything."

"Yeah," Robert said, his stomach churning with a mixture of apprehension and determination. "Wonder how they'll take it, how they'll react to all of this." "John will be stoic, as always," Sara predicted with a sigh, a small, knowing smile on her face. "William will worry, he always does, our little worrier. And Stacey, well, Stacey will probably freak out. But we'll get through it. Together. We always do."

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 9‌

After wrapping things up at work, I headed back to my office, excited to get back to my spellbook. I figured I had some time before the kids got home, so I wanted to make sure I had a good mix of spells ready to go, ideally

some that I could level up soon.

I'd already nailed down spells from five of the magic schools, but I still needed to find something useful from Creation, Light, Enchantment, and Time. I started with Light and quickly found a pretty handy one: 'Floating Mage Light.' It's a basic spell, but it'll be super useful for lighting up the dungeon when we explore. Next, I checked out Time magic. There weren't a ton of options, but I did find 'A Gentle Tick of Time,' which can subtly slow things down a bit. Finally, I landed on 'Minor Mending' in the Creation school – it'll let me fix small tears and cracks in stuff. I was just about to start looking at Enchantment spells when John got home, so my research

time was cut short.

Sara came into the office, looking curious. "Should we fill John in now, or wait for everyone?" she asked. Robert considered this for a moment. "Let's give him a quick rundown," he suggested. "It'll be less of a shock, and we can use it as practice for when we tell everyone else." Sara agreed, "Sounds good. We'll give him the overview now and the deep dive later." A few minutes later, they heard the front door – John was home. He poked his head into the office, "Hey, what's going on?"

Sara smiled at him. "Hey sweetie, come on in. Your dad and I need to talk to you about something," she said. Immediately, John got defensive. "Okay, whatever it is, I swear I didn't do it," he said quickly. Sara laughed a little. "Don't worry, you're not in trouble. Actually, in this case, I'm the supposed one doing it. Or, I guess the one it's being done too," she clarified. John looked totally puzzled. "Wait, what's happening?" he asked.

Robert decided to take the lead. "You know how you're always playing those video games and watching those fantasy shows?" he started. John,

still confused, just replied, "Yeah... so?" Robert continued, "Well, that's actually going to make this a lot easier to explain. This morning, I had a

visitor." John raised his eyebrows. "What kind of visitor?" he asked. Robert took a deep breath. "The kind that gives out status screens, apparently," he said, trying to sound serious. John was utterly bewildered. "Status screens? What are you even talking about?" he asked. "I'm talking about these kinds of status screens," Robert said, and with that, he pulled up his own status screen for John to see.


Name: Robert Williams

Class(1):

None

Merged Class: None

Race: Human (Tier G)

Class(2):

None

Merged Profession: None

Gender: Male

Level: 4
