Charisma: 10

Resistances: (EL: 0, MI: 0, TI:0,

SP: 0, HI: 0, SR: 0, PH: 0

Status Effect: None

Free Stat Points: 0


John's jaw dropped, staring at the screen. "Whoa, what the hell is that thing? And how are you already Level 4?" he asked, completely baffled. Robert chuckled slightly. "Okay, first off, watch your mouth. Second, I knocked out a couple of simple 'quests,' apparently." Robert then showed him a message

from the System Log, pointing out the six-month deadline. John's face went white, and he practically leaped out of his chair.

"Wait, hold on – you're leaving? In six months? And never coming back?!" he exclaimed, his voice rising. "Whoa, calm down, son," Robert said, trying to keep his voice level. "Yes, I am leaving. I know it sucks, and believe me, I wish it were different, but I can't change it. This... being, whatever it was, that gave me this whole 'opportunity' didn't exactly give me a choice."

"That's bull!" John yelled, his voice filled with a mix of anger and fear.

"There has to be a way to stop it!" Robert shook his head sadly. "We can't, son," he repeated. "We've already looked into it. The System, or whatever you want to call this thing, has already put a lot into this, into me, and it's not backing down." John's voice was desperate now. "But what about us? Couldn't the System just take all of us?" he asked. "We asked about that, too," Robert said, shaking his head again. "It seems like only people directly connected to the System can go, and it's not willing to take on more people right now. Besides, I wouldn't, I would never, ask you or your siblings, or your mom, to just drop everything for me, your lives."

John slammed his fist down on the table in frustration. "It's not about dropping everything, Dad! It's about staying together, as a family!" Robert sighed, feeling the weight of the situation. "What about your grandparents? Your cousins? All your friends here? What about college? You've always dreamed of working at SpaceX," he reminded him. John slumped back down, defeated.

"It's not fair," he mumbled, his voice thick with emotion. "You're supposed to be there to see the first launch of a rocket I designed." Robert's voice was soft. "I know, son. I know, and I'm so sorry. But I can still help you, and maybe, just maybe, I can still be a part of your future, even if I'm not there in person." John was interested.

"How? What do you mean?" John asked, a flicker of curiosity in his eyes. "Skills, son. It's all about the skills," Robert replied, bringing up his skill list. "Take a look at this." John's eyes scanned the list, widening again. "Whoa, seriously? You can actually do magic? That's so not fair!" he exclaimed, a touch of playful jealousy creeping into his voice. Robert

smiled. "Well, here's the thing: I can unlock even more skills, and I can unlock them at Tier 4, which is way beyond normal human ability." John, still processing, asked, "Okay, but what does that actually mean?

How do these skills even work?" "Basically," Robert explained, "skills give you the knowledge and ability to do things. Like, I have Leatherworking

now. When I got that skill, I suddenly knew the basics of working with

leather. I didn't know how to make, like, a specific fancy wallet until I used a skill book, but I understood the fundamentals."

"So," John said, putting the pieces together, "if you unlocked Blacksmithing, you wouldn't automatically know how to forge a specific Japanese katana, but you'd understand the general process of making

swords?" "Exactly," Robert confirmed. "And I also have this Teaching skill.

It's pretty basic right now, but if I can get it to Tier 3, I can pass on the knowledge of a skill to someone else, up to Tier 1 Level 10."

I should interject here and let you know that while you can teach a non-system user, you cannot go above Tier 1 Level 3 with them. Also, you can not teach them more than 1 skill every few weeks, without a core their mind needs a lot of time to recover.

"Hal said that as a non-system user, I can only teach you skills up to Tier 1 Level 3, and I can only teach you 1 skill every few weeks to allow your mind to recover for the download, or whatever it is," Robert said. "So, what were you thinking of teaching me?" John asked, curious. "This," Robert said, pulling up a sorted list of available skills.


Skill Name

Skill Tier

Tier Level

Skill Description

Space Craft Design

4

5

A comprehensive skill encompassing the design and engineering of spacecraft for space travel.

Space Craft - Electrical Systems Design

4

5

A specialized subskill focused on the creation and design of the electrical




systems essential for spacecraft operation.

Space Craft - Non- FTL Propulsion Systems Design and Engineering


4


5

A specialized subskill dedicated to the development and design of propulsion systems capable of propelling spacecraft at sub-FTL speeds.

General - Power Production Design

4

5

A general skill covering the design and engineering of power systems.

Advanced Anti-Matter Energy Engineering and Design


4


5

A specialized subskill focused on the creation, containment, and utilization of anti-matter energy for power generation.

"So you just learned those?" John asked, his eyes wide with surprise. "Yep," Robert replied with a grin. "Spent five of my six unlocked skill points. But once I upgrade my Teaching skill, I'll be able to impart that knowledge to you. Even at Tier 1.3, you'll be one of the smartest people on the planet when it comes to those subjects."

"Wait, you spent five of your six points on skills that probably won't help you when you leave? Don't do that again! I can manage. You might need those points!" John exclaimed, a hint of panic in his voice. "I gain a point

every few levels," Robert reassured him. "Plus, I think I can get more from feats, traits, and titles. So, I have a feeling I'll end up with more points than I can use. I'd rather invest some now to help you out. It's not a waste."

"So, I have one normal skill point and one unlocked skill point left," Robert explained. "A normal point lets me unlock a skill I've earned or increase an existing skill by one level. An unlocked point, on the other hand, lets me unlock any skill, even if it's normally out of my reach, or boost an existing skill by five levels. To get Teaching to Tier 3, I need 16 more levels, which means either three more unlocked points or two unlocked and five normal points. I'll figure it out." "Once I do, you can start learning," Robert continued. "As for the other kids, I'll need to see what they're interested in."

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 10‌

The late afternoon sun cast long shadows across the living room as Sara anxiously paced, her gaze repeatedly drawn to the hallway leading to Robert's study. The muted sounds of conversation, a low rumble of male voices, drifted out, but she couldn't decipher the words. John, ever the stoic one, had engaged Robert in a brief, intense discussion before retreating, leaving a palpable tension in his wake. Seven minutes – an eternity in Sara's worried mind – crawled by before the sound of the front door opening heralded Richard's arrival. She forced a bright smile, a mask to hide the turmoil within, and greeted him with an uncharacteristically effusive hug.

"Welcome home, darling!" she exclaimed, her voice a little too high- pitched. Richard, ever observant, immediately sensed something was amiss. "Mom? What's with the sudden burst of affection?" he asked, a playful tone barely masking his underlying concern. "Are you alright? You seem...

different." The forced cheerfulness crumbled, and Sara could only manage a weak, "Let's talk in your father's office. It's... a long story."

Inside Robert's study, the atmosphere was heavy with unspoken anxieties. Robert and John, interrupted mid-conversation, turned to greet them.

Robert's face was a roadmap of weariness, a forced calm barely concealing the underlying stress. "Hey, Dad. Mom's acting really strange. What's going on?" Richard's question cut straight to the point, his gaze darting between his parents, searching for answers. Robert sighed, the weight of the day pressing down on him.

"We had some... unsettling news today, son. It's understandably upset your mother." "What kind of news?" Richard pressed, his voice tight with apprehension. He was preparing himself for the worst, the unspoken fear of loss hanging heavy in the air. John, usually so articulate, simply added, "It's... complicated." Robert gestured for Richard to sit, the formality of the gesture amplifying the seriousness of the situation. "Sit down, son. This is going to be hard to hear. But first, let me reassure you: no one has died, and Nana is fine. However... in six months, I'm leaving. And I won't be returning."

Richard stared at his father, his expression a whirlwind of confusion and disbelief. "What... what are you talking about? Not coming back? Are you... are you going to die?" The raw, vulnerable question hung in the silence, a testament to the depth of his fear. "No, no, absolutely not," Robert reassured him quickly, his voice firm despite the tremor in his hands. "I'm being... forced to leave. Compelled." "Forced? By who?" Richard's voice rose in pitch, disbelief giving way to anger. Robert, with a heavy heart, activated

the System interface, displaying the stark, uncompromising message that had shattered their world.

"This isn't a joke, Richard. This is real. And I have no say in the matter." Richard stared at the glowing text, the reality of the situation slowly crushing him. "That's... that's just wrong!" he exclaimed, his voice breaking with emotion. "Can... can we at least go with you?" The desperate plea was met with a heartbreaking shake of Robert's head. "I wish we could, son.

More than anything. But it's impossible. All I can do is try to prepare you all for a future without me."

"Prepare us? How can you possibly prepare us for this?" Richard's voice was laced with frustration and a growing sense of helplessness. "This System, this... thing... it doesn't care about our feelings! It's just tearing you away from us!" Robert acknowledged his son's pain, his voice calm but resolute. "I know it's unfair, Richard. But we have to adapt. We have to be strong. I intend to use the time I have left to teach you, your sister, and even John valuable skills – skills that will help you thrive. John will become a leading expert in rocket engineering. I'll do the same for you and Stacey, focusing on your individual aspirations."

Richard was taken a back. "I.. I don't even know how that is possible." Robert began to explain. "I have a skill called teaching, with time I can increase the level, once it is high enough I can just give you skills. With

John, I have focused on making him a great rocket engineer. I can do the

same with you." Richard was confused, "I want to go into law enforcement, what skills can you give me?"

Robert paused, taking time to think. "While that is different from John,

there are many skills I can give to you that would put you above your peers. As an example, I could make you a world-class medic or I could give you

all the training and skills that the best Swat team member would have, and more." Robert stated. "And what about Stacey? She's determined to be a veterinarian,"

Richard interjected, his concern shifting momentarily to his younger sister. "I can give her a significant advantage in her studies," Robert replied. "I can provide her with the foundational knowledge and skills she'll need to excel in veterinary medicine, putting her years ahead of her peers." Richard sat quietly, processing the information, his anger slowly giving way to a grudging acceptance. "Okay," he finally said, his voice subdued. "I... I understand what you're trying to do. But I'm still angry. And what about you, Dad? How are you preparing for... whatever this is?"

"I understand your anger, Richard," Robert said, his voice filled with empathy. "And I share it. But we have to make the best of this. To prepare myself, I'll be training in a System-generated dungeon – a simulated environment designed to test and enhance my abilities. I'm also studying this," he said, gesturing towards the ancient-looking grimoire on his desk, "a spellbook, to learn magic." Richard's eyes widened in astonishment.

"Magic? You can actually learn magic?" He paused, then added, "You said 'learn more,' meaning you already know some?" "I spent the morning learning a few basic spells," Robert confirmed. "This book contains all the Tier 1 spells I currently have access to." He carefully handed the weighty tome to Richard. Richard took the book, his fingers tracing the strange symbols and intricate diagrams. A spark of curiosity ignited within him. "Can... can I learn these?" he asked, hope flickering in his eyes.

Not yet, unfortunately. Casting spells requires mana, a form of energy that doesn't exist naturally in our world, at least not in a usable form. You, through your connection to the

system do have access to Mana.

Robert nodded no, "I'm afraid not, knowing the spells will not help with access to Mana, which doesn't exist in this universe yet." Richard's face fell slightly. "So, it's not just about knowing the spells," he said, thinking aloud, "it's about having the... the power source to make them work." He paused, then his eyes lit up. "Wait... if this whole thing is like a game, what about a

Mana Stone? Wouldn't that provide a temporary source of mana?" Robert considered this, stroking his chin thoughtfully. "That's... a surprisingly insightful idea. Let me inquire." Robert closed his eyes for a moment, focusing his thoughts. "Hal, is that a viable option?"

It is theoretically possible. You would need to imbue him with the skill to draw mana from the stone. However, he would have no means of replenishing the stone's energy, making it a limited resource.

Robert relayed the information to Richard. "It is possible to create a mana stone for you, but recharging it would be a major problem, perhaps impossible. It might be useful for specific, crucial spells, like emergency

healing or protection, but it would be a very limited option." "So, depending on the stone's capacity and the spell's cost, we might get a few uses, maybe more," Richard mused. "I think it would be worth it, just for emergencies.

Having a way to heal someone instantly, even a few times, could make all the difference."

"I'll look into creating a mana stone," Robert promised. "But it will take time. My priority is still the Teaching skill. And honestly, I have no idea how to craft magical artifacts." He glanced at the clock. "Stacey will be home soon. Let's hold off on further discussion until we can all talk

together. We'll have a family meeting tonight to explain everything in detail."

As Richard and John left the study, Robert turned to Sara, a mixture of exhaustion and grim determination etched on his face. "That went... better than I anticipated," he admitted. Sara sighed, a shaky breath escaping her lips. "True, but Richard is the logical one. Stacey... she's far more emotional. She adores you, Robert. This news... I fear we're in for a very difficult night." A heavy silence descended, the ticking of the clock a constant reminder of the dwindling time. In the other room, the brothers grappled with their new reality. "So... is this really happening?" Richard

asked, his voice hushed. "As far as I can tell, yes," John replied. "I saw him cast a spell. And that book... it appeared out of nowhere. I think it's real."

"I know," Richard said, running a hand through his hair. "There could be

other explanations, but... I don't think so. I think it's real. And if it is... what do we do?" John shook his head, his expression bleak. "I don't know. All we can do is be strong. For Mom, and especially for Stacey. She looks up to Dad so much. This is going to devastate her." Richard nodded, his jaw tight. "Yeah. I don't even want to be there when he tells her. She's not going to

handle this well. Not at all." The weight of their shared uncertainty pressed down on them, a heavy burden in a world suddenly turned upside down.

They were adrift, facing an unimaginable future, clinging to each other for support.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 11‌

The click of the front door latch, followed by the thud of it closing, echoed through the house, pulling Richard and John from their intense, hushed conversation. Stacey, their younger sister, burst into the living room a moment later, a whirlwind of youthful energy, her face alight with the

carefree excitement that only a teenager could possess after a day at school.

"I'm home!" she announced, her voice bright and cheerful, completely oblivious to the heavy atmosphere that had settled over the room just moments before. Her backpack swung from one hand before she unceremoniously dropped it onto the couch with a loud thump, adding to

the growing pile of their belongings that seemed to be accumulating in the living room.

"Hey, Stace," Richard greeted her, forcing a smile and trying to mask the growing anxiety that had been churning in his gut all afternoon. He tried to sound casual, normal. "How was school?" "It was fine," she replied, her typically short attention span already shifting, her gaze landing on the worn, leather-bound spellbook in Richard's hands.

Its unusual appearance, so different from anything she'd seen before, immediately piqued her curiosity. "What's that?" she asked, tilting her head. "Is it a new comic book? Can I see?" Richard hesitated, his mind scrambling for a way to explain the inexplicable, to somehow make the fantastical reality of the System and his father's impending departure

comprehensible to his little sister.

"Uh, kind of," he stammered, the words feeling clumsy and inadequate. "It's... it's a book about magic." Stacey's eyes widened, not with the playful skepticism she usually displayed towards her older brothers' pronouncements, but with genuine, wide-eyed disbelief. "Magic?" she repeated, her voice a mixture of awe and confusion. "Like, real magic? Like in Harry Potter, or on TV?"

Before Richard could fumble through a response, Robert and Sara entered the living room, drawn by Stacey's arrival and the escalating conversation. Robert's presence usually filled the room with a sense of warmth and security, but today, his voice, usually so comforting and jovial, carried a

somber tone that immediately silenced the room.

"Everyone, gather around," he announced, his gaze sweeping over his three children. "Stacey, your brothers already know, but something is about to happen, something that will change all of our lives, forever." Fear flickered in Stacey's eyes, her youthful exuberance replaced by a sudden, chilling premonition. The playful banter and teasing questions about magic were instantly forgotten.

"Did we get a transfer?" she asked, her voice trembling slightly, the question revealing her immediate, childlike fear of being uprooted from her familiar life. "Are we moving? I don't want to leave my friends! I like it here." Robert gently placed a hand on her shoulder, his touch a reassuring

anchor in the storm of her rising panic.

"Calm down, sweetheart," he said, his voice soft but firm. "You're not moving. You're staying right here. I'm the one who's going away." Confusion clouded Stacey's face, her fear now mixed with bewilderment. "What do you mean, you're moving?" she asked, her brow furrowed.

"Where are you going?"

"Wait," a new, even more horrifying thought struck her, and her voice rose in pitch, "are you and Mom getting a divorce? You can't do that! We're a family. You can't just leave!" Robert shook his head, his heart aching at the distress in his daughter's voice. "No, no, nothing like that," he reassured her quickly. "Your mother and I aren't getting a divorce. We're not splitting up. I'm being... sent on an adventure, a journey. It's complicated."

With a heavy heart, Robert opened the system log, the glowing blue

interface illuminating the dimly lit room, and showed it to Stacey. Her eyes scanned the screen, the strange symbols and statistics swimming before her, and a mixture of fear and disbelief washed over her face. The reality of the situation, the sheer impossibility of it, began to sink in.

"Wait," she whispered, her voice trembling, "what is this? Is this... is this

real? Some kind of joke?" "I'm afraid its real princess," Robert replied, his voice filled with a deep, profound regret, each word a heavy weight. "And no, I can't get out of it. I wish I could. And no, no one can go with me. It's just me."

Stacey, unable to comprehend or accept this sudden, devastating upheaval of her world, ran to her father, wrapping her arms around him tightly in a desperate embrace. "But Dad, that's not fair!" she cried, her voice muffled against his chest. "You can't leave. You can't just go away! We need you!"

Robert pulled her close, holding her tight, his own emotions threatening to overwhelm him. "I know it's not fair, sweetheart," he said, his voice gentle but firm, "and I wish things were different. I wish I could stay. But I have to do this. There's no other choice. All I can do is get ready and make sure you all are taken care of, that you're safe and have everything you need."

He stroked her hair, trying to offer some comfort amidst the storm of emotions. "I know it's hard to understand," Robert continued, his voice thick with emotion, "and it's okay to be scared and angry. But I'll do everything I can to prepare you all for the future. You'll have everything you need to be happy and successful, even if I'm not here."

Stacey's tears continued to flow, hot and silent against her father's shirt. "But I don't want anything without you, Dad," she sobbed, her small body shaking. "You're the best dad in the world. I don't want you to go." A heavy silence fell over the room, the weight of the situation pressing down on them all, broken only by Stacey's quiet sobs.

Finally, she pulled back, her face red and tear-streaked, and asked in a small, broken voice, "So, what happens now? What will you do? Where are you going?" Robert took a deep breath, trying to compose himself, to be strong for his family. "I'll get ready," he explained, his voice regaining some of its steadiness.

"The system, this... this thing that's sending me away, it will train me for the next six months. And I'll use that time to help you all too. As I learn new things, I'll teach you. I have a plan, and it will set you all up for a bright

future, a good life." He then outlined his plan, explaining how he intended to use his teaching skill, a unique ability granted by the System, to impart

the knowledge they would need to succeed in their chosen careers, to ensure their financial security and well-being in his absence.

Everyone listened intently, absorbing his words, and slowly, grudgingly, agreed that it was the best, perhaps the only, course of action under these extraordinary circumstances. Then, Robert turned to a more pressing matter: the need for absolute secrecy. "This isn't something you can share with your friends," he emphasized, his gaze sweeping over each of his children, his expression deadly serious.

"For starters, they probably wouldn't believe you. It sounds crazy, I know.

And if word got out, if the wrong people found out about this, I'm pretty

sure men in black suits would show up to have a chat, and it wouldn't be a friendly one." He paused, letting his words sink in, his gaze unwavering. "Do we all agree to keep this a secret within the family? No exceptions?"

Sara nodded, her face pale but resolute. "I think we can all agree that telling the Men in Black would be a bad idea," she said, attempting a weak smile, trying to inject a sliver of levity into the tense situation. John raised a hand, his expression thoughtful. "Yeah, this isn't something anyone needs to

know," he agreed. "But what will we tell people when they ask where you went? People will notice you're gone, Dad."

Robert pondered the question, stroking his chin thoughtfully. "That's a good point," he admitted. "We'll need to come up with a cover story, something believable. We can't just say I disappeared. Actually," he continued, a new

idea taking shape in his mind, "Richard gave me an interesting idea a while ago. While no one will be able to cast spells in this universe for a long time, we can prepare our future family, generations down the line."

Sara looked puzzled, tilting her head in confusion. "What are you getting

at? How can we prepare future generations for something that won't happen for years?" "Well," Robert explained, a glimmer of excitement in his eyes, "we can start by copying the spellbook. It contains every Tier 1 spell for various spheres of magic. It's a wealth of knowledge, and I doubt anyone

else in this universe will have access to such extensive, detailed magical information."

"I'll also be returning eventually, so I can guide our family and help them become leaders in this new reality, when magic finally does become commonplace." Richard's eyes lit up, his mind racing, grasping the implications of his father's words. "Wait," he said, his voice rising with excitement, "you can create mana stones, right? Those things that power spells? And you can enchant items too, make them magical?"

Robert nodded, confirming his son's deductions. "Yes, I have those skills.

They're part of the System." "So," Richard continued, his voice filled with a growing sense of wonder, "we could create powerful magic items, things that could protect our family and ensure our future for generations to come. Even healing items, right? Things that could heal any injury?"

"Probably," Robert replied, a thoughtful expression on his face. "I still need to experiment with those skills, see what their limitations are. But in theory, yes. Where are you going with this, Richard?" Richard grinned, a spark of his usual mischievousness returning to his eyes. "What if we created items that could heal anything?" he proposed, his voice brimming with excitement.

"We're worried about the Men in Black, about the government finding out, but maybe we could work with them. We could explain the situation, offer them some of these items in exchange for protection, and to ensure they

leave us alone, that they don't try to take Dad or exploit the System." Robert pondered the idea, turning it over in his mind, weighing the potential risks and rewards.

"That might work," he conceded, a thoughtful frown creasing his brow. "However, I think it's best to wait until I level up a few more times and

unlock my class. I have a feeling I'll be too powerful for them to mess with eventually, once I've had time to train. But your idea could be a good way to generate income for the family in the meantime. I wonder how much the Secret Service would pay for a healing item for the President, something that could heal him from any injury, no matter how severe."

John grinned, catching on to the possibilities. "Or items to protect the President from almost anything," he added, his voice filled with excitement. "Good work, little brother. You came up with a great idea, as usual." Richard smirked, puffing out his chest slightly. "I usually do," he said, a hint of his usual arrogance returning. Stacey's eyes widened, her earlier fear momentarily forgotten as she considered the implications.

"Do you think they'd actually pay money for those kinds of items?" she asked, her voice filled with awe. "Real money?" John chuckled, the sound a welcome break in the tension that had filled the room. "I'm thinking they'd pay a lot," he said, a confident grin spreading across his face.

"Okay," Robert stated, his voice regaining its authoritative tone, the gears in his mind already turning, formulating a plan. "So, once I reach level 20 and figure out my capabilities, we'll figure out how to approach the government, if we even need to. We'll see what they know. For now, I have a few days

before my first dungeon run. I'll continue studying the spellbook and gathering supplies, getting everything in order."

"I'm going back to my office," Robert announced, rising to his feet, the weight of responsibility heavy on his shoulders. "You kids should head to your rooms and think about all of this. Process it in your own way. We'll

talk more at dinner. And Richard," he added, holding out his hand, "give me that book back. I need to study."

Richard reluctantly handed over the spellbook, a pout marring his face, his earlier excitement momentarily dimmed by the prospect of being separated from the source of such fascinating knowledge. He knew, however, that his dad needed it more.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 12‌

The pronouncement landed like a physical weight, a palpable pressure that seemed to steal the very air from their lungs. The news, delivered with such unexpected gravity, hung in the silence, a suffocating presence that enveloped the entire household. Each member of the family, in their own distinct way, retreated into the solitary confines of their thoughts, seeking

refuge from the storm that had suddenly erupted within their previously tranquil lives.

Their minds, once occupied with the mundane concerns of everyday existence, now raced uncontrollably, grappling with the enormity of the change, the daunting uncertainty of a future that had been irrevocably altered. The familiar tapestry of their lives had been unraveled, leaving them adrift in a sea of anxieties, hopes, and fears.

Richard, with his innate predilection for strategic thinking, his mind a complex and intricate network of possibilities, immediately began to construct elaborate plans, weaving intricate webs of contingencies, his thoughts a whirlwind of potential challenges and meticulously crafted solutions. He paced his room, a restless energy consuming him, his lips moving silently as he formulated and discarded countless scenarios.

John, ever the pragmatist, his feet firmly planted on the ground of reality, focused his attention on the immediate, tangible consequences of the impending changes. He meticulously assessed the logistical hurdles, the practical adjustments that would be required to navigate this new and

unfamiliar terrain. His mind, a precisely calibrated instrument, worked methodically, calculating resources, prioritizing tasks, and anticipating needs.

He envisioned the coming months as a series of interconnected challenges, each requiring a specific and carefully considered response. Lists began to form in his head, mental inventories of supplies, skills, and potential obstacles. He saw himself as the family's quartermaster, responsible for ensuring their survival and well-being in this new, uncharted territory.

Stacey, the youngest, still teetering on the cusp of adolescence, sought solace in the familiar comfort of her bedroom, her heart aching with a

premature sense of loss, a grief for the innocence that had been so abruptly snatched away.

The world, once a safe and predictable haven, now loomed large and menacing, filled with shadows and uncertainties. The sudden intrusion of adult concerns, the shattering of her carefree existence, weighed heavily upon her young shoulders, a burden she was not yet equipped to bear. She curled up on her bed, clutching a worn teddy bear, her eyes wide with a mixture of fear, confusion, and a deep, unsettling sadness.

As the day bled into evening, a peculiar and almost palpable atmosphere of anticipation settled over the house, a strange and contradictory blend of emotions. It was a potent cocktail, a mixture of the intoxicating allure of a grand, albeit perilous, adventure, the chilling apprehension of confronting unknown dangers lurking in the shadows, and the tantalizing glimmer of potentially extraordinary rewards that lay just beyond the horizon.

This volatile combination of fear and excitement both invigorated and unnerved them, creating a sense of heightened awareness, a feeling that they were teetering on the precipice of something monumental, something that would forever alter the course of their lives. They were bound together by this shared experience, this collective plunge into the unknown.

Following a dinner characterized by strained silences and forced attempts at normalcy, Robert, the steadfast patriarch of the family, his face etched with a newfound gravity and determination, gathered his loved ones in the living room, the familiar heart of their home. He announced, his voice resonating with the weight of his responsibility and the profound implications of his words, the urgent need for a frank and open discussion about their future, a future that had been irrevocably transformed.

He outlined a meticulously crafted plan, a strategy developed in close collaboration with his advanced AI companion, Hal, a plan that revolved around the acquisition of skills and the creation and strategic utilization of enchanted, magical items.

These artifacts, he explained with unwavering conviction, would be their lifeline, their source of both protection and prosperity in this new and

unpredictable reality. He spoke of a world beyond their comprehension, a world of dungeons and magic, a world where ones very survival would depend on their adaptability, their courage, and their willingness to embrace the extraordinary.

Robert patiently and thoroughly addressed John's inherently pragmatic questions regarding the practicalities of replenishing the magical energy within these artifacts. He introduced the concept of mana stones, explaining that they were essentially self-contained reservoirs of potent magical

energy, capable of recharging the enchanted items, acting as conduits for the very essence of magic.

He meticulously detailed the strategic prioritization of crafting both defensive and healing items, unveiling the existence of a remarkably powerful Tier 4 healing artifact, a legendary object capable of feats previously relegated to the realm of myth and fantasy, including the miraculous regeneration of lost limbs.

He emphasized, however, that such extraordinary power inevitably attracted unwanted attention, drawing those who would seek to exploit it for their own nefarious purposes. Therefore, he stressed the paramount importance

of also creating robust defensive items, shields against the dangers that lurked in this new world. He also spoke about self defense training, and teaching Sara more medical knowledge.

The conversation then shifted to the crucial and unavoidable topic of their financial stability. Robert, with characteristic forthrightness, acknowledged the necessity of resigning from his current employment, explaining that his time and energy would be entirely consumed by the demands of this new reality. He reassured them, however, that their immediate financial needs were relatively modest and could be readily met through the acquisition of silver and gold coins within the dungeons, the very environments that held both peril and promise.

He further explained that these coins could be easily exchanged for conventional currency, providing a sustainable income until they could

establish a more formal and lucrative arrangement with the government. He expressed unwavering confidence that the government, recognizing the

unique value of their skills and the artifacts they would acquire, would be more than willing to compensate them handsomely for their services and the invaluable intelligence they would gather.

The following morning, the house was enveloped in an almost palpable silence, a stark and jarring contrast to the usual vibrant symphony of morning activity. The children, normally brimming with youthful energy and boisterous enthusiasm, were visibly subdued, their faces reflecting a complex mixture of apprehension, confusion, and a nascent fear of the unknown. The weight of their new reality had settled upon them, a tangible burden that stifled their usual exuberance.

Richard, his voice barely above a whisper, questioned the absolute certainty of this radical departure from their previous lives, while John, ever practical, focused on the immediate logistical details, even questioning the necessity of attending school.

Robert, however, remained steadfast in his conviction that maintaining their daily routines, as much as was feasible, was of paramount importance. He believed that this semblance of normalcy, however fragile, would serve as an anchor, grounding them amidst the turbulent sea of change that threatened to engulf them, before turning to Hal to gain more personal insight into the challenges ahead.

One crucial aspect to understand about the System, is its unwavering nature. It is strict, uncompromising, and at times, brutally frank, but ultimately, it operates on a principle of fairness.

The first floor of the Dungeon will present a relatively low level of challenge. You can anticipate encountering creatures such as rats, slimes, or perhaps other small,

relatively harmless fauna. The duration of your exploration there should be brief, likely encompassing only three or four chambers – a concise introductory experience designed to acclimate you to the realities of the Dungeon.

Robert considered this, a slight furrow in his brow. "So, my current capabilities should be more than adequate? While acquiring a few additional spells might be beneficial, my existing proficiency with basic weaponry and my current spell repertoire should suffice for this initial foray."

Indeed, in all honesty, you possess sufficient strength to defeat any entity on the first floor with a strategically placed kick. However, I believe the true significance of the first floor lies not in the combat experience, but rather in the access it grants to the System's shop. This will provide you with a valuable opportunity to thoroughly assess your immediate and future needs, allowing you to formulate a comprehensive plan for your progression.

Robert's interest piqued. "Will the shop's inventory be subject to change? Will items appear and disappear randomly?"

The inventory will evolve, but it will expand rather than contract. While certain items might be unique and available only for a limited time, the majority will remain consistently stocked unless purchased. This feature is designed to facilitate long-term strategic planning, allowing you to save resources for desired acquisitions without the fear of them vanishing unexpectedly.

Robert nodded slowly, absorbing this information. "That's reassuring. So, if I encounter, say, a Tier 2 Spell Book, I can confidently save up the necessary currency, knowing it will remain available until I'm able to

purchase it?"

Precisely

"Alright," Robert said, a sense of resolve solidifying within him. "In that case, I'll conserve my skill points for the time being. Is there an expedited method for acquiring more?"

You can accrue skill points through leveling up, achieving specific titles, and completing designated feats. However, I am currently restricted from providing detailed guidance on the specific requirements for obtaining these accolades.

Robert sighed, a hint of frustration in his voice. "Back to the grind, it seems." With that, he opened his well-worn spellbook, its pages filled with arcane knowledge, and immersed himself in study.

Several hours later, Sara's gentle voice broke through his concentration. "Lunchtime," she announced, entering his office with a warm smile. He looked up, momentarily disoriented, the transition from the arcane world of his spellbook to the mundane reality of his home a jarring one. "I could certainly eat," he admitted, realizing he had been lost in his studies. "Reading, it appears, is a surprisingly energy-intensive activity." He followed Sara to the dining room, the familiar scent of home-cooked food a welcome comfort.

As he took his seat at the table, Sara placed a freshly made sandwich before him. "So," she began, her voice laced with a mixture of apprehension and forced cheerfulness, "a new day dawns, and yet, everything appears deceptively… normal. This is all truly happening, isn't it, Robert?"

"Yes, my love, it is," Robert replied, his tone somber, reflecting the weight of their new reality. He reached across the table, gently taking her hand. "I don't know what I'm going to do without you by my side." Sara squeezed his hand, offering a reassuring smile. "You'll be fine, Robert. You are, without a doubt, the strongest and most capable person I know. Now, tell me, when is your inaugural… expedition planned?" "Tomorrow, I believe,"

Robert answered. "Hal assures me that the first floor presents minimal danger, so insignificant, in fact, that I could theoretically 'kick' my way through it."

Sara's expression, however, remained serious, her brow furrowed with concern. "Don't underestimate it, Robert," she cautioned.

"Approach it as if it were exceedingly dangerous, even if it isn't.

Overconfidence can be a fatal flaw." Robert nodded, acknowledging the

wisdom in her words. "You're absolutely right," he conceded. "I apologize. My intention was to reassure you, but I see now that it was misguided." "Just return to me safely, Robert," Sara said softly, her eyes filled with a

mixture of love and fear. "That's all that matters."

After lunch, Robert returned to the solitude of his office, resuming his intense study of the spellbook. The demands of his day job, however,

intruded, forcing him to pause several times to answer urgent work calls and participate in virtual meetings. He also managed to submit a formal request for a leave of absence for the following day, a precursor to his eventual resignation. Later that afternoon, as the children returned home from school, he reluctantly concluded his work for the day and rejoined his family.

"After tomorrow," he explained, "I'll have a much clearer understanding of the overall situation, the potential rewards, and my earning capacity. Once I have that information, I'll be able to submit my formal notice. I feel a profound sense of guilt about this, as I won't be able to provide the customary two-week notice. My focus must, unfortunately, shift entirely to training and preparation, leaving no time for my office responsibilities."

John, ever the pragmatist, offered a wry, forced laugh. "Well, on the bright side, Father, you won't be needing them as a reference for future employment." Robert managed a weak smile. "That's a valid point, though

the guilt persists. The fortunate aspect is that my team is exceptionally well- trained and capable of functioning effectively without my direct supervision for the period it will take to find a suitable replacement. Nevertheless, I can't shake this feeling of letting them down."

Sara interjected, her voice firm but supportive. "I understand your sentiments, Robert, but you must prioritize your own safety and well-being at this juncture. You mentioned that the initial stages of the Dungeon are relatively easy, but how long will that remain the case?"

"I anticipate that the lower levels, perhaps the first few floors, will be manageable, possibly for a week or so," Robert replied. "After that, I will undoubtedly need to dedicate significant effort to enhancing my skills and acquiring more potent spells." "Then there you have it," Sara stated

decisively. "Your company will endure a few extra meetings for your

supervisor. You, on the other hand, cannot afford to make any mistakes. Express your sincere apologies, but explain that you have no other option." "I know you're right," Robert conceded, his voice heavy with resignation. "It's a difficult decision, but it's the only one I can make.

Following that, my focus will shift entirely to intensive training and the acquisition of more powerful spells. I'm hoping to locate, or perhaps purchase, a Tier 2 spellbook soon to significantly augment my magical capabilities. I'm also optimistic that the System will offer skill books related to enchanting, to provide me with a solid foundation in that crucial area.

The introductory book I received covered the fundamental principles, but it lacked a substantial collection of practical blueprints."

"What time are you planning to depart tomorrow, Father?" Richard inquired, his voice filled with a mixture of anxiety and morbid curiosity. "Likely immediately after you all leave for school," Robert replied. "I

anticipate returning well before you do."

Stacey's voice, small and filled with trepidation, broke the momentary silence. "I'm sorry, Dad, but we won't be attending school tomorrow. We won't be able to concentrate on our studies while you're undertaking your first… run." Robert looked at his daughter, his heart aching for her fear. "I understand your concern, Stacey," he said gently. "You may stay home from school tomorrow, but that's the only exception. Now, all of you, please focus on your homework. I'll see you at dinner."

After dinner the family all spen some time together, before they all went to bed. Tomorrow was going to be a big day.


OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 13‌

The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and sizzling bacon filled the air as Robert entered the kitchen, finding his family already gathered around the breakfast table. A mixture of apprehension and forced cheerfulness hung in the atmosphere, a fragile attempt to maintain normalcy in the face of the extraordinary. He offered them a reassuring smile, though he knew it couldn't fully mask the weight of the impending task. "Morning, everyone," he said, taking his seat. "So, Hal," he addressed the unseen System AI, "when exactly do we get this show on the road?"

Whenever you deem yourself prepared, Robert. However, do bear in mind that you are required to complete two dungeon runs within this week. Procrastination is not advisable.

Robert nodded, relaying the information to his family. "Sounds like we shouldn't put this off any longer. I think I'll get changed, gather my gear, and head out right after we finish breakfast," he announced.

Stacey, her eyes wide with worry, immediately piped up, "Be careful, Daddy, please." Her voice was small, laced with a vulnerability that tugged at Robert's heart. "I will be, sweetheart, I promise," he reassured her, forcing a confident tone. "Honestly, I'm not overly concerned about this initial run. It's supposed to be relatively low-risk, a chance to get my bearings." He tried to project an air of calm assurance, though a knot of anxiety tightened in his stomach.

After they had finished eating, Robert retreated to his bedroom, the familiar space now feeling strangely alien, a relic of a life that was rapidly changing. He exchanged his comfortable morning attire for sturdy denim jeans and a heavy, long-sleeved shirt, practical clothing suitable for rough terrain. He laced up his well-worn hiking boots, their familiar weight grounding him.

From the back of his closet, he retrieved his hunting knife, a reliable tool he'd owned for years, and secured it to his belt. The cold steel against his

hip was a stark reminder of the potential dangers ahead. Finally, he focused his thoughts, mentally transferring his well-stocked backpack to his System Inventory. He'd recently managed to level up the Inventory skill to Level 2, granting him an additional 15 slots – a significant increase in capacity.

He was confident he could reach Level 3 before his next required run, and with dedicated effort, even Level 4 before the week was up. The thought of that deadline, a looming specter, sent a shiver down his spine. He pushed

the thought aside, focusing instead on the immediate task. After a final moment of reflection, a mental checklist of his preparations, he left the room.

He found his family assembled in the den, their faces a mixture of anxiety and forced smiles. The unspoken fear hung heavy in the air. "Alright,"

Robert said, trying to inject a note of brisk efficiency into his voice. "I

believe I'm as ready as I'll ever be. Let's get this over with." Stacey rushed forward, throwing her arms around him in a fierce hug. "Please, please

come back safe, Daddy," she pleaded, her voice muffled against his chest. "I will, princess," Robert promised, his voice thick with emotion.

He held her tight, savoring the feel of her small arms around him, a tangible connection to the life he was fighting to protect. He then embraced his sons, exchanging firm handshakes and nods of understanding, a silent acknowledgment of the shared burden they now carried. Finally, he turned to Sara, his wife, his anchor. He pulled her close, kissing her deeply, a wordless expression of love and a silent plea for strength. "Okay, Hal, let's do this," Robert said, stepping back from Sara. "Walk me through the procedure."

When you give the signal, I will initiate the dungeon entry sequence. A portal will manifest at your designated location. It will remain open only long enough for you to pass through, and it is exclusive to your use – no one else may

enter. Upon your return, the portal will reappear in the exact same location, so it is imperative that the area remains unobstructed.

Robert relayed this information to his family, his voice calm and measured. "So, Hal will create the portal in that corner," he said, pointing to an empty space along the far wall. "Only I can go through it, and it'll disappear as soon as I'm inside. It'll reappear in the same spot when I'm finished, so everyone, *please* stay clear of that area." He looked at each of them in turn, ensuring they understood the instructions.

Taking one last, lingering look at his family, their faces etched with a

mixture of fear and hope, Robert nodded to Hal. A soft, ethereal blue glow began to emanate from the designated corner, steadily intensifying. The air shimmered, and then, with a subtle distortion of reality, a portal materialized – a tear in the fabric of space-time, just large enough for a person to pass through.

It pulsed with a gentle, otherworldly light, a gateway to the unknown. With a final, silent farewell to his loved ones, Robert stepped forward, his heart pounding in his chest, and crossed the threshold. The portal vanished behind him, leaving no trace of its existence.

He found himself standing in a small, enclosed chamber, its walls constructed of smooth, white bricks that radiated a faint, cool light. The room was stark and minimalist, a perfect square measuring no more than fifteen feet on each side. A single, unadorned door stood directly opposite him, and to his left, a small, waist-high pedestal held a glowing, crystalline orb. The air was still and silent, devoid of any discernible scent.

"Welcome to Dungeon 7883667HG8776DE985762763FF7-1," a voice announced, seemingly emanating from the very walls themselves. The

voice was different from Hal's, possessing a more formal, almost mechanical tone.

Robert blinked, slightly taken aback. "Wow, okay, that's a mouthful. I'm definitely not going to remember that designation," he said, a hint of wry humor in his voice. "Could we perhaps... shorten it? Maybe call it 'The Training Dungeon'?"

"Dungeon Label set to 'The Training Dungeon'," the voice replied without hesitation. A moment later, a subtle chime echoed through the chamber, and

a notification appeared before Robert's eyes


Title Awarded: First Delver

A smile appeared on his lips. "Thank you Hal."

While I would like to take credit, that was the dungeon AI

"So this dungeon has it's own AI?" Robert asked

Yes, AIs manage all aspects of the system. This is the landing room. It is a safe space unique to each floor.

Nothing can enter here except you. Take all the time you need to prepare before proceeding to the next room. The orb on the pedestal is the System Store Interface. Simply touch it to access it.

Intrigued, Robert approached the glowing orb, his curiosity piqued. He reached out and gently placed his hand on its smooth, cool surface.


'The Training Dungeon' System Shop Interface


Option

Description

Show Inventory

Display a list of available items in this store

Make Purchase

Buy an item(s) from this store

Sell Item

Sell an item(s) to this store

Use Tokens

Use store tokens to make a purchase.

"So, just to clarify," Robert began, addressing Hal as he continued to

examine the glowing orb, "this System Store will actually purchase items from me? I can offload unwanted gear or materials here?" He wanted to be absolutely certain of the mechanics before he started experimenting.

That is correct, Robert. The System Store provides a

mechanism for you to sell items directly. However, I must

caution you: the prices offered within the dungeon environment will be considerably lower than what you might obtain through conventional trading outside the System.

Think of it primarily as a convenient way to declutter your inventory and free up space, rather than a viable strategy

for generating substantial profit. It's a matter of convenience over maximizing value.

"Understood," Robert replied, absorbing the information. It made sense; the System wasn't designed to be a get-rich-quick scheme, at least not through this particular avenue. "Convenience, not profit. Got it." He mentally filed away that crucial detail. With that clarified, Robert turned his full attention back to the orb. "Alright then," he said with a renewed sense of purpose, "let's see what treasures this shop has to offer." His fingers danced lightly

over the orb's surface, and a shimmering, holographic interface sprang to

life before him, displaying a categorized list of items available for purchase – the inventory of the System Store.

"Not much, but enough to start," Robert commented. "Those skill tokens are a nice touch."

Correct. I think the System is being generous. Use those tokens now. Common-tier tokens probably won't be as valuable later on.

Robert agreed and spent his three tokens on the starter packages.


Purchase Complete:
