2 basic skill tokens

Robert equipped the armor and strapped the shortsword to his belt. "Time to continue," he said.

He approached the door and swung it open. A long hallway stretched out

before him, leading to a dimly lit room. Robert stepped into the corridor, his eyes scanning the darkness. As he reached the end of the hallway, he cast a light spell into the room. A cacophony of screeches erupted as three large rats charged towards him. Robert drew his sword and prepared to meet the onslaught. With a swift strike, he felled the first rat.


Sword Strike: Tier 1 Sword Skill, Level 2 Short Sword Skill, +7 to attack chance, success, target hit. Damage applied base 5, bonus from skill 3,

size difference 4, total damage 12, target killed


Quest Complete!

The notification flashed before his eyes, detailing the attack. Before he could fully react, the second rat lunged, biting his leg.

User attacked by Lart Common Rat, small size bonus +2, speed bonus +2 user distracted +2,

chance to hit +6, user hit. Base damage 2, tier 1, total damage 3, user hit for 3 health.

"Hal, turn off those notifications!" Robert exclaimed, hopping back.

Confirmed.

Regaining his composure, Robert intercepted the third rat's attack and dispatched it with a swift blow. He then turned to finish off the second rat.


Combat complete:

Targets Killed:

3 Level 1 Common Large Rats killed (10 exp*3),

total 30 experience.

Skills used:

Bladed Weapons: +3 exp Short Swords: +2 exp

"Okay, Hal, that could have gone better. Let's keep the combat notifications to the bare minimum, please."


Notification settings adjusted

"So, what's next? Do I loot these things, search the room, or keep going?" Robert asked.

Always loot your kills, you never know what you might find. Simply touch the body and think 'loot.' While rats aren't worth much, you can learn skills to break down creatures more efficiently, obtaining valuable materials like skins, pelts, and other parts. The loot function is just a basic starting point.

Robert approached the first rat and looted it, receiving a single copper coin. He repeated the process with the other two rats. After a quick search of the room, he found nothing of interest except a new hallway leading deeper into the dungeon. With a determined look, Robert stepped into the unknown.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 14‌

Robert pressed onward, his footsteps echoing softly in the dimly lit hallway that stretched out before him like a maw leading into the unknown. He reached the threshold of the next chamber and, with a murmured incantation and a flick of his wrist, cast a 'Minor Illumination' spell, flooding the room with a soft, white light.

The sudden brilliance revealed a horrifying sight: a pack of oversized rats, their eyes gleaming with feral hunger, their high-pitched squeals piercing

the silence as they surged towards him in a wave of fur and teeth. Reacting instantly, Robert channeled his earth magic, shaping the raw energy into a dense, 'Lesser Bullet of Earth' that hurtled towards the lead rat with brutal force.

The projectile struck true, impacting with a sickening thud and sending the creature sprawling lifelessly to the stone floor. Before the others could close the distance, he followed up with a 'Lesser Bullet of Fire', but his aim was slightly off, the fiery missile narrowly missing its intended target and impacting harmlessly against the far wall.

Undeterred, Robert swiftly recast the fire spell, his focus unwavering, and this time, the burning projectile found its mark, incinerating one of the remaining rodents in a flash of searing heat. As he was casting, one rat had gotten through his defenses. Drawing his hunting knife with practiced ease, He parried a set of teeth. another set sank into his leg. Robert parried the first set, his blade deflecting a vicious bite aimed at his hand. Out of the

corner of his eye he spotted the second rat, but felt teeth sink into his leg. Gritting his teeth, He finished off the rat in front of him.

He then turned to the one gnawing on him. A swift, decisive thrust of his blade silenced the last remaining rat, ending the immediate threat. The

chamber fell silent, save for Robert's own ragged breathing and the faint crackling of embers where the fire spell had impacted. He surveyed the scene, the bodies of the five oversized rodents littering the floor. With a sigh, he methodically looted the corpses, adding a paltry sum of eight

copper coins to his meager purse – a small reward for a surprisingly brutal encounter.

Shaking his head at the underwhelming spoils, he moved on, stepping cautiously into the next corridor, the darkness beckoning him deeper into the dungeon's depths. He allowed a moment of peace to wash over, before speaking, "So, Hal, overall assessment? How am I performing so far?" He tried to keep his voice light, masking the lingering throb in his leg and the underlying unease that gnawed at him.

Not a disastrous performance, all things considered,

however, I must inquire as to your defensive strategy, or rather, the apparent lack thereof. You sustained

unnecessary damage during that encounter, a wound that could have been easily avoided with the proactive application of a relatively simple protective spell. Why did you choose to engage in direct combat without first establishing any form of magical defense?

Prudence dictates prioritizing personal safety, especially in an environment as unpredictable as a dungeon. A preemptive shield, even a minor one, could have significantly mitigated the risk.

Robert paused mid-stride, a wave of self-recrimination washing over him as Hal's words sank in. He slapped his forehead with the heel of his hand. "Damn it," he muttered, chiding himself, "I completely blanked on the

defensive spells. What an utterly idiotic oversight."

He mentally berated himself for his carelessness, a rookie mistake that could have had serious consequences. With a renewed sense of focus, he quickly summoned his System Spell Sheet, his eyes scanning the list of available spells, making a silent vow to prioritize defensive measures in future encounters.

He wouldn't make the same mistake twice. As he reached the threshold of the third room, he took a moment to prepare, his earlier recklessness replaced with a cautious approach. He first murmured the incantation for

'Minor Shield of Air,' feeling the familiar sensation of swirling air currents forming a protective barrier around him.

Then to top off his health he added the words of 'Valicar's Light Touch of Healing' on himself. He inhaled deeply, centering himself, and then, with another whispered incantation, cast 'Minor Illumination' into the chamber, bathing the space in a revealing light, ready to face whatever awaited him.

Two distinct groups of three rats each scurried out from opposite corners of the room, their beady eyes glinting menacingly in the sudden brightness.

Robert reacted with practiced efficiency, launching a volley of three 'Lesser Bullets of Earth' at the group on his right, while simultaneously drawing his hunting knife and closing the distance with the rats on his left, prepared to engage them in close-quarters combat.

The ensuing battle was a whirlwind of motion and magic, but thanks to his preemptive defensive measures, it was remarkably brief and one-sided. He emerged victorious, completely unscathed, the six rats lying lifeless on the stone floor.

A slight frown creased his forehead as he surveyed the scene. "Hal," he inquired, a hint of suspicion in his voice, "isn't this… well, isn't this a bit

*too* easy? I mean, these are supposed to be training runs, but I'm barely breaking a sweat." He felt a growing sense of unease, a feeling that something wasn't quite right.

You are, quite literally, engaging in combat with rodents, Robert, large rodents, admittedly, but rodents nonetheless. While their size may be somewhat enhanced compared to their mundane counterparts, they still possess the inherent limitations of, well, *rats*. Their tactical prowess is hardly noteworthy.

This particular dungeon floor is a standard introductory scenario, meticulously designed to acclimate you to the fundamentals of combat and spellcasting within a controlled, relatively low-risk environment. It's a proving ground for basic skills, not a crucible of ultimate challenge.

However, do not allow this initial ease to lull you into a false sense of security. Complacency is a dangerous enemy. The difficulty will escalate progressively. Consider this a gentle introduction; the true challenges lie ahead.

"I suppose you're right," Robert acknowledged. "So, this was the third room. I'm guessing there are only a few more. This won't be a long dungeon floor."

Correct, Remember, this is just the beginning. The real tests lie ahead.

"Duly noted," Robert murmured, acknowledging Hal's advice and making a conscious effort to dispel any burgeoning complacency. He methodically looted the fallen rodents, collecting their meager offerings before proceeding down the seemingly endless hallway, the silence broken only by the rhythmic tap of his boots against the stone floor.

He reached the entrance to the next chamber, and, remembering his earlier oversight, he paused to recast 'Minor Shield of Air,' renewing the protective barrier of swirling wind currents around him – a precaution that had already proven its worth.

With another muttered incantation, he cast 'Floating Mage Light,' flooding the room with light and revealing the next challenge: two groups of four rats each, a noticeable increase in both number and, presumably, potential threat compared to the previous encounters.

He stuck to his now-established strategy, a combination of ranged magic and close-quarters combat. He unleashed a barrage of 'Lesser Bullets of Earth' at the group positioned on his right, while simultaneously charging

towards the group on his left, his hunting knife held ready. As he closed the distance, a swift, darting strike from one of the rats glanced off his newly- cast shield, the impact jarring but ultimately harmless – a potent reminder that even these seemingly insignificant creatures could pose a danger if underestimated. The battle was short but furious, a flurry of spells and steel. Finally, with the last rat dispatched and silence returning to the chamber, Robert looted the bodies, adding their meager coins to his growing pouch.

He then paused, leaning against the wall for a moment, taking several deep breaths to regulate his breathing and calm his racing heart. "Hal," he inquired, a hint of weariness in his voice, "quick question: if I were to rest here for a short period, say, a minute or two, to regain my stamina, would these… *delightful*… rats respawn, forcing me to repeat this charming exercise?" The question was pragmatic, a consideration of resource management and efficient progression.

Respawns depend on the dungeon, for this training dungeon, they won't. Take your time and rest

"Valuable intel, indeed," Robert acknowledged, mentally filing away the information about the lack of immediate respawning for future reference; a small comfort, but a welcome one nonetheless. After allowing himself a

brief respite, a few precious moments to catch his breath and gather his strength, he straightened up, pushing himself away from the wall and steeling his resolve for the next challenge. He proceeded into the connecting hallway, his senses heightened, anticipating another encounter with the dungeon's ubiquitous rodent population.

Reaching the entrance to the next chamber, he paused, performing his now- routine pre-combat ritual: a murmured incantation to re-cast 'Minor Shield of Air,' ensuring his protective barrier was at full strength. Then, taking a deep, steadying breath, he cast 'Floating Mage Light,' the spell banishing

the darkness and revealing the scene within: not two, but *three* distinct groups of rats, a significant escalation in the threat level, their beady eyes gleaming with predatory hunger.

Robert reacted instantly, his training kicking in. He unleashed a rapid-fire barrage of 'Lesser Bullets of Earth,' his aim honed by previous encounters, decimating almost half of the assembled rodents before they could even

close the distance. He then transitioned seamlessly to melee combat, drawing his hunting knife and moving with a surprising agility, weaving through the remaining rats, his blade a blur of silver.

Despite his proactive defense and swift attacks, he couldn't avoid all damage; several rats managed to land glancing blows, but his air shield held firm, absorbing the brunt of the impacts. Finally, after a frantic, heart-

pounding skirmish, the last rat fell, silence descending once more upon the chamber.

Robert, leaning heavily against the wall, his chest heaving, his breath coming in ragged gasps, muttered, "Hal, that... that was significantly more

intense than the previous encounters." The understatement was palpable; he was clearly feeling the strain of the escalating challenges.

Indeed, the difficulty increased substantially, but you performed admirably, Robert. You maintained your composure under pressure and secured a decisive victory.

While you sustained some minor damage, that's a natural consequence of engaging in combat, particularly given your current level of experience and skill mastery. With consistent practice and dedicated training, your efficiency and defensive capabilities will undoubtedly improve.

"That's true, I suppose," Robert replied, his voice still slightly breathy. "It's strange... logically, I knew I wasn't in any actual peril, but the adrenaline,

the instinct... it still felt incredibly intense."

Combat is inherently stressful. Increased power and skill will make future battles of this scale easier to manage. For now, prioritize learning from each encounter and honing your techniques through practice. That is the path to mastery.

"That's a perspective I hadn't fully considered, but I suppose you're right," Robert conceded, acknowledging the wisdom in Hal's words. He leaned against the wall, taking a few more deep, steadying breaths. "Just give me a minute to collect myself, and then I'll press on. No use delaying the inevitable."

After allowing himself a short period of recuperation, a brief pause to regain his composure and let his heart rate return to normal, Robert pushed himself upright, a renewed sense of determination hardening his gaze. He ventured into the next hallway, the narrow passage leading him deeper into the dungeon's unknown depths.

As he reached the threshold of the next chamber, his hand instinctively went through motions, ready to renew, his now-routine pre-combat preparation: a whispered incantation to refresh the swirling winds of his 'Minor Shield of Air,' ensuring his defenses were at their peak. But before his hand moved, and he could utter the first syllable of the spell, Hal's voice resonated clearly in his mind, an unexpected interruption that brought him to a halt.

This will be the final room. Expect your hardest fight.

Robert, momentarily paused by Hal's interruption, took the opportunity to review his available spells, seeking a way to enhance his combat

effectiveness. He decided to add a new layer to his pre-battle preparations, selecting 'Minor Increased Movement' from his repertoire, a spell designed to imbue him with a temporary burst of speed. He murmured the incantation, feeling a subtle surge of energy coursing through his limbs, a lightness in his step. Satisfied that he was as prepared as he could be, he stepped across the threshold and into the next chamber, simultaneously casting 'Floating Mage Light' to banish the darkness.

The sudden illumination revealed a truly daunting sight: four distinct groups of four rats each, a veritable horde of rodents, their eyes gleaming with predatory hunger as they surged towards him in a unified wave of attack. This was, by far, the most significant challenge he had faced yet.

Reacting instantly, Robert unleashed a rapid-fire volley of 'Lesser Bullets of Earth,' his enhanced speed allowing him to cast and aim with remarkable swiftness. The projectiles slammed into the advancing rats, cutting a swathe of destruction through their ranks, eliminating roughly half of the monstrous rodents before they could even close the distance. Without missing a beat, he transitioned to melee combat, drawing his hunting knife and engaging the remaining rats, relying on his 'Minor Shield of Air' to deflect the inevitable attacks from the swarming creatures.

The battle was a blur of motion and violence, a desperate dance of survival.

Despite his best efforts, his shield, weakened from blocking. began to

waver, and two rats managed to slip past his defenses, sinking their teeth into his leg, sending jolts of pain through him. A third rat, emboldened by his momentary vulnerability, launched a desperate, leaping attack, catching

Robert off guard and sending him stumbling backward, momentarily disrupting his balance.

The remaining rats seized the opportunity, swarming him with renewed ferocity. In a desperate, adrenaline-fueled frenzy, Robert fought back with primal intensity, parrying bites, deflecting claws, and landing a lucky,

desperate blow that knocked one rat away. However, another rodent managed to latch onto his arm, its sharp teeth piercing his flesh, causing a searing wave of pain. Gritting his teeth against the agony, Robert, with a surge of raw strength born of desperation, punched the rat clinging to his

arm, dislodging it with a sickening crunch. Seizing the momentary reprieve, he instantly channeled his magic, forming and unleashing a 'Lesser Bullet

of Earth' at point-blank range, obliterating the creature. He followed it up immediately with a second, aimed at the last remaining rat, finally ending the brutal encounter.


Level Up!

Robert, his chest heaving, his breath coming in ragged gasps, slowly sank to the floor, the adrenaline-fueled frenzy giving way to exhaustion and the throbbing pain in his arm and leg. He leaned heavily against the cold stone wall, his body trembling with exertion. "That... that was far too close," he muttered, his voice strained, the words barely audible above the pounding

of his heart. "I need to get *significantly* better. That level of performance is simply unacceptable." The self-criticism was harsh, but honest; he knew he had made mistakes, relied too much on brute force and not enough on strategy and preparation.

After several long moments, allowing his breathing to return to something approaching normal and the shaking in his limbs to subside, he focused his will, murmuring the incantation for 'Valicar's Light Touch of Healing,' directing the restorative magic towards the gnawing pain in his arm.

He felt the familiar warmth spread through his injured limb, the tissues knitting themselves back together. Once the healing was complete, he pushed himself to his feet, his legs still slightly unsteady. He surveyed the chamber, now eerily silent save for the dripping of water somewhere in the

distance. The room was clear of immediate threats, the only remaining feature of note being a simple, wooden chest resting in the far corner.

He methodically looted the sixteen rat corpses, collecting their meager spoils, before turning his attention to the chest, a flicker of anticipation stirring within him – a potential reward for his harrowing ordeal.

Well done, Robert, that was a tough fight, but you persevered. Once you open the chest, the portal home will appear.

Opening the chest Robert was greeted by the dungeon's AI


Dungeon run complete: Uncommon chest awarded.

Chest contains:

One skill book (Aikido) Five silver coins

Two basic skill tokens

One Uncommon Shop Token

Items added to user inventory.

Thank you for visiting The Training Dungeon!

With that the chest vanished, replaced by a shimmering portal. As Robert stepped through the portal he received one final notice:


Quest Complete!

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 15‌

A surge of energy, exhilarating and potent, coursed through Robert as he stepped through the shimmering portal, back into the familiar confines of his home. The crisp, clean air filled his lungs, a stark contrast to the stale, damp atmosphere of the dungeon. The now-familiar "Level Up!" notification flashed before his eyes, a testament to his victory, but the sense of triumph was quickly overshadowed by a much more heartwarming sensation.

Two tiny arms, strong with the fierce love of a child, wrapped themselves around his legs in a vice-like grip. "Daddy, you're back!" Stacey's cheerful voice, filled with unadulterated joy, rang out, instantly melting away the lingering tension from the dungeon. "My little princess," Robert chuckled, his voice thick with emotion as he reached down and ruffled her hair. He looked around, realizing the rest of his family wasn't immediately there.

"I'm back, and I'm alright. Where's everyone else? Did they forget about their old man?" "Mommy's in the shower," Stacey explained, her voice

dropping to a conspiratorial whisper, "and the boys are..." Her explanation was cut short as John and Richard, alerted by the commotion, burst into the room, their faces lighting up at the sight of their father. "Dad! You're really back!" John exclaimed, his usual reserved demeanor cracking to reveal pure, unadulterated relief.

"Yes, I'm back," Robert confirmed, his voice steady despite the whirlwind of emotions swirling within him. The relief of returning home, the joy of seeing his children, the lingering adrenaline from the dungeon - it was almost overwhelming. "I've finished the first floor. Let's wait for your

mother, and then we can talk about it, okay? I have a lot to tell you." He headed towards the bathroom suite, his heart swelling with a profound

sense of gratitude.

"Honey, I'm back," he called out to Sara, his voice echoing slightly in the tiled space. "Give me a minute," Sara replied, her voice muffled by the

sound of running water. Turning around to head back to the kids, Robert only took a few steps before he was enveloped in a tight, almost desperate hug. Sara, wrapped in a towel, her hair damp, clung to him as if he might disappear.

"You made it back," she whispered, her voice trembling slightly, her body pressed against his. The fear and worry she had been holding back for days poured out in that single, heartfelt embrace. A warm smile spread across Robert's face, and he held her close, savoring the feeling of her in his arms. "Yes, I did," he murmured, burying his face in her hair. "But we should probably get out of the bathroom. The kids are waiting, and they're probably bursting with questions."

“The kids will wait a minute,” Sara murmured, pulling Robert into a passionate kiss, her earlier worry replaced by a surge of affection. She

lingered for a moment, her eyes, filled with a mix of relief and lingering worry, softening as she gazed at him. “I was so worried,” she whispered, her voice thick with emotion. After a much-needed moment with Sara, clinging to the normalcy and love it represented, Robert returned to the living room.

The kids were excitedly chattering, their earlier apprehension replaced by a flurry of questions and observations. He sat down on the couch, instantly becoming the center of their attention. "So," he asked, a playful twinkle in his eye, "what do you want to talk about, kids? What burning questions do you have for your old, dungeon-delving dad?" John, ever the eager one, his mind always racing, immediately piped up. “So, what did you see? What did you do? What did you fight? Tell us everything!"

Robert leaned back, a thoughtful expression on his face, and began to recount his adventure. He painted a vivid picture of the dungeon floor he had just explored, describing the echoing, torch-lit corridors, the chilling dampness, and the monstrous creatures he had encountered. He spoke of the challenges he had faced, the strategic battles he had fought, and the close calls that had left his heart pounding. As he spoke, he could see the wonder and fear reflected in their eyes, their imaginations running wild with his descriptions, their concern for him evident.

When he finished, a flurry of questions erupted. “You fought rats?" John asked, a hint of disappointment in his voice, clearly unimpressed. "Even I could fight rats! Did you find any loot?” “Yes, rats,” Robert replied, a

chuckle escaping his lips, "but rats the size of small dogs. And lots of them, all at once. Imagine a whole horde of them, rushing at you in the dark."

“Gross," Stacey exclaimed, wrinkling her nose in disgust. "No more talk about rats, Dad. Please." "As for loot," Robert continued, pulling out a handful of copper coins from his pocket, their dull gleam reflecting the lamplight, "just coins. Not much value here, unfortunately. But I did find a chest at the end, hidden away in a corner. Inside was a skill book."

“A skill book?" Richard asked, his eyes widening with interest. "What does it do? What kind of skill?" “It teaches me Aikido,” Robert answered, holding up the worn leather-bound book. “Aikido?” Stacey asked, tilting

her head. “What’s that?” “It’s a type of martial art,” Robert explained. “A way of fighting, but also a way of moving, of using your body.

I’ll probably learn it and then teach you all. It's all about using your opponent's energy against them. I also got a few more Skill Points, so I might be able to level up my teaching skill to Tier 3, which will let me teach you guys even better." With that, Robert decided to put the excitement of his return behind him and spent the rest of the day just relaxing with his family, savoring their company, and recharging after his ordeal.

The following morning, Robert woke up early, his mind buzzing with the possibilities that the new skill book presented. He retreated to his home office, a quiet sanctuary where he could focus without distraction. As he

opened the book, a prompt appeared before his eyes, asking if he wanted to spend a skill point to learn the skill within. He selected "yes," and a surge of knowledge flooded his mind, a torrent of information washing over him.

Images flashed before his eyes: graceful movements, precise strikes, and effective defenses, all flowing together in a seamless dance of motion. He saw bodies twisting, turning, redirecting force. Aikido, he realized, was more than just a martial art. It was a philosophy, a way of life. It emphasized harmony, balance, and the use of an opponent's force against them, a principle that resonated deeply with him.

General Skill - Martial Arts Unlocked, Subskill Aikido Learned.

The notification confirmed his understanding. Eager to put this new

knowledge into practice, he headed out to the backyard, the cool morning air crisp against his skin. As he moved through the forms, practicing the graceful, flowing movements of Aikido, he felt a sense of peace settle over him, a sense of power tempered by control.

His family watched from the window, a mix of amusement and admiration on their faces. "Honey, that was... impressive," Sara said, a teasing twinkle in her eye, as he finished his practice. John and Stacey, however, were less impressed. "Mom, really?" John groaned, rolling his eyes. "Sorry, kids,"

Sara chuckled, ruffling John's hair. "Just a little too much excitement for this early in the morning." Robert laughed as he headed back inside, wiping the sweat from his brow. "Thanks, honey," he said, grinning. "Later, I'll

show you some more moves, maybe teach you a few."

"Gross!" the kids chorused, their faces scrunched up in mock disgust, a playful end to the morning's training. While continuing to laugh, Robert told them he was headed back into his office to look into using his stat points from his level up. He needed a clear head for that.

He decided to allocate one stat point to Intelligence, bringing it up to match his Wisdom, creating a balance that felt right. Another point went to Dexterity, to enhance his newly acquired martial arts prowess, to make his movements sharper, more fluid. Finishing that up, he looked at his Skill Points. He had three basic and four Unlocked points, which would be enough to get his teaching up to the next tier.

Making his decision, he focused his will, channeling the points into upgrading his Teaching skill. He invested three points, elevating it to Tier 3, Level 4, a satisfied hum resonating within him as he felt the skill solidify, growing stronger. Robert took a deep breath, his fingers drumming on the desk, a nervous energy thrumming through him. He'd leveled up his Teaching skill, and now came the true test, the one that made him the most

apprehensive. "Hal," he asked his AI companion, his voice low, "how do I use this on John? How do I transfer this knowledge?"

Think about the knowledge you want to transfer. Call him in, and I'll guide you through it.

A knot formed in Robert's stomach. This wasn't just teaching anymore. This was rewriting his son's mind, imprinting knowledge directly onto his consciousness. "John," he called out, his voice slightly strained, "can you

come here for a second?" John entered, his usual carefree demeanor replaced by a flicker of curiosity, sensing the seriousness in his father's tone. "Yeah, Dad? What's up?"

Go ahead and place one of your hands on John's head. Once you are ready focus on teaching him the skill. Let John know it will feel strange and will probably give him a headache.

Repeating what Hal had said, Robert placed a hand on John's head, the touch feeling strangely unnatural, almost invasive. "Just relax and focus," he instructed, his voice low and steady. "It might feel a little...strange. Hal says you might get a headache." John closed his eyes, a trusting smile on his face, completely unaware of the monumental process about to begin.

Robert took a deep breath and channeled the knowledge, picturing equations and formulas, the building blocks of Algebra, flowing from his mind into his son's.


You are attempting to grant the Subskill Algebra to a Non-System User.

This is not recommended.

Repeated use of this ability can cause harm to the recipient.

Do you wish to continue (Yes/No)?

He gritted his teeth, his resolve hardening, and mentally pressed "Yes." Nothing seemed to happen for a moment, the silence stretching, then John suddenly tensed up, his body going rigid. A moment later, he started to

shake, a soft groan escaping his lips, a single tear forming in the corner of his closed eye.


Transfer complete.

Non-System User John Williams has been given the following Skill

Mathematics at Tier 1 Level 3 Subskill Algebra at Level 3.

Robert took his hand off John's head, his own hand trembling slightly. John slumped to the ground as if his strings had been cut, his face pale, his breathing shallow. "John? Are you alright?" Robert asked, his voice laced with worry, fear gripping his heart. Had he pushed too far? John opened his eyes, a grimace forming on his face, his hand going to his head. "Yeah, I think so," he said, his voice weak. "But...wow. That felt like someone crammed an entire textbook into my head, all at once. My head is pounding."

That should be the worst time for him The issue was you imparted a skill and a subskill; he was hit twice as hard. I'd give him at least 3 weeks before you try another one.

"It seems I made a mistake," Robert admitted, his voice filled with regret. "I should've just transferred the Math skill first. By going straight for Algebra, the system had to grant the general Math skill first. That was a bit much, all at once. Too much information." He turned to John, his voice full of concern. "Hal says we need to wait at least three weeks before attempting

another skill transfer. We'll let your mind recover. For your brother and

sister, we'll start with basic Math today, and we'll revisit Algebra in a couple of weeks. We'll take it slower."

Later that day, Robert repeated the process with Richard, Stacey, and Sara, transferring the general Math skill to each of them. While they experienced some discomfort, a mild headache and a feeling of mental fullness, it was nowhere near as intense as John's reaction. They were able to handle the

single skill transfer much better.

Exhausted from the intense mental exertion, the sheer emotional toll of transferring skills to his family, the worry and the relief swirling within him, the family decided to call it a night and retire early. They needed rest, time to process the day's extraordinary events, and to prepare for the challenges that still lay ahead. The weight of his responsibilities, the power

he now wielded, and the uncertain future pressed down on Robert, but as he looked at his sleeping family, he knew he would do whatever it took to protect them, to guide them through this new, strange reality.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 16‌

The days immediately following Robert's first harrowing dungeon

experience were a period of intense adjustment and rapid transformation, not just for him, but for the entire family. John, in particular, underwent a

remarkable metamorphosis. While initially disoriented by the sudden influx of advanced mathematical knowledge, he quickly embraced his newfound abilities with an almost obsessive fervor. He spent countless hours poring

over textbooks, scribbling complex equations on any available surface, his usual lighthearted demeanor replaced by a laser-like focus that bordered on unsettling.

He devoured information like a starving man, his mind effortlessly grasping concepts that had previously been beyond his reach. Robert watched his eldest son with a mixture of pride and concern, constantly monitoring him

for any adverse side effects, any sign that the forced knowledge transfer had caused unforeseen damage. While Richard and Stacey didn't exhibit the

same dramatic shift as John, they too displayed a significant, albeit more subtle, improvement in their mathematical comprehension, a testament to the effectiveness of Robert's Teaching skill, even at its current level.

The day after his return from the dungeon, Robert faced the daunting task

of explaining his sudden departure from his job. He informed his boss, with a carefully crafted explanation about an urgent and unforeseen personal

matter, that he needed to tender his immediate resignation. His boss, understandably, was far from thrilled, expressing his displeasure with a

mixture of frustration and bewilderment. However, he ultimately conceded, recognizing the sincerity in Robert's voice and the urgency in his eyes.

Fortunately, Robert had accumulated a substantial amount of vacation time – thirty days' worth – which provided a temporary financial cushion, a small reprieve in the midst of the overwhelming uncertainty. Later, while examining the silver coins he'd acquired from the dungeon, Robert noticed

their unremarkable appearance, devoid of any intricate designs, save for a series of strange, unfamiliar symbols etched onto their surfaces.

Hal explained that these markings were in the System's original language, a unique script that could only be applied to officially sanctioned System currency. Each coin, Hal further elaborated, weighed precisely one ounce and could be sold for approximately thirty dollars in the outside world.

While this wasn't a king's ransom, a few hundred of these coins would be sufficient to cover their basic living expenses for a reasonable period.

The real financial breakthrough, however, would come if he could manage to acquire a few gold coins – a prospect that would significantly alleviate

their immediate monetary concerns and allow them to explore the potentially lucrative, but still largely unknown, possibilities of enchanting items. Driven by this need, and by the looming six-month deadline, Robert threw himself into a rigorous training regimen.

He meticulously studied the spellbook, committing incantations and diagrams to memory, practicing the intricate hand gestures and vocalizations required for each spell. He sparred with John, honing his swordsmanship skills, and diligently practiced Aikido, striving for fluidity and precision in his movements. After three long days of dedicated practice, talking with the family, it was agreed it was time to take on the second

floor.

Finally, clad in his full armor, a significant upgrade from his previous attire, and with his weapons readily accessible, Robert stepped back through the shimmering portal, venturing once more into the depths of the Training Dungeon, ready to face whatever challenges awaited him on the second

floor. He was armed not only with steel and magic, but also with a growing understanding of the System and a fierce determination to protect his family.

"Welcome to Dungeon 7883667HG8776DE985762763FF7-1 currently called The Training Dungeon," the dungeon AI announced.

Robert, recognizing the familiar room, quickly snapped a few photos for his family. He then turned his attention to the System Store.

“Hal, is the System trolling me?” Robert asked, puzzled by the offerings.

No, while the System won’t simply hand you everything, it also recognizes your unique circumstances. It’s ensuring you’re prepared without making it too easy

“So, these spellbooks could contain incredibly powerful spells, or they could be useless?” Robert questioned.

I can’t say for certain. Any spell can be valuable, especially for training your skills. However, the specific spells are

random

“That ruins my plan to sell coins to support my family,” Robert lamented.

Selling System coins might not be a sustainable strategy.

It’s unlikely that people regularly find large quantities of gold and silver coins

"You're absolutely right," Robert concurred, his mind already racing with possibilities. "My primary focus for income generation needs to shift towards enchanting. If I can master the creation of even moderately enchanted items, I should be able to sell a few discreetly before arousing

undue suspicion or attracting unwanted attention from… well, anyone who might take an interest in unexplained magical artifacts."

He paused, considering another potential avenue. "And healing magic… that could be an even more lucrative, and perhaps less conspicuous, option.

If I can acquire and master more potent healing spells, spells beyond the basic 'Light Touch of Healing,' I might be able to offer discreet, paid healing services. People are always seeking miracle cures, and I could potentially provide them, for a price, of course. It's a delicate balance, though – too much visibility, and I risk exposure; too little, and we won't have enough to live on."

Driven by this strategic shift in focus, Robert interacted with the glowing orb once more, making several purchases from the System Store. With that business concluded, he closed the shop interface, the holographic display vanishing with a shimmer. Before venturing out of the safe confines of the landing room, he took a moment to equip the newly acquired armor pieces, the firm leather a reassuring weight against his skin. He adjusted the straps, ensuring a snug but comfortable fit, a tangible improvement in his defenses. Ready, he moved to the next room.

As he stepped through the doorway and into the first chamber of this new floor, he was immediately struck by an unusual, almost unsettling,

ambiance. Unlike the previous rooms, which had been shrouded in darkness save for his own magical illumination, this one was bathed in a soft, ethereal glow, emanating from an unseen source. The light was strangely unsettling, casting long, distorted shadows that seemed to dance and shift of their own accord.

Peering cautiously into the chamber, Robert's eyes widened in surprise. He spotted several amorphous, gelatinous shapes, shifting and pulsing rhythmically, their forms indistinct and constantly changing. They were

unlike anything he had encountered before.

"Hal," he inquired, his voice a hushed whisper, "is there a System function, some kind of spell or ability, that allows me to *identify* unknown entities or objects? I need more information about what I'm dealing with here." He felt a prickle of unease; these strange creatures were clearly something beyond his current understanding.

You can use the Identify skill to learn about creatures and items. Higher tiers provide more detailed information.

"That sounds like a necessary skill for survival in this place," Robert muttered, acknowledging the inherent dangers of facing unknown entities.

He promptly allocated a Skill Point to learn 'Identify,' understanding its importance for both offense and defense.


General Skill Identify Learned, due to feats, skill unlocked at Tier 4 Level 5.

With his new skill, Robert focused on one of the creatures.


Name: Common Slime

Class: N/A

Race: Slime (Red) Profession: N/A Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 1, Dex 1, Con 1, Int 1, Wis 1, Cha 1

Level: 3

Resistances: Physical (100%), Fire (100%)

Health: 25

Mana: N/A

"Wonderful," Robert muttered sarcastically, reading the information provided by 'Identify.' "So, we have five Red Slimes, boasting a delightful

one hundred percent resistance to both physical and fire damage. Just perfect. My sword is about as useful as a wet noodle against these things." He paused a beat.

That would be a good guess.

"Five Red slimes, no fire," he repeated. He considered. "Given the elemental nature of magic, and the fact that these are Red Slimes, associated with fire, it's a logical deduction that water-based attacks would be their weakness. I'll proceed on that assumption; it's the best option I have at the moment." With his strategy tentatively decided, Robert prepared for the

encounter. He murmured the incantation for 'Minor Shield of Air,' feeling the familiar sensation of swirling air currents forming a protective barrier around him. Then, with a cautious step, he entered the chamber, his senses on high alert.

The slimes, predictably slow and sluggish in their movements, began to

advance towards him, their gelatinous bodies quivering with what he could only assume was predatory intent. Selecting the nearest slime as his initial target, Robert focused his will and unleashed a 'Lesser Bullet of Water,' the projectile arcing through the air towards the amorphous creature. The watery missile struck the slime with a resounding splat, and Robert

immediately followed up by casting 'Identify' again, checking the creature's status to gauge the effectiveness of his water-based attack and confirm his hypothesis.


Name: Common Slime

Class: N/A

Race: Slime (Red) Profession: N/A Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 1, Dex 1, Con 1, Int 1, Wis 1, Cha 1

Level: 3

Resistances: Physical (100%), Fire (100%)

Health: 10

Mana: N/A

"Water it is, then," Robert confirmed, a grim satisfaction in his voice as the 'Identify' spell confirmed the significant damage inflicted by the 'Lesser Bullet of Water'. With a newfound confidence in his chosen tactic, he moved with swift, practiced precision, dispatching the remaining slimes with a series of well-aimed water bullets. Each creature required two direct hits, a testament to their resilience, but against his focused water attacks, they proved no match. He maintained a steady rhythm, casting, aiming, and firing, his movements fluid and economical, conserving his mana as much as possible.

Once the final slime dissolved into a harmless puddle, leaving behind only a faint, shimmering residue, Robert allowed himself a moment to catch his breath. He methodically looted the fallen creatures, collecting his due. Each slime yielded a paltry sum of 5 copper coins, a small but expected reward.

However, upon looting the final slime, he discovered a pleasant surprise: a small, shimmering opal, nestled amongst the dissolving remains. "Well,

now," he murmured, picking up the gem and holding it up to the light, admiring its iridescent glow. "A gem! I have no immediate idea of its

precise market value, but it's undoubtedly more valuable than a handful of copper.

A welcome bonus, indeed." With the chamber finally cleared of all threats and rewards collected, Robert turned his attention to the next unexplored passage, eager to discover what further challenges – and potential treasures – awaited him within the depths of the dungeon. As he stepped through the doorway, he was immediately met with a new sight. Inside the next room, he encountered another group of slimes, but these were distinctly different in appearance from the previous group, their coloration a stark contrast to

the fiery red of the ones he had just defeated. A new variable had been introduced, and Robert knew he needed to adapt quickly.


Name: Common Slime

Class: N/A

Race: Slime (Blue)

Profession: N/A

Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 1, Dex 1, Con 1, Int 1, Wis 1, Cha 1

Level: 3

Resistances: Physical (100%), Water (100%)

Health: 25

Mana: N/A

"Five more slimes," Robert observed, taking stock of the situation in the new chamber. "But these are *blue* slimes. A complete reversal of the previous encounter. Logically, if Red Slimes are weak to water, then Blue

Slimes, their elemental opposite, should be vulnerable to fire. 'Lesser Bullet of Water' is definitely out; it's time to switch tactics."

He prepared himself for the encounter, a grim determination setting in. With the practiced efficiency born of repetition and a growing understanding of

the dungeon's mechanics, Robert engaged and swiftly dispatched the five Blue Slimes, his 'Lesser Bullets of Fire' proving as effective as he had hypothesized. He moved with a confident fluidity, eager to progress and discover what further challenges, and potential rewards, lay beyond this chamber.

The next two rooms presented familiar scenarios, a sense of *déjà vu* washing over him. The first contained Brown Slimes, which he quickly recognized as vulnerable to earth-based attacks, and the second was populated by Whitish-Blue Slimes, susceptible to his 'Minor Shield of Air,' and his air based attacks. He dealt with these elemental foes methodically, conserving his mana and minimizing any unnecessary damage. While the loot obtained from these encounters was, as expected, unremarkable – a scattering of copper coins and the occasional minor crafting material – the fourth room he entered held a surprise, a deviation from the established pattern, hinting at the dungeon's potential for unexpected rewards.

The training was not just combat; it was about recognizing what element worked with what slime.


Ring of Lesser

Stoneskin


Tier 1

A plain copper ring that, when activated, envelops the

wearer in a thin, protective layer of stone. This 'Stoneskin' absorbs 15 points of damage before dissipating. The ring holds 10 charges, consuming one per activation. It can be recharged at a cost of 100 mana per charge.

"A genuine magic item! My very first one, in fact. Not a bad start at all," Robert murmured, a surge of excitement coursing through him. He carefully slipped the Ring of Lesser Stoneskin onto his finger, the cool metal a

tangible reminder of his progress. The simple copper band felt surprisingly substantial, imbued with a subtle energy he could almost sense. He admired it for a moment before turning his attention back to the dungeon, his focus sharpening. He moved on to the next room, pushing open the heavy door and stepping through, his senses on high alert. As he entered he spoke.

"Well, now this presents a more complex tactical scenario," he observed, taking in the scene before him. "Two distinct groups, each comprised of eight slimes… and a mix of all four elemental types in each group.

Two red, two blue, two brown, and two whitish-blue. Definitely a step up in difficulty, but nothing insurmountable, provided I approach this methodically." He paused, formulating a plan of attack, drawing upon his previous experiences. Robert decided to adhere to the elemental weaknesses he had already established, prioritizing targets based on the order he had encountered them previously. This meant focusing first on the Red Slimes, neutralizing them with 'Lesser Bullets of Water,' then shifting his attention to the Blue Slimes, exploiting their vulnerability to fire with appropriately

targeted spells.

The Brown (Earth) and Whitish-Blue (Air) slimes would follow, each engaged with their respective elemental weaknesses. It was a calculated approach, designed to maximize his efficiency and minimize the risk.


Level Up!

After looting the fallen slimes, Robert proceeded to the final room. Inside, he found two massive, imposing slimes. Using Identify, he learned more about these formidable foes.

Name: Uncommon Large Slime

Class: N/A

Race: Slime (Red) Profession: N/A Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 3, Dex 3, Con 6, Int 3, Wis 3, Cha 3

Level: 3

Resistances: Physical (100%), Fire (100%)

Health: 100

Mana: N/A


Name: Uncommon Large Slime

Class: N/A

Race: Slime (Blue)

Profession: N/A

Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 3, Dex 3, Con 6, Int 3, Wis 3, Cha 3

Level: 3

Resistances: Physical (100%), Water (100%)

Health: 100

Mana: N/A

"Alright," Robert muttered, steeling his resolve as he surveyed the daunting challenge before him. "These slimes are clearly a significant step up from

the previous encounters. They'll be tougher to take down, requiring more mana and more precise tactics. But," he added, a determined glint in his eyes, "we can do this. Careful planning and precise execution are key." He took a deep breath, mentally preparing himself for a protracted and demanding fight.

As soon as Robert crossed the threshold into the chamber, a fiery projectile launched with surprising speed and accuracy by the Red Slime slammed into him, bypassing his now-dormant air shield.

The searing heat caught him completely off guard, inflicting a painful 10 points of fire damage. The sudden attack served as a harsh lesson: these

slimes were not only more resilient but also possessed offensive capabilities.

He immediately prioritized maintaining a safe distance, dodging a jet of water launched by the Blue Slime. In return, he retaliated with a carefully

aimed 'Lesser Bullet of Water' of his own, striking the red slime. However, to his dismay, the attack only inflicted a mere 7 points of damage – a significantly lower amount than he had anticipated. "This is going to be a long and arduous battle," he grimaced, realizing the increased resilience of these enhanced slimes. With unwavering determination, Robert settled into a grueling rhythm, unleashing a relentless barrage of 'Lesser Bullets of

Water' at the Red Slime, prioritizing it based on his established strategy.

The combat was a protracted, intense affair, demanding constant focus and precise spellcasting. Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the targeted Red Slime dissolved. He immediately shifted his focus to the Blue Slime, switching to 'Lesser Bullets of Fire' to exploit its elemental weakness. The

fire spells proved more effective, bringing the blue slime down more quickly. The battle, though ultimately successful, left Robert utterly drained, his mana reserves significantly depleted. He checked his character stats, noticing for the first time that his Stamina had reached 10 points – a milestone, but also a clear indication of his physical exhaustion.

He made a mental note to investigate ways to improve his Stamina regeneration. As he finished looting the fallen slimes, collecting his hard- earned rewards, he was surprised to discover that each slime had yielded a silver coin – a substantial improvement over the copper he'd been finding. Then, as soon as he claimed the final coin, the remnants of the defeated slimes vanished completely, and in their place, a treasure chest materialized with a soft shimmer, a tangible reward for his perseverance.


Dungeon run complete: Uncommon chest awarded.

Chest contains:

One Book of Blueprints (Enchanting Tier 1) Twenty-Five silver coins

One Uncommon Shop Token

Items added to user inventory.

Thank you for visiting The Training Dungeon!

As soon as the items were claimed, the chest vanished, and a portal materialized in its place.

Casting a healing spell to recover his strength, Robert took a final look around the room before stepping through the portal.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 17‌

"Well, hello there, handsome," Sara drawled, her eyes twinkling with amusement and a hint of appreciation as Robert stepped back through the shimmering portal, clad in his newly acquired leather armor. "Looking incredibly dashing, or should I say, dangerous, in all that leather." Robert grinned, a flash of weariness momentarily forgotten in the warmth of her playful banter. He reached out, pulling her into a quick, reassuring hug, savoring the brief contact.

"Thanks for the compliment," he replied, his voice a low murmur against

her hair. "But if I'm being honest, I'm far more interested in removing all of this than posing in it." Sara chuckled, stepping back and playfully swatting his arm. "Always making grand promises, aren't you?" she retorted, her eyes sparkling. "Actions speak louder than words, my dear." Leaving that playful exchange hanging in the air, they made their way to the master bedroom, where Robert gratefully shed the constricting, sweat-soaked

armor, the leather still bearing the faint scent of the dungeon.

He took a long, hot shower, letting the water wash away the grime and lingering tension of the battle. Refreshed and clad in comfortable clothes, he rejoined his family in the living room, ready to share the details of his second dungeon run, including the strategic acquisition of the enchanted item recipe book. John, ever the analyst, immediately began flipping through the pages of the newly acquired book, his brow furrowed in

concentration. "This seems like a reasonable starting point," he commented, his fingers tracing the diagrams and descriptions.

"These Tier 1 enchantments are certainly not earth-shattering in terms of power, but that 'Minor Healing Ring'… that could prove quite useful in a variety of situations. Though, I confess, I'm not entirely sure how to quantify the practical effect of '10 health points' in real-world terms." "That's an excellent question, and one I hadn't fully considered," Robert admitted. "Let's find out." He activated his newly acquired 'Identify' skill, focusing his intent on each member of his family in turn. The System

responded, displaying a concise summary of their base statistics, including their current health points, providing a tangible benchmark for comparison.


Name: Sara Williams

Class: N/A

Race: Human(Non-System)

Profession: N/A

Gender: Female

Stats: Str 3, Dex 4, Con 3, Int 5, Wis 6, Cha 9

Level: N/A Resistances: N/A Health: 30 Mana: N/A


Name: Stacey Williams

Class: N/A

Race: Human(Non-System)

Profession: N/A

Gender: Female

Stats: Str 2, Dex 3, Con 3, Int 5, Wis 5, Cha 8

Level: N/A Resistances: N/A Health: 25 Mana: N/A



Name: Richard Williams

Class: N/A

Name: John Williams

Class: N/A

Race: Human(Non-System)

Profession: N/A

Gender: Male

Stats: Str 4, Dex 4, Con 4, Int 6, Wis 5, Cha 7

Level: N/A Resistances: N/A Health: 35 Mana: N/A

Race: Human(Non-System)

Profession: N/A

Gender: Male

Stats: Str 3, Dex 4, Con 4, Int 6, Wis 6, Cha 7

Level: N/A Resistances: N/A Health: 35 Mana: N/A

"Okay, so, based on these 'Identify' results," Robert began, explaining the implications of the newly revealed health statistics to his family, "10 health points represents a surprisingly *significant* portion of your overall health, especially for you, Stacey, and Mom. For someone with a lower health pool, that 'Minor Healing Ring' could quite literally be the difference between life and death, or at the very least, prevent a serious injury from becoming critical. And considering the remarkably low material cost – a

simple copper ring – it's an incredibly efficient investment." He paused, pulling out his phone and quickly searching online for current market prices. "It appears that a plain copper ring can be acquired for around twenty dollars, and a set of basic engraving tools will run us another twenty to thirty. That's a negligible expense for such a potentially life-saving item. I'll place an order for five rings and the tools on Amazon right now. With any luck, they should arrive tomorrow, allowing us to begin production almost immediately."

Richard, who had been quietly examining the photographs in the enchanted item recipe book, suddenly spoke up. "These illustrations are actually quite detailed and informative," he observed. "We should consider compiling

some sort of informational packet, a guide for… well, for whoever might need this kind of knowledge in the future. These pictures would be perfect visual aids." Robert considered the suggestion, nodding slowly. "That's… a surprisingly insightful idea, Richard. Even though the full System integration is still months, potentially years away, having readily available information could be incredibly valuable. A proactive approach, preparing for the inevitable. We can use this," he said, placing the comprehensive System guidebook on the table, "as our primary source material. A foundation to build upon."

The family gathered around the table, drawn in by the prospect of contributing to this crucial project. John, his eyes gleaming with intellectual curiosity, eagerly flipped through the guidebook's pages. "This is astonishing," he murmured, his voice filled with awe. "This book contains a wealth of information, meticulously detailed explanations of nearly every aspect of the System. It covers the history, the various races, the bestiary of monsters… We should definitely prioritize creating copies of this, or at the very least, extracting and organizing the most essential information." The

remainder of the day was dedicated to a lively, collaborative discussion, brainstorming the optimal content and structure for their planned informational packet. Ideas flowed freely, fueled by a shared sense of

purpose and a growing understanding of the System's complexities.

Later, during dinner, John, ever the strategist, steered the conversation back to their immediate crafting priorities. "While the informational packet is important, I still believe focusing on readily producible healing items is the most pragmatic approach," he stated, his gaze fixed on Robert. "Consider a 'Basic Rod of Healing,' for instance. According to the recipe book, it provides eight points of healing per charge and holds fifteen charges. That's enough to stabilize a severely injured person, potentially preventing them from succumbing to their wounds. The only significant drawback is that it doesn't appear to be rechargeable."

Robert nodded, thoughtfully studying the relevant entry in the recipe book. "You're correct, it's a one-time-use item. But the crafting process itself seems remarkably straightforward. All we need is an oak rod – easily

obtainable – and the same basic engraving tools we ordered for the rings. The primary limitation is the mana cost: two hundred mana per rod.

Considering the time required for both the rune-carving process and my current mana recovery rate, I estimate we could realistically produce two rods per day, at least until I can further increase my mana capacity and enchanting proficiency."

The family spent a little while longer discussing the optimal crafting strategy, weighing the pros and cons of various enchanted items, before finally calling it a night, their minds filled with plans and possibilities. The following day, Robert, after bidding his family a temporary farewell, kept a

watchful eye out for the expected Amazon delivery. As soon as the package arrived, he retreated to his office, his anticipation growing. He carefully unpacked the contents: the five simple copper rings and the set of engraving tools. He then retrieved the blueprint book, opened it to the 'Minor Healing Ring' recipe, and laid out all the necessary materials on his desk.

Following the instructions with meticulous precision, he picked up the first copper ring and touched the engraving tool to its surface. He felt a subtle

tingle as his 'Enchanting' skill activated, guiding his hand with an almost supernatural precision. The tool moved seemingly on its own, carving

intricate runes into the soft metal. Within twenty minutes, the process was complete. He checked his status, confirming the expenditure of 100 mana, and initially believed he had successfully created a ring capable of healing someone five times. However, a closer inspection of the finished product revealed a crucial, unexpected detail.


Name: Ring of Healing

Tier: 1

Rank: Uncommon

Description: This ring was made by an expert enchanter and when used will expend 1 charge to heal up to 17 health points.

Charges: 10

"Hal, what's going on?" Robert asked his AI.

Simple, as a Tier 4 Level 5 Enchanter, you're crafting a Tier 1 item. Even though you're not very experienced, your skill tier compensates. It makes sense that an expert would produce a better result than a novice.

"So, my Tier 1 items will be better than the book suggests?" Robert asked.

Mostly, Factors like material quality, tool quality, and other variables play a role. But these rings are perfect, capable of nearly fully healing anyone in your family.

Robert glanced at his status screen, noting his current mana levels and the time elapsed during the creation of the first ring. He calculated that, with careful pacing and allowing for natural mana regeneration, he could comfortably craft a ring approximately every 45 minutes without completely depleting his reserves. This would allow him to maintain a steady production rate without compromising his ability to perform other essential tasks, such as spell practice and, you know, eating.

With this schedule in mind, he dedicated the remainder of the day to crafting the remaining four copper rings, meticulously repeating the enchanting process for each one. He worked with a focused intensity, the rhythmic carving of runes and the subtle hum of magical energy filling his office. He finished the final ring just as the familiar sounds of his children returning home signaled the end of the school day, a perfect synchronization of his crafting schedule and family life.

As soon as his children, Richard and Stacey, walked through the door, along with John, Robert gathered them together, a sense of quiet pride swelling within him. He presented each of them, and Sara, with one of the newly enchanted 'Minor Healing Rings.' The children were immediately captivated, marveling at the intricate runes carved into the simple copper bands. They were even more amazed when, upon slipping the rings onto

their fingers, the bands magically adjusted themselves, resizing to fit perfectly and comfortably. Robert carefully explained the rings' function, emphasizing their limited healing capacity and the importance of using them judiciously. He stressed that these were not toys, but potentially life- saving tools to be used only in emergencies.

He then turned his attention to the next phase of his crafting plan: the creation of the 'Basic Healing Rods.' He placed another Amazon order, this time for a set of twenty-one-inch by one-and-a-quarter-inch oak dowels –

the core material for the rods – along with a can of wood stain to give them a more polished appearance, and, importantly, an electric engraving pen to streamline the rune-carving process. He informed his family that he would begin working on the rods as soon as the materials arrived the following day, further expanding their arsenal of magical protections. While reviewing the seemingly endless entries in the blueprint book, searching for

other potentially useful enchantments, Robert identified several protective items that he believed would significantly benefit his family's safety.

He decided to prioritize two specific creations: an 'Amulet of Protection (Kinetic)', designed to mitigate damage from physical impacts, and a 'Ring of Protection (Falling)', which, as the name suggested, would safeguard against fall-related injuries.

These two items, he reasoned, would provide a substantial layer of defense against some of the most common and potentially debilitating threats they might encounter in their daily lives. He also bookmarked two additional types of healing rods, expanding beyond the basic version: a 'Rod of Cure Poison' and a 'Rod of Cure Blindness'. These specialized rods, while requiring more complex enchantments and a higher mana investment, would address specific, potentially life-threatening conditions. Robert envisioned that these three types of healing rods – basic, poison-curing, and blindness-curing – would eventually form the cornerstone of their income- generating strategy, providing a valuable service and ensuring their family's long-term financial security.

The next day, the eagerly awaited package containing the oak dowels and the electric engraving pen arrived. As soon as the children had left for

school and John had departed, Robert, with a sense of purpose, retreated to his makeshift workshop – his home office, now repurposed for his

burgeoning magical crafting endeavors. He carefully laid out the blueprint book, opening it to the 'Basic Healing Rod' page, and arranged the newly arrived materials on his workbench. With a practiced hand, he measured and cut the oak dowels to the precise length specified in the instructions.

Then, taking a deep breath to steady himself, he began the intricate process of carving the required runes into the smooth surface of the wood.

This time, aided by the electric engraving pen, the task was significantly less arduous than hand-carving the rings. Still, it demanded intense concentration. Each rune had to be etched perfectly, following the blueprint's intricate patterns. As he completed each rune, a faint, ethereal

glow emanated from the wood, accompanied by a subtle drain on his mana reserves – a tangible manifestation of the magical energy being infused into the rod.

After approximately an hour of meticulous work, the rune-carving was complete. He then carefully applied the wood stain, transforming the pale oak into a rich, dark hue, giving the rods a more refined and professional appearance. Finally, with the stain dry, he performed the final step: the imbuing of the rod with the healing enchantment itself.

He channeled his mana, focusing his will, and felt the familiar surge of

energy flowing from him into the wooden rod. He repeated this process for each of the rods, working steadily until the last one was complete. As he finished the final rod, a wave of profound satisfaction washed over him. He had not just crafted a tool; he had created something truly special, something that could potentially save lives. He carefully inspected each of the completed rods, admiring the intricate runes and the smooth, polished finish. A feeling of quiet pride swelled within him; he was making tangible progress, taking concrete steps to protect and provide for his family in this new, uncertain reality.


Name: Oak Rod of Healing

Tier: 1

Rank: Uncommon

Description: This rod was made by an expert enchanter and when used will expend 1 charge to heal up to 12 health points.

Charges: 20

Once again, the tangible results of his labor underscored the significant advantage conferred by his high 'Enchanting' skill tier; what might have

taken an apprentice enchanter days, or even weeks, he had accomplished in a matter of hours. He carefully calculated the time and mana expenditure involved in creating each rod, factoring in his natural mana regeneration rate.

He concluded that completing the remaining nineteen 'Basic Healing Rods' would require approximately four days of dedicated effort, a substantial

time commitment, but one he deemed absolutely worthwhile given the potential rewards – both financial and in terms of the invaluable healing

capabilities the rods would provide. After allowing himself a full hour for his mana reserves to replenish, a necessary precaution to avoid overexertion, he commenced work on the next rod, determined to complete at least three more before the day's end, maintaining a steady and

sustainable production rate.

This rigorous crafting schedule became his new normal for the following

four days. He meticulously balanced his enchanting work with his familial responsibilities and personal needs, a careful juggling act that demanded

discipline and focus. His free time was no longer spent in passive leisure; instead, every spare moment was dedicated to honing his skills, expanding his magical repertoire, and producing the enchanted items that would safeguard his family and secure their future.

He even managed to find time during this to, once again, level up his inventory skill. Finally, with the last of the healing rods completed and his preparations meticulously checked, Robert knew the time had come for his third foray into the depths of the Training Dungeon, a prospect that filled him with a mixture of apprehension and anticipation. He was ready to face whatever challenges awaited him, armed with his growing magical prowess and the knowledge that he was fighting for something far more important than personal glory.

Robert looked around and saw that the room was the same as before. Deciding to just get started he went to the System Store and opened the inventory.
