"Hal, could this... could this be a sign?" Robert asked, his voice tight with urgency.

The answer is clear, Robert. Purchase the ring. And a word of advice: do not deplete that final charge. Your class ability is exceptionally powerful. With dedicated study, you can

master not only the crafting of similar items but also the spell it contains.

Robert's eyes widened. "Any magic item?"

Indeed. As a Master of Creation, you possess the unique ability to decipher the workings of others' creations.

Robert didn't hesitate. He bought the ring and slid it onto his finger. He stepped out of the room and into a dimly lit hallway. Casting a quick light spell, he moved down the corridor, his heart hammering in his chest. As he emerged, his breath hitched. Before him stretched an open field, an expanse of countless headstones under a breathtaking, star-dusted sky. Cautiously, Robert activated his air and light shields. After a final, lingering look at the graveyard, he cast his Blessing of Light spell. Prepared, he stepped into the eerie silence. He'd taken no more than five steps when the earth around several headstones erupted, and four skeletons clawed their way free.

Name: Skeleton

Class: N/A

Race: Undead

Profession: N/A

Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 8, Dex 14, Con 10, Int 6, Wis

8, Cha 5

Level: 10

Resistances: Slashing(50%), Darkness(90%), Death(auto) Health: 110

Mana: N/A

Robert's sword glanced off the nearest skeleton, barely leaving a scratch. He reacted instantly, unleashing a Radiant Bolt that staggered the creature, followed by two more rapid casts that obliterated it. Before he could savor

the momentary victory, another skeleton lunged, its rusty sword raised. Robert parried, retreated, and dodged the onslaught of the remaining two, then dispatched the second skeleton with a flurry of Radiant Bolts.

This aggressive display, however, proved costly: four more skeletons erupted from the earth, surrounding him. Thinking quickly, Robert activated the Ring of Turn Undead, banishing two in a blinding flash. He fell back, raining down bolts of energy until the remaining foes crumbled to dust. The graveyard fell silent once more, but Robert, panting heavily, surveyed the

scene with dismay; he'd barely crossed any distance, and the graveyard clearly teemed with undead. After looting the fallen, he found only a few

silver coins and a mysterious substance: bone dust. "Hal," he asked, "what's this bone dust for?"

It is merely an ingredient for alchemy. It holds no value to you unless you pursue that discipline, but it can be sold for profit once you arrive on a System World.

"A problem for later," Robert muttered, tucking the bone dust away. He crept through the graveyard, a grim reaper in his own right, felling three more clusters of shambling skeletons. But his streak of relatively easy

victories was about to shatter. Lulled into a false sense of security, expecting another predictable wave of bone and rusty steel, he was completely blindsided by the thing that erupted from the earth.


Name: Skeleton Warrior

Class: Fighter

Race: Undead

Profession: N/A

Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 13, Dex 13, Con 12, Int 6,

Wis 8, Cha 5

Level: 12

Resistances: Slashing(50%), Darkness(90%), Death(auto) Health: 150

Mana: N/A

These skeletons were different—equipped with superior swords and shields. Wary of this heightened threat, Robert launched a Radiant Bolt. But this skeleton, possessing an agility its lesser brethren lacked, raised its shield, deflecting the magical missile. The creatures advanced, their swords gleaming menacingly in the dim light. Realizing the limitations of a purely magical approach, Robert drew his own blade. Steel met steel, the clash echoing through the silent graveyard.

The skeleton's strikes were powerful, forcing Robert to rely on his superior swordsmanship to parry each blow. As the battle wore on, fatigue began to set in. Another bolt of energy was met with a well-timed block. Seizing a fleeting moment of opportunity, Robert activated the Ring of Turn Undead. A blinding flash consumed the creature, banishing it in an instant.

He turned to the second skeleton, determined to conserve the ring's power. He focused his attacks, battering the skeleton's shield until it splintered and broke. With its defense shattered, he unleashed a final, decisive barrage of Radiant Bolts, overwhelming the creature.

The immediate threat neutralized, Robert slumped, catching his breath. The encounter had been a grueling test, pushing his skills to their limit, but he

had prevailed. The two skeletons yielded more bone dust, and a welcome ten silver coins. Recognizing the need to recover, Robert rested.

He rose, weary but resolute, and continued his perilous journey deeper into the graveyard. Another pair of skeletal warriors rose to meet him, their swords glinting ominously—a grim reminder of the constant danger. This new pair, with their enhanced strength, proved formidable. Robert fought with every ounce of skill and cunning, parrying blows and unleashing his own magical attacks, but the relentless onslaught took its toll. He emerged victorious, but only after another exhausting battle, forcing him to rest again.

Examining his gear, he noted several chips in his sword's blade; a replacement would be needed soon. Rising once more, he pressed on, bracing himself for the next inevitable encounter, which came swiftly as he uncovered another pair of foes.


Name: Skeleton Mage

Class: Mage

Race: Undead

Profession: N/A

Gender: N/A

Stats: Str 8, Dex 14, Con 10, Int 11,

Wis 10, Cha 5

Level: 13

Resistances: Slashing(50%), Darkness(90%), Death(auto) Health: 130

Mana: N/A

Before Robert could even process the results of his Identify spell, a bolt of dark energy slammed into his shield, the impact jarring him and weakening the magical barrier. He surged forward, intent on closing the distance with the attacking skeletal mages, but a fiery projectile from the second forced him into a desperate dive. He retaliated with a Radiant Bolt, only to see it harmlessly absorbed by a shimmering, arcane shield surrounding the creature.

The air crackled with hostile magic. The battle became a brutal, back-and- forth exchange of spells and evasive maneuvers. Robert struggled to pierce the second skeleton's defenses, while the first, now stripped of its protective shield, relentlessly harassed him with dark magic.

Then, a flicker of opportunity: the first skeleton's arcane shield wavered. Robert seized the moment, unleashing a concentrated barrage of Radiant Bolts. The creature staggered, its form flickering, then collapsed into a lifeless heap of bone. Now, with his focus solely on the remaining mage, the duel intensified. Spells crisscrossed the battlefield, each a potential

harbinger of death.

The tension was a palpable thing, a suffocating weight in the air. Yet, through a combination of skill, resilience, and sheer will, Robert persevered. A final, perfectly-aimed Radiant Bolt struck true, and the skeletal mage crumbled, its malevolent energy extinguished. He looted the fallen, collecting twenty silver coins and more bone dust, then slumped against a headstone, struggling to catch his breath. His status page revealed a critically low mana pool; a significant rest was unavoidable. He consumed a ration, reviewing the battles, searching for any tactical improvements he could make.

After over an hour, feeling his mana partially replenished, Robert stood, ready to continue. He realized he'd scoured most of the graveyard; only the small mausoleum remained. Recognizing this likely held the final, and most difficult, challenge, and understanding the need to be at his absolute best, Robert decided on a longer rest, waiting for his mana to fully regenerate.

Once his reserves were restored, he meticulously recast his protective spells. Then, with a deep breath to steel his nerves, he pushed open the mausoleum doors and entered. The air inside was thick with a palpable sense of dread. Dim light revealed six skeletal figures standing sentinel, their empty eye sockets burning with an unholy, malevolent glow.

As he advanced, three sarcophagi burst open, spewing forth two

powerfully-built skeletal warriors and a robed skeletal mage. Surrounded by nine formidable opponents, Robert knew this was the ultimate test. The skeletal warriors, wielding swords and shields, pressed a coordinated attack,

while the mages unleashed a torrent of devastating spells. Robert, a whirlwind of motion, dodged, weaved, and countered with his own arsenal of spells and the practiced skill of his swordsmanship.

The battle raged, a chaotic maelstrom of life and death. Robert’s magic began to tear through the skeletal ranks, yet their numbers remained daunting. With each passing moment, the situation grew increasingly dire. Yet, Robert refused to falter. Drawing upon the last vestiges of his strength and refined skill, he fought with a ferocity that surprised even himself. He danced away from incoming attacks, parried lethal blows, and launched calculated counterstrikes. One by one, the skeletal warriors fell, their lifeless forms adding to the macabre decor of the mausoleum floor. Finally, a well-aimed bolt pierced the mage's defenses, ending its threat. With the heavy hitters eliminated, the remaining six skeletons were swiftly dispatched.


Level Up!

Looting the skeletons, he received his normal rewards. As soon as the final body was looted they all vanished and a Golden Chest appeared.


Dungeon run complete: Epic chest awarded. Chest contains:

One Rare Silver Inlayed Steel Longsword(Enchanted)

Ten gold coins

One Rare Shop Token

One Unlocked Skill Point

One pair of Uncommon Heavy Leather Pauldrons One pair of Uncommon Heavy Leather Bracers

One pair of Uncommon Heavy Leather Greaves

One Uncommon Heavy Leather Helm

One pair of Uncommon Heavy Leather Boots.

Items added to user inventory.

Thank you for visiting The Training Dungeon!

With that final thought the chest vanished and Robert walked through the portal that replaced it.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 23‌

The dungeon's stale, damp air, a clinging reminder of the ordeal he'd just endured, clung to Robert like a shroud. Yet, even the oppressive atmosphere couldn't extinguish the flickering flame of triumph within him. He had conquered the grueling test, pushed himself to the absolute limit, and

emerged victorious. As the familiar warmth of his home enveloped him, a wave of exhaustion washed over him, a stark contrast to the adrenaline that had fueled him moments before.

Sara, his wife, her face a canvas of mingled relief and deep-seated worry, rushed to meet him. "Robert!" Her voice was a breathy exclamation, her

brow furrowed with concern. "You're back! Are you hurt?" She searched his face, her hands hovering, wanting to touch, to reassure herself he was truly whole. He pulled her into a tight embrace, burying his face in her hair, the

familiar scent grounding him.

"I'm fine, love," he reassured her, the words a hoarse whisper against her

ear. His body throbbed with a symphony of aches, a testament to the brutal battles he'd faced, but he pushed the pain aside. "Just... incredibly worn out." The children, John, Richard, and little Stacey, drawn by the commotion, clustered around him, their eyes wide with a mixture of awe and apprehension.

"Dad, you look like you fought a dragon!" John observed, his voice tinged with both admiration and concern. Stacey, her lower lip trembling slightly, reached out a tentative hand to touch his arm. "Daddy, are you really okay?" she asked, her voice a fragile thread of worry. He knelt, ruffling her hair with a gentle hand. "I'm fine, princess," he promised, forcing a smile. "Just a little tired. It was a tough one."

He regaled them with a carefully edited tale of his adventure, pulling out a photograph of the eerily beautiful, yet terrifying, graveyard, and a chilling image, captured by his Identify spell, of one of the skeletal warriors. Stacey gasped, her small hand flying to cover her mouth in a mixture of fear and fascination. John, however, looked at his father with a growing unease.

"Dad, are you sure you should be doing these dungeon runs?" he asked, his voice laced with a concern that belied his young age.

Robert sighed, the weight of his responsibilities pressing down on him. "I don't have a choice, son," he explained, the weariness returning to his voice. "If I don't complete two runs a week, the System will force me into back-to- back runs on the last day. And that..." he trailed off, unwilling to voice the potential dangers of such a grueling schedule. "That's not fair!" Richard burst out, his young face flushed with righteous anger.

"I know, son," Robert agreed, his voice heavy with resignation. "The System is inflexible. A cold, calculating machine. It has its goals, and it will stop at nothing to achieve them, regardless of the human cost." "But," Robert added, forcing a brighter tone, "I did get some pretty good rewards this time." He pulled out the items acquired from the rare chest, the gleaming new sword catching the light.

John picked it up, his fingers tracing the intricate carvings on the hilt. "This is beautiful, Dad," he breathed, his earlier concern momentarily forgotten. "Yes, and perfect timing," Robert agreed, a genuine smile finally reaching his eyes. "My old sword was starting to show its age, and neither my mending spell nor my Repair ability could fully restore it."

He paused, then continued, "But the best part is the gold. It's finally enough to buy one of the Tier 2 spell books, and I desperately need the power boost to keep up." "Which one are you going to get?" John asked, his eyes shining with interest. Robert hesitated. "I'm leaning towards water," he admitted. "I wish one of the books offered advanced healing; that would significantly help me craft more powerful items. But, with any luck, one of the water spells will have some healing properties, even if it's not the primary focus."

After a precious hour spent reconnecting with his family, a balm to his weary soul, Robert retreated to his spare room, the designated space for his System-related activities. He began the methodical process of organizing his inventory, a task that always brought a strange mix of satisfaction and frustration. As he sorted through the accumulated items, he was struck, not for the first time, by the ephemeral nature of so many of them.

Equipment that had once seemed invaluable was now obsolete, rendered useless by the System's relentless progression. Returning to his office, seeking inspiration for his next enchanting project, a sudden, intriguing thought sparked in his mind. "Hey Hal," he asked, his voice tinged with curiosity, "is it possible to enchant cloth?"

Indeed. Enchanting cloth is achievable, but it presents a

greater challenge than enchanting objects with fixed forms.

The process requires a superior level of skill and

exceptional precision, particularly in the stitching. Your current capabilities suggest you can manage it, Robert.

However, a crucial caveat: inferior thread can compromise the enchantment's stability, leading to a potentially dangerous and uncontrolled discharge of magical energy.

"Can I use something stronger than cloth thread?" Robert asked.

Certainly. Your proficiency in sewing makes silver thread a natural choice for enchanting cloth. Silver possesses excellent conductive properties for magical energy. When purchasing, however, be certain to select thread of the utmost purity; impurities can significantly compromise the enchantment's stability.

Robert's search for silver thread led him down an online rabbit hole, culminating in a surprisingly affordable find. "Forty dollars for a hundred feet of 99.99% pure silver? A steal," he muttered to himself, clicking the

'buy' button with a satisfied smirk. The transaction complete, his thoughts immediately jumped to the practical application. Cloaks. The image formed in his mind: a flowing garment, subtly shimmering with magic. A cloak woven with an air shield, a constant barrier against attack. Or perhaps, he considered, a spark of excitement igniting within him, a cloak of swiftness, drawing upon the power of a minor time spell to grant bursts of incredible speed. The potential applications seemed endless.

Both cloak concepts possess considerable merit.

Remember to acquire a set of needles specifically designed

for working with fine metallic threads; standard needles may prove inadequate.

"Thanks for the reminder, Hal," Robert replied, a grateful smile spreading across his face. He turned his attention back to the screen, browsing through various online vendors for suitable cloaks. He quickly located several promising options and, with a few clicks, ordered a dozen heavy cloth cloaks in a variety of dark, neutral colors, thinking they would provide the best canvas. Just as he confirmed the purchase, Sara entered the room, her

gaze drawn to the array of cloaks displayed on his monitor.

"Cloaks?" she questioned, a playful lilt in her voice, one eyebrow arched in amusement. "Really, Robert? Aren't those a bit... theatrical, even for you?" "They're a simple, classic garment," Robert defended, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "Perfect for testing my enchantments. I need a blank canvas, and this will help me practice. Once I've mastered the basics, I'll

move on to more complex items, like shirts and jackets, or even dresses."

"I suppose that makes a certain kind of sense," Sara conceded, though a small, thoughtful frown creased her brow, hinting at a lingering skepticism. "But couldn't you achieve the same result with just a simple piece of cloth? Seems a bit extravagant." "Not quite," Robert explained patiently. "I need to test the enchantments on something I can actually wear, something that simulates real-world conditions. A loose piece of fabric won't give me

accurate results."

The following day, a large package arrived, containing Robert's carefully chosen supplies and the dozen cloaks. He cleared his workbench, a sense of anticipation building within him. With practiced precision, honed over countless hours of crafting, he began the intricate task of enchanting the first cloak. Selecting a spool of shimmering silver thread, he meticulously inscribed the runes of the Air Shield spell onto the dark fabric, his brow furrowed in concentration. After an hour of focused, painstaking work, the enchantment was complete. He stepped back, took a breath and cast the

Identify spell to reveal its properties.


Name: Cloak of Shielding

Tier: 1

Rank: Uncommon

Description: This cloak, crafted by the hand of an expert enchanter, will expend 1 charge to cast a Minor Shield of Air spell upon the wearer.

Charges: 15

Pleased with his first creation, Robert turned his attention to the second cloak. He imbued it with the runes of the minor movement spell, carefully weaving them into the fabric. Once the enchantment was complete, he cast the Identify spell.


Name: Cloak of Minor Movement

Tier: 1

Rank: Uncommon

Description: This cloak, crafted by the hand of an expert enchanter, will expend 1 charge to cast a Minor Increased Movement spell upon the

wearer.

Charges: 15

The Air Shield cloak, humming faintly with contained magic, was carefully folded and stored alongside its un-enchanted brethren. A profound sense of satisfaction, the quiet pride of a craftsman in a job well done, settled over Robert. He sealed the box, leaving the remaining cloaks for later, and sought out the comforting chaos of his family. He found them gathered in

the living room, a tableau of domestic tranquility: Sara reading, the children engrossed in a board game.

He joined them, relishing the simple joy of their company, the worries and pressures of the System fading into the background. The next morning,

while organizing his ever-growing inventory – a task that seemed to become more complex with each passing day – Robert noticed a

surprisingly large balance of silver coins. Nearly four hundred, accumulated from countless dungeon runs, and largely forgotten amidst the more immediately pressing concerns of crafting materials and magical upgrades.

He rarely paid attention to the mundane currency, focused as he was on acquiring rarer resources. Intrigued by their current potential value, and

aware that his enchanting supplies weren't cheap, a plan began to form. He decided to investigate their worth in the "real world."

Robert's research pointed him towards a local pawn shop, "Golden Hand Pawn," a well-established, if somewhat dusty, institution known for its fair dealings, at least according to online reviews. He arrived to find a short queue, a mix of people hoping to offload unwanted possessions or secure a quick loan. As he waited, he approached a young employee, a man with tired eyes and a neatly trimmed beard, who was restocking shelves behind the counter.

"Excuse me," Robert began, "I have a collection of silver coins I'm looking to sell. Would you be interested?" The employee, sensing a potential commission, immediately straightened up, a flicker of interest in his eyes. "Possibly," he replied, his voice noncommittal. "Let's see what you've got."

Robert produced a single coin from the pouch, placing it carefully on the counter.

The employee picked it up, turning it over in his fingers, his brow furrowing as he examined the unfamiliar script and intricate design. "Where did you get these?" he asked, his tone a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. "They were part of my father's estate," Robert explained, keeping his tone neutral. "He was a bit of a collector, but I don't know much about their origins."

The employee nodded slowly, then disappeared into a back room, returning moments later with a small testing kit. He meticulously tested the coin, confirming its high silver purity. "Alright," he said, finally looking up. "We can offer you spot price minus five dollars, depending on how many you have." Robert pressed for clarification. "$30.47 is the spot, take away $5 will make your total $25.47".

Robert considered for a moment, then countered, "How about $26.00 even?

It's a fair price, and it saves us both the hassle of dealing with cents." The employee hesitated, then, with a shrug, agreed. "Deal." Robert returned to his car, the weight of the remaining 199 coins a tangible reminder of his

unexpected windfall. He brought the heavy pouch back inside, the employee now visibly more enthusiastic.

After a thorough, and somewhat painstaking, count and examination of each coin, the transaction was finalized. Robert walked out of the Golden Hand Pawn with $5,174 in crisp bills, a significant sum that eased the financial pressure he'd been feeling. Back home, he found Sara in the kitchen, preparing dinner. He recounted the story of the pawn shop visit, handing her the thick stack of cash.

"Here," he said, "Put this somewhere safe. It's a nice little bonus." While he was pleased with the unexpected income, Robert knew it wasn't a

sustainable solution. The System demanded constant progress, a relentless pursuit of power. With a renewed sense of purpose, and a slightly lighter heart, he returned to his office, the image of the unfinished cloaks foremost in his mind.

His enchanting endeavors, the true path to security and advancement, beckoned. Several days, filled with focused work and precious family time, passed in a blur. Finally, the last of the cloaks was imbued with its

protective enchantment. Robert stood back, admiring his handiwork. He was ready.

He prepared himself mentally and physically, gathering his supplies and donning his enchanted gear. It was time to descend into the dungeon once more, this time to face the unknown challenges of the sixth floor.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 24‌

Stepping through the portal, Robert was greeted by the usual AI greeting:

Welcome, adventurer. You have entered Dungeon 7883667HG8776DE985762763FF7-1, currently known as The Training Dungeon. You are now on the Sixth Floor.

Robert not wasting any time went straight to the shop interface to buy the water spell book.
