3

rare

1 token

This pack contains 5 random Tier 3 spell scrolls.

"Hal, I'm starting to think the System's messing with me," Robert said, a puzzled frown on his face. "I need that healing book, but what's the deal with these spell scrolls?"

Spell scrolls are one-time-use spells, you can cast directly

from them, or study the scroll to learn the spell permanently. Studying it destroys the scroll, though.

"So, five random spells I can potentially add to my spellbook? Anything goes, huh?" Robert mused. "I guess even a mediocre Tier 3 spell is better than nothing at this point."

True, but remember the randomness. You could get spells from schools you can't use yet, or even five duplicates.

"Still worth a shot, if it gets me closer to that healing book. Fifty gold..." Robert trailed off.

Speaking of gold, have you considered selling some of your items?

"Completely slipped my mind!" Robert exclaimed. "Does the System shop pay decently?"

Not compared to a real merchant. But for an enchanter, even a third of an item's value can be a boost.

"A third? The System's a real tightwad," Robert chuckled.

It's designed to encourage player interaction, the System wants users to rely on each other, not it. Of course, in your situation, options are limited.

After buying the water book and the scroll pack, Robert experimented with selling some items to get a feel for the System's pricing.


Name: Fire Opal

Tier: 1

Quantity: 1

Price: 30 Silver


Name: Cloak of Shielding

Tier: 1

Quantity: 1

Price: 70 Silver


Name: Cloak of Minor Movement

Tier: 1

Quantity: 1

Price: 70 Silver


Name: Oak Rod of Healing

Tier: 1

Quantity: 1

Price: 1 Gold

"Hal," Robert said, a slight edge of disbelief in his voice, "Am I losing it, or are some of these prices seriously inflated?"

Enchanted items invariably command a premium. The art of enchanting is a rare and coveted skill. As for the healing item, any artifact capable of mending wounds is highly sought after. While that particular rod might offer only modest healing to a seasoned adventurer, it could be the difference between life and death for someone awaiting a skilled healer. The question then becomes: what value do you place on a human life?

Robert paused, stroking his chin thoughtfully. "Point taken. So, in theory, if I returned with eighty of those rods, I could afford the remaining books..." He trailed off, lost in calculation. Before embarking on his task, Robert retrieved the spell scrolls and examined them with a critical eye.

Name: Scroll of Earth Bind

Tier: 3

Rank: Uncommon

Description: Earth Spell that anchors an opponent to the earth, making them unable to move or cast spells. This spell is useful for controlling powerful enemies or escaping dangerous situations.

Charges: 1


Name: Scroll of Water Wall

Tier: 3

Rank: Uncommon

Description: Water Spell that creates a wall of water to block attacks and projectiles. The wall can last for 30 seconds plus 15 second per tier over 3 plus 5 seconds per (int/10) or until it is dispelled.

Charges: 1


Name: Scroll of Healing Light

Tier: 3

Rank: Uncommon

Description: Light Spell that emits a beam of healing light that restores 20 health points per second to a target ally. The healing effect lasts for 10 seconds.

Charges: 1


Name: Scroll of Gravity Well

Tier: 3

Rank: Uncommon

Description: Gravity Spell that creates

a gravitational pull that draws enemies towards the caster, dealing 15 damage plus 10 damage per tier over 3 and reducing their movement speed for 10 seconds + 5 seconds per tier over 3.

Charges: 1


Name: Scroll of Nature's Wrath

Tier: 3

Rank: Uncommon

Description: Nature spell that summons a barrage of thorns up to 10 thorns plus 2 thorns per tier over 3 and 1 through per (Int/10)and vines to attack enemies in a 10-foot radius, dealing 10 nature damage per hit.

Charges: 1

"These scrolls are surprisingly potent," Robert observed, a hint of awe in his voice. "Three of them are immediately usable, without needing to unlock any new skills." He held them up, examining the intricate script.

And it might be highly advantageous to unlock the requisite skills for the remaining two, you possess the unspent skill points.

Robert hesitated. "That's true...but am I becoming overly reliant on magic? Maybe I should diversify," he mused, pacing the small room.

You are, fundamentally, a mage, mages thrive on magic. While supplementary skills like swordsmanship or archery can provide a tactical advantage, your core strength, your essence, lies in the arcane arts. Your current path reflects a significant investment in that core strength.

"Right," Robert conceded, a renewed sense of purpose filling him. "Alright, I'll unlock those two skills and commit these spells to memory." He nodded

decisively. Robert dedicated the following hours to mastering the five spells contained within the scrolls. He practiced the incantations, the hand gestures, the subtle modulations of his inner mana. Once he felt a

comfortable level of proficiency, he rose, stretching his tired muscles, and prepared to depart for the dungeon. Abruptly, the door behind him dissolved into shimmering particles, replaced by a swirling, iridescent portal. "Hal, what in the world is happening?" Robert asked, a jolt of alarm coursing through him.

Curious, the System is altering your destination. It appears an unforeseen event has necessitated a change of plans.

"Should I be concerned?" Robert inquired.

Not unduly. The level of challenge will remain consistent. However, a novel situation has arisen, and the System has evidently determined that you are the most suitable candidate to address it. Alternatively, another user may have requested aid, and you were selected.

"Wait, someone requested help? How?" Robert asked, bewildered.

You must understand, dungeons are not bespoke creations for each individual, that would be an inefficient expenditure of resources. The System draws upon a vast, pre-existing network of dungeons spanning the multiverse. It identifies an unoccupied level, modifies it to meet the specific parameters of the challenge, and then establishes a portal connection. Reusing existing structures is far more efficient than generating them anew.

"I... I think I understand," Robert replied slowly. "So, the portal is basically a shortcut to some random, unused dungeon level in another System- connected reality?"

Precisely. I hypothesize that an unusual event is unfolding, and the System has opted to capitalize on it.

Robert chuckled wryly. "So, because I took extra time to prepare, the System decided to throw me a curveball. I guess I only have myself to blame."

Perhaps, however, the System would not redirect you without sufficient justification. Consider this a valuable, and potentially more rewarding, opportunity.

With a final, resolute nod, Robert steeled his nerves and stepped through the swirling portal, bracing himself for the unknown that awaited him.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 25‌

Robert stumbled through the shimmering, disorienting space of the portal, expecting the cold, damp embrace of a dungeon. Instead, he landed on solid earth, the scent of wildflowers and freshly turned soil filling his nostrils. He blinked, momentarily blinded by the sudden sunlight. He wasn't in a dank crypt; he was standing on a well-worn dirt road that meandered between quaint, half-timbered houses with thatched roofs. A verdant forest, alive with the chirping of unseen birds, stretched beyond the village's edge, a

picture of serene, rustic life.

It was… idyllic. Almost too idyllic. He took a tentative step forward, the crunch of gravel under his boots the only sound breaking the peaceful silence. The village seemed deserted, the silence unsettling. Where were the people? The livestock? Even the stray dogs one might expect in a rural setting were absent. He ventured deeper, a growing unease prickling at the back of his neck. This wasn't right. This wasn't a dungeon. This wasn't…

A blood-curdling scream, raw and desperate, shattered the tranquility. It ripped through the air, a jagged tear in the fabric of the peaceful scene. Robert's instincts took over. He broke into a run, his hand instinctively reaching for the hilt of his sword, his heart pounding in his chest. He followed the sound, his pace quickening with each desperate cry. Rounding a bend in the road, a horrific scene unfolded before him. A family – a man, a woman, and a young girl – were huddled together, their faces contorted in terror.

They were under attack by a pack of skeletal warriors, their bony claws dripping with an unnatural, oily black substance. The skeletons were led by a grotesque goblin shaman, its wrinkled green skin stretched taut over sharp bones, its eyes burning with a malevolent, sickly green light. The shaman cackled, a sound that grated on Robert's nerves, as it raised a gnarled staff, preparing to unleash another spell.

Without hesitation, without a second thought, Robert acted. He channeled his power, focusing the raw energy of his will, and unleashed a blinding

burst of radiant energy. The spell struck the closest skeleton, the one directly threatening the little girl. The skeletal structure, already brittle and decayed, couldn't withstand the holy power. It exploded in a shower of bone fragments, the oily black substance dissipating into nothingness.

The sudden, unexpected attack startled the remaining undead. Robert seized the advantage. He unleashed a flurry of spells, bolts of pure energy lancing out from his fingertips, striking the remaining skeletons with pinpoint accuracy. One by one, they crumbled, their unholy animation extinguished. The goblin shaman, momentarily stunned by the ferocity of Robert's assault, shrieked in rage and flung a dark, viscous bolt of energy.

Robert, anticipating the attack, dodged with a practiced ease, the spell impacting harmlessly on the ground, leaving a patch of withered, blackened earth. He retaliated with a swift, precise spell of his own, a concentrated blast of force that slammed into the shaman, sending it sprawling. Before it could recover, Robert was upon it, his sword a silver flash in the afternoon sun.

The blade met the goblin's flesh with a sickening thud, ending its threat permanently. Panting, his heart still racing, Robert turned to the terrified family. They were huddled together, the man shielding his wife and

daughter with his body, his eyes wide with a mixture of fear and disbelief. "Are you alright?" Robert asked, his voice hoarse from exertion.

He sheathed his sword, trying to appear as non-threatening as possible. The man stared at him, his mouth agape. He opened and closed it several times, as if struggling to form words. Finally, he stammered, "Xal'thak, n'zarth, k'thr'lak, y'thr'lth." The sounds were utterly foreign, a jumble of guttural clicks and hisses. Robert frowned, confused. "Hal, I cannot understand them," he said, his voice low, hoping the family wouldn't be further alarmed by his seemingly talking to himself.

They are speaking System Common. Normally, you would learn the language beforehand during the initial System integration process, but due to the early and unexpected deployment, you were not granted the necessary linguistic

protocols. One moment, I shall attempt to rectify this oversight.


System Override Requested!

Override Approved!

Basic System Language Pack Granted!

New Skills Learned!

A wave of warmth washed over Robert, a tingling sensation spreading through his mind. It felt as if a locked door in his brain had suddenly been flung open, revealing a flood of new information. Suddenly, he could understand their words, the sounds now forming coherent sentences in his mind. "Are you okay, stranger?" the woman inquired, her voice trembling, her eyes still wide with fear, but a glimmer of hope now shining within them.

"Yes, I’m fine. I apologize for the language barrier," Robert replied, relief flooding through him. "I... I wasn't prepared for this." "But we’re speaking Common, everyone knows Common," the man exclaimed, perplexed, his brow furrowed in confusion. He looked Robert up and down, taking in his strange attire – the enchanted leather armor, the unfamiliar sword, the faint aura of magical energy that still clung to him.

"I’m new to the System," Robert explained, trying to keep his voice calm and reassuring. "My Universe is still integrating. I haven’t been granted the full range of standard protocols yet." The man's eyes widened in sudden understanding. "You’re a Forerunner," he realized, awe creeping into his voice. He took a step back, almost reverently. "A Forerunner. I’ve never met one before. I've only heard stories..."

Forerunner is the system label given to identify people like you who are the first system users for a universe, while not common, it's a known event, often accompanied by initial instability and integration challenges.

Robert, still slightly overwhelmed by the sudden influx of information and the dramatic shift in the man's demeanor, refocused on the immediate

situation. "What’s happening here?" he asked, gesturing towards the destroyed skeletons and the lingering scent of dark magic. "Are you

injured? I can heal you. I have some basic healing spells." “We’re fine, thank goodness,” the man replied, shaking his head. He reached out and took his wife's hand, his grip tight and reassuring.

"Monsters started attacking the village a short while ago. We were just heading inside when they found us. We thought... we thought we were going to die." He shuddered, the memory of the near-death experience still fresh. “I should continue on to see if there are others I can help," Robert said, his voice filled with a newfound sense of urgency. He couldn't shake the image of the terrified family, the horrifying closeness of death. He needed to do more. "Will you be okay? Do you have somewhere safe to

go?" He added, almost as an after thought, "by the way, my name is Robert, Robert Williams."

“We’ll be fine. This is our home," the man said, gesturing towards the simple, yet sturdy-looking house behind them. "We’ll head inside and

barricade the door. Just be careful, Robert,” the man warned. “The village elder and the guard captain should be at the town center, near the village hall. You might want to check there. They'll likely be coordinating the defense." "Also it is nice to meet you, Robert, my name is Kael, and this is my wife Elara, and our daughter Lyra."

He gestured to each in turn. "We are going to head in, please be careful." Elara gave Robert a small, grateful smile, her eyes still red-rimmed from crying, and Lyra, a little girl of no more than five, peeked out from behind

her mother's skirts, her large, innocent eyes filled with a mixture of fear and curiosity. With that, the family retreated into their home, the sound of

furniture being dragged across the wooden floor and heavy bolts being slammed into place echoing through the otherwise quiet street.

Robert watched them go, a knot of anxiety tightening in his stomach. He quickly gathered the meager loot from the fallen creatures – a few chipped bone fragments, a tarnished silver ring from the goblin shaman – and stored them in his inventory. He then turned and headed towards the town center, his pace brisk, his senses on high alert. The idyllic facade of the village had been shattered, revealing a terrifying reality.

As he headed toward the center of the village, a growing sense of dread filled him. The silence was broken only by the occasional gust of wind rustling through the trees and the distant sounds of battle. He passed two other homes, their doors hanging open, their interiors ransacked. Outside

each, he found scenes of carnage. Two more families, brutally slain. He saw the bodies of men, women, and children, lying broken and lifeless on the ground.

Nearby, he spotted the attacking forces – more skeletal warriors and goblin shamans, their eyes glowing with that same unsettling green light. Without a word, Robert engaged, the fury of the previous encounter fueling his actions. Spells flew, his sword danced, and the undead fell swiftly beneath his onslaught. But the victory felt hollow, the silence that followed punctuated only by his own ragged breathing. "Hal," Robert asked, his

voice heavy with sadness, his hands trembling slightly as he cleaned his sword, "is this real? Are these poor people really dead? This isn't some... some simulation?"

I'm afraid so, Robert, this is a real System World, and these are real people, with real lives, now extinguished. Their deaths are permanent.

Robert felt a wave of nausea wash over him. He had seen death before, in his own world, but it had always been distant, impersonal, mediated by news reports or television screens. This was different. This was visceral, immediate, and utterly heartbreaking. "But how?" he asked, his voice choked with confusion. "I'm only level 12. These creatures are no match for me. Surely, the inhabitants of a System World, a world supposedly integrated with this... this cosmic network of power, should be more powerful, more capable of defending themselves."

You possess a powerful mage class, relatively good gear for your level, and you have invested heavily in your magical skills, the first family you encountered, Kael, Elara, and Lyra, they were not combatants. Kael is a farmer, Elara a seamstress, and Lyra is, well, a child.

I can can access very basic system data on them and tell you that Kael was level 26 and Elara level 21, but their

levels were gained in non-combat professions. They had no combat skills, no magical abilities to defend themselves.

Like in your own world, Robert, many people depend on others for protection. In your world, it might be the police, the military. Here, it's the village guard, perhaps a local lord or a group of adventurers. These people were simply… unlucky.

Robert forced a sad smile, a bitter taste in his mouth. "It makes sense, in a horrible, twisted way," he mumbled, quickening his steps, pushing himself to move faster. The sounds of battle grew louder, drawing him towards the village center. At the next intersection, his heart sank. Another family. The scene was sickeningly familiar. The man, lying face down in the dirt, a skeletal warrior's broken sword still protruding from his back. The woman, a few feet away, her body contorted in a silent scream, her eyes wide and staring blankly at the sky.

Two small children huddled nearby, crying uncontrollably. Fury, raw and untamed, surged through Robert. He roared, a primal scream of rage and frustration, and unleashed a torrent of profanities, a stream of curses directed at the System, at the monsters, at the universe itself. He didn't

bother with strategy, with finesse. He simply attacked. He charged into the midst of the remaining skeletons, his sword a blur of silver, fueled by his righteous anger.

Bolts of energy flew from his fingertips, incinerating bone and sinew. He ignored the skeletal swipes, the minor cuts and bruises they inflicted, his focus narrowed to a single point: the goblin shaman, the leader, the source of this nightmare.

Steel met bone in a symphony of violence. Robert parried, thrust, and slashed, his movements driven by instinct and adrenaline. The goblin shrieked, its spells going wild, missing their target. Finally, with a desperate cry, Robert lunged, his sword piercing the goblin's chest. The creature

gurgled, its sickly green eyes fading to dull black, and collapsed. He turned his attention back to the remaining skeletons, his fury still burning hot.

He dispatched them with brutal efficiency, spells and sword working in perfect harmony, until silence once again descended upon the street. Only this time, the silence was broken by the sobs of the surviving children and the ragged breathing of the woman, who was still alive, though badly wounded. Rushing to the fallen man, Robert knelt beside him, desperately channeling his most potent healing spell. He focused all his will, all his

energy, into the incantation, pouring every ounce of his magical power into the attempt. But nothing happened. The man remained lifeless, his body cold and still.

I'm sorry, Robert, but you currently lack the power to resurrect the dead. That ability is far beyond your current capabilities

Despair, black and suffocating, crushed him. He sank to his knees, the weight of his failure pressing down on him like a physical burden. Tears welled up in his eyes, blurring his vision. He looked at the woman, her face pale and streaked with tears, her children clinging to her, their small bodies trembling. He choked out, "I'm so sorry. I... I tried. If I'd only moved faster, if I'd been stronger..." "Stranger, stop!" the woman's voice, though shaken and weak, held a surprising strength, a core of resilience that refused to be broken.

"This... this was not your fault. You saved me and my children. That's all that matters." She reached out and took her husband's lifeless hand, her grip tight with grief, her knuckles white. Taking a deep, shuddering breath,

Robert forced himself to stand, to regain some semblance of control. "Is there somewhere you can hide?" he asked, his voice rough with emotion. "Somewhere safe? A cellar? A reinforced room?"

He needed to get them to safety, to give them a chance to survive. "Yes," she said, her voice thick with emotion, her eyes distant, focused on some

unseen point beyond the immediate horror. "Our home... it's nearby. I'll take the children and... and wait there. Until this madness ends." She gave a weak, watery smile. "Thank you, stranger. Thank you for everything." With a final, heart-wrenching sob, she let go of her husband's hand, scooped up

her children, and disappeared into the maze of houses, her footsteps fading into the silence.

Robert stood alone, the weight of responsibility and grief settling on him like a shroud. He had saved some, but not all. He had arrived too late to

prevent the tragedy, to save the lives of those who had already fallen. It was a heavy burden to carry, a bitter taste of the realities of this new, terrifying world. But he knew he couldn't falter. He couldn't give in to despair. He had to keep moving. He had to help whoever else he could. With renewed determination, his jaw set, his eyes burning with a fierce resolve, he turned towards the town center, the heart of the battle yet to be fought, the sounds of combat growing louder with each step.Just as hope dwindled, an old man emerged from the village hall.

With a shattered glass orb, he summoned a blinding light. Robert pressed on, the urgency of the situation fueling his pace. He couldn't afford to waste time looting the bodies, the cries for help still ringing in his ears. He had to reach the village center, to find the remaining defenders, to offer whatever assistance he could. As he rounded the last house, the village center came into view, a scene of chaotic, desperate struggle.

A small, two-story building, likely the village hall, stood at the heart of the square. It was a simple structure, built of wood and stone, with a thatched roof and a small bell tower. Flanking the hall were two other buildings: a slightly larger structure that appeared to be an inn, its sign depicting a frothy mug of ale, and a general store, its windows boarded up, its door hanging open at a precarious angle. Before the hall, a fierce battle raged.

Five defenders – a mix of men and women, armed with swords, spears, and axes – fought valiantly against a horde of skeletal warriors and goblin shamans. They were clearly outnumbered, their movements desperate, their faces grim with determination and fear. A goblin shaman, its staff crackling with dark energy, unleashed a bolt of sickly green magic. The spell struck

one of the defenders, a young woman wielding a spear, sending her crashing to the ground, her body convulsing.

Seizing the opportunity, Robert charged into the fray, his sword already drawn, a battle cry tearing from his throat. He moved with a speed and ferocity born of desperation and rage, cutting down the nearest goblin with a swift, brutal strike. His sudden appearance caught the remaining goblins

off guard, their attention momentarily diverted from the beleaguered defenders.

This brief respite allowed the defenders to regroup, to pull their wounded comrade back towards the relative safety of the village hall. They formed a

defensive line, their backs to the building, their weapons raised in defiance. But the goblins, recovering from their initial surprise, pressed their attack, their numbers seemingly endless. Robert found himself in the thick of the fighting, dodging spells, parrying blows, his magic and sword working in concert.

He was acutely aware of his vulnerability, his protective spells barely holding against the onslaught of dark magic. Desperate, he began to channel a powerful nature spell, drawing upon the energy of the earth, of the surrounding forest. He could feel the power building within him, a tingling sensation spreading through his limbs. But before he could unleash the spell, reinforcements arrived – another wave of goblins, their numbers doubling the already overwhelming force. Hope flickered and threatened to die. Just as hope dwindled, an old man emerged from the village hall. With a shattered glass orb, he summoned a blinding light.


Blessing of the Orb of Sacrifice received.

All stats +10

Health +200 Mana recharged

Greater shield of Protection granted

30 seconds remaining

A surge of divine energy, a gift from the shattered Orb of Sacrifice, flooded Robert's being, imbuing him with an almost godlike power; his muscles

surged with newfound strength, his mind sharpened to a razor's edge, and his magical reserves replenished to overflowing. He became a whirlwind of destruction, a tempest of steel and searing magic, his sword a blur as he carved a path of righteous fury through the goblin ranks, each strike precise and lethal, his spells erupting with devastating force. The remaining skeletons, already hard-pressed by the revitalized defenders, crumbled

under the combined assault, their bony frames shattering into dust.

The tide had turned, the battle won in a breathtakingly swift and decisive counterattack. But the blessing was ephemeral, a fleeting gift; as quickly as it had ignited, the divine power receded, leaving Robert drained, his body trembling with exhaustion, his vision swimming. He stumbled, nearly collapsing under the sudden weight of his fatigue. A strong hand caught his arm, a kind defender – a woman with tired eyes and a determined set to her jaw – rushing to his aid.

"Careful, stranger," she said, her voice firm but gentle. "You pushed

yourself beyond your limits. You'll need time to recover." Robert, unable to muster a coherent response, simply nodded weakly, his gratitude overwhelming, and sheathed his sword with a shaking hand, the metal scraping against the scabbard. He leaned heavily on the defender, allowing her to guide him towards the relative safety and sanctuary of the village hall, his legs heavy, his mind reeling from the aftereffects of the divine intervention.


Level Up!


With an incredible show of Willpower Will Power +1


OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 26‌

Robert entered the crowded room, a scene of controlled chaos and palpable anxiety. Families, their faces etched with worry, clustered together, seeking comfort in numbers. The four defenders, recognizing him, quickly ushered him towards a smaller room at the back.

There, a young woman was frantically tending to a man lying prone on a makeshift bed. His body was a canvas of horrific wounds, deep gashes that seeped blood despite the crude bandages applied to them. "Dwalin's lost a significant amount of blood," the woman stated, her voice tight with concern and barely controlled desperation. "I've managed to staunch the bleeding for now, but without a proper healer, his chances are slim."

One of the defenders suggested, "We need to send someone to High Watch, immediately." Robert, however, stepped forward, his gaze fixed on the injured man with a determined intensity. "That won't be necessary. Let me try." The woman looked up, surprised, a flicker of hope mixed with

disbelief in her eyes. "You... you can heal?"

Robert nodded, a slight grimace acknowledging the effort it would require. "I know a little. I have a Tier 3 healing spell. Let's see if it's enough." As he spoke, he raised his hand, and a brilliant, almost blinding beam of light erupted forth, engulfing the wounded man. The light pulsed with a vibrant energy, throbbing rhythmically.

As it slowly faded, the horrific wounds began to visibly knit themselves

together, skin and muscle reforming before their astonished eyes. Dwalin's ragged breathing evened out, and a healthy flush of color returned to his

pale face. Robert, visibly drained, sank to his knees, his own breathing labored. "That... took more out of me than I expected."

The woman was speechless for a moment, her eyes wide with awe. "A Tier 3 healing spell? That's… that's beyond the capabilities of most healers in High Watch!" The man who had initially guided Robert into the hall approached, his voice a deep, rumbling baritone. “Greetings, stranger. My

name is Rhys. These are my companions: Kael, Moromir, and Kaelan. The man you healed is Dwalin. And you are…?”

Before Robert could respond, the young woman interjected, her voice filled with gratitude. “Thank you, sir, for saving him. My name is Calla.” Robert nodded, still catching his breath. “It’s a pleasure to meet you all. I’m Robert Williams. Once I’ve recovered a bit, I’ll check on anyone else who might need healing. But if there's an immediate, critical case, you can use this.”

He held out his rod of healing. Rhys explained, “Dwalin was the most severely injured here. But we still need to thoroughly search the village, for both survivors and any remaining goblin threats.” Robert nodded in understanding. “I encountered two families hiding in their homes on my way here. Sadly, one man didn't survive, and two other families were completely lost. The southern approach to the village seems clear, at least

for now.”

Rhys, his curiosity piqued, asked, "Robert, we are deeply grateful for your assistance, but what brings a man of your obvious abilities to such a small, remote village?" Robert hesitated for a moment. "Before I answer that, who was the elderly man wielding the glowing orb?" Calla answered, her voice laced with sorrow. "That was Elder Darian, my grandfather. He sacrificed

himself to protect us all."

Robert offered his condolences, his tone sincere. "I'm truly sorry for your loss. Losing family is never easy." He then turned back to Rhys. "As for why I'm here... the System sent me. I was *supposed* to be in a dungeon, but it appears plans changed." Kael's eyes widened in surprise. "You mean... you received a *System Quest* to come here?"

Robert nodded, a thoughtful expression on his face. "I suppose so. I must have missed the notification in all the chaos. But it seems my task was to

save your village." Rhys, still processing this revelation, raised an eyebrow. "Why our village? And why send someone of *your* level? I'm level 30, and even *I* struggled to hold them off." Robert mentally contacted his AI. "Hal, how much should I reveal to them?"

They're part of the System. They know to stay out of its way, but they also seem to have a good heart. I believe you can confide in them.

After a brief, internal consultation, Robert's expression turned serious. "I'm not from this universe," he stated, his voice firm and steady. "My home

universe isn't integrated into the System yet. I've been selected as a

Forerunner, part of the test to potentially bring the System to my world. I was undergoing training in a designated dungeon when the System abruptly redirected me here."

Rhys's jaw dropped, his eyes wide with astonishment. "You're a

Forerunner? That's... incredible. So, in essence, the System used our village, our crisis, as a training exercise for you? Well, I suppose it worked out in

our favor, in the end." Robert, curious about the context of the attack, asked, “Is this kind of thing – these goblin attacks – a common occurrence around here?”

Rhys shook his head, a grim expression settling on his face. “No, absolutely not. This is unprecedented. We have no idea where this goblin horde

originated.” The next several hours were a somber blur of activity. Robert, having replenished his mana reserves, diligently used his healing magic to assist the injured villagers, while others worked tirelessly to bury the dead.

A heavy silence, punctuated by quiet sobs and the rhythmic clang of shovels, descended upon the village as the sun began to set. The villagers had survived, and there would be a tomorrow, however hard that tomorrow would be. Later that evening, as they gathered in the relative safety of the inn, a young girl, appearing to be around the same age as Robert's own

daughter, approached their table.

Her eyes were red-rimmed and swollen from crying, her face a mask of grief. “What am I supposed to do now?” she asked, her voice a trembling whisper. Calla, ever compassionate, responded gently, “Elara, I’m so, so sorry for your loss. Do you have any relatives nearby, anyone you could go

to?” Elara shook her head, fresh tears streaming down her cheeks. “Mommy never talked about any other family. I… I should have been home, but I was enjoying the day and I took my time getting back.”

Robert exchanged a worried look with Rhys, who quietly explained,

“Elara’s family was one of the ones you found, Robert. She’s completely

alone now.” Elara’s quiet sobs intensified. “I have no one,” she choked out. “I’m too young to take care of myself.” Robert turned back to Rhys, a sense of urgency growing within him. “She’s too young to access the System,

correct? No leveling, no skills?” Rhys nodded grimly. “Not until she reaches fifteen.”

“And the village?” Robert asked, his hope dwindling with each passing moment. “Can any of the families here take her in?” Rhys shook his head, a heavy sigh escaping his lips. “The goblins utterly devastated our fields.

We’re facing a harsh winter; we'll be struggling just to survive. Some families might even be forced to leave.” “So, what options does she have?” Robert pressed, a hint of desperation creeping into his voice.

"I'll have someone escort her to High Watch and present her to the mayor.

He'll either try to find a family willing to adopt her, or, more likely, he'll

place her on a caravan heading to a larger city," Rhys replied. "The problem is, that transport costs a significant amount. And since she has no funds, she'll be indentured to the caravan master until she can work off the debt."

Robert’s eyes widened in alarm. “Wait, you mean if no one takes her in, she’ll essentially be sold into a form of servitude?” Rhys nodded, his tone apologetic. “It’s not precisely slavery. It’s a work bond. She’ll be obligated to work for the caravan master until she repays the cost of her transport and upkeep.”

“And how much would this transport cost?” Robert asked, his voice tight with barely suppressed anger. “Five or six gold pieces, I’d estimate,” Rhys replied. “Six gold *to* ride in the back of a wagon?” Robert exclaimed, incredulous. “Are these wagons constructed from dragon bone?” Rhys sighed, understanding Robert’s outrage.

“The nearest large city from High Watch is about a month’s journey away. The cost covers food, security along the way, and, of course, a profit margin for the caravan master. It’s not an ideal system, but it’s the established

norm.”

There is another option

"Absolutely not, Hal. Don't even suggest it," Robert snapped, his voice sharp with immediate refusal. His sudden outburst startled those around him. Calla, her face etched with confusion, looked around the room, then back at Robert. "Who is Hal? Is someone else here?" Robert sighed, realizing he needed to provide some context. "My apologies. Hal is a System AI – an Artificial Intelligence – assigned to me as part of my

Forerunner training," he explained.

Calla's brow furrowed further. "An AI? What exactly *is* that?" "Think of it as a miniature, personalized System," Robert elaborated, trying to simplify the complex concept. "It's a construct, a helper, designed to

provide me with information and assist me in navigating the System's intricacies."

Rhys, intrigued by this new information, leaned forward. "So, you have a direct, personal link to the System itself?" Robert shook his head. "Not precisely. Hal *isn't* the System. He's an artificial being, a construct

*created* by the System. He acts as an intermediary, offering guidance and support, but he's not the System itself."

Calla, still trying to grasp the concept, interjected, "Alright, I'm not sure I entirely understand all of that, but I won't dwell on it. So, what was it that Hal said that upset you so much?" Robert's expression darkened, his voice dropping to a near whisper. "He presented me with another option regarding Elara's situation... and I *really* don't like the implications."

I did not say it was a good option, only that there was

another one. Normally I'm not allowed to tell you about other users, but I'm allowed to make an exception. Ask Elara about her Trait.

"What about her Trait?" Robert inquired, his voice a low murmur, laced with a curiosity that belied the seriousness of the situation. Elara visibly flinched, her face paling, and her eyes darted around the room nervously, as if searching for an escape. "No one knows about that," she whispered, her

voice barely audible. "Not even Mamma and Pappa knew." Rhys, with his

characteristic gentle demeanor, offered a reassuring smile. "It's alright, child. You're safe here. No one present will judge you, no matter what it is." Elara, still hesitant, finally confessed, her voice a mere breath, "It's called 'Born in Power'." Calla, now deeply intrigued, leaned forward, her voice soft and encouraging. "Can you... can you read us the official System description, Elara?"

Elara hesitated for a moment longer, gathering her courage, then began to recite the description in a quiet, almost trembling voice:

'This rare and powerful trait imbues its bearer with an extraordinary affinity for magic. Those blessed with this trait possess the potential to unlock and master not just one, but four distinct spheres of magic, offering unparalleled versatility and power. Furthermore, this trait grants a significant advantage in the pursuit of higher-tier classes,

increasing the likelihood of attaining a more potent and prestigious class.'

A profound silence descended upon the small group gathered at the table as the full weight of Elara's revelation sank in. The implications were staggering. Rhys was the first to break the silence, his voice grave and filled with a newfound urgency. "No one, absolutely no one, can know about this, Elara. If word of this Trait gets out, every noble house in the kingdom, every power-hungry lord and lady, will be clamoring for you. They'll force you to take binding oaths, perhaps even coerce you into a strategic marriage, all to exploit your potential for their own selfish gain."

Calla, her brow furrowed with worry and a sense of helplessness, spoke next. "But what can we do? We're simple farmers, Rhys. We have no

knowledge of the kingdom's elite, no understanding of their schemes and machinations." Robert, feeling the weight of responsibility pressing down on him, turned inward, mentally addressing his AI companion. "Hal," he thought urgently, "what are you suggesting? What's the other option you mentioned?"

Simple. You take her with you and train her yourself.

Robert's mind raced. "Are you crazy? First, how could I train her? I'm still learning myself. Second, how could I take her? And third, what happens when my time here is up and I'm sent to another world?"

This is why the System sent you here: to give her a chance. The training you're receiving is preparing you, but you're not the only one it's looking after. Elara has a future the System is invested in. If you agree to take her, the System will send her with you. As for your time on Earth, she goes with you.

You'll be her teacher and she'll be your student until she's ready to stand on her own.

Robert hesitated. "I'm barely able to protect myself. How can I protect a child?"

You're not considering your potential power. You have a

Mythical class, Robert. You'll likely gain at least a Legendary profession and second class, possibly even Mythical. With that kind of power, few will pose a threat.

Robert countered, "There must be more powerful beings out there."

There are, but they're not common. Most beings you'll

encounter will be ordinary users with common or uncommon classes. Many will outlevel you, but levels aren't the deciding factor.

Robert pressed, "What are you getting at?"

Let's ignore class abilities for a moment and focus on stats. As a Tier G Human, your average stats are 10 each, totaling 70 at level 10. Common classes grant 3 stat points per level, so at level 20, an average user would have 100 points. Mythical classes, however, grant 10 points per level, totaling 170 at level 20.

At level 20 you gain a profession and a common profession grants 2 points per level, so at level 50, a common user

would have around 250 points. A Legendary profession grants 6 points, and a Mythical grants 7. So, at level 50, you could have 640 or 670 points. Those extra points translate to thousands of extra mana, health, strength, and a longer lifespan. Add in the skill point advantage of Mythical classes, and you're significantly more powerful.

After that you put back in Class Abilities and a high-tier class dominates a common or uncommon class.

Robert was stunned. "It sounds like the System is setting me up to be some kind of overlord."

Your actions determine your destiny. You could choose a less powerful path. The System offers opportunities, but

how you seize them is up to you. Taking Elara is a chance to make a difference, but it's your choice.

Robert sighed. "I know I can't leave her. I'd never forgive myself."

The System respects your decision. If you choose not to, you'll still be rewarded, but differently.

"There really isn't a choice and you know it. I think you know me well enough to know that I'd not leave her here, knowing bad things will probably happen to her." Robert snapped.

Again the choice to have personal honor is your choice, the System isn't forcing it on you.

Robert chuckled bitterly. "So, the System's a bit of an ass, huh?"

The System knows your feelings and honestly doesn't care.

Robert grinned. "A real ass, then."

"Robert!" a voice called out, sharp and insistent, pulling him from his internal conversation. "What?" Robert asked, blinking, momentarily disoriented. "You were completely zoned out, ignoring us. We asked for

your thoughts on the situation, and you didn't respond," Calla chided gently. "Oh, my apologies. I was just conferring with Hal," Robert explained, then, realizing that might not be sufficient, added, "We were discussing Elara's predicament."

Rhys leaned forward, his interest piqued. "And? What did you discuss?" Robert took a deep breath, preparing to reveal the potentially life-altering information. "It seems the System has other plans for Elara... and, by extension, for me. It appears the real reason I was sent here might not have been to save the village, but to take Elara with me and become her teacher, to train her in the ways of magic."


Hidden Quest Unlocked

Rhys smiled, "Well, you did save our village. I guess this is a bonus."


Quest Complete!

Robert chuckled as a treasure chest materialized on the table. "By the gods, what just happened?" Moromir exclaimed. "Seems the System didn't

consider my village-saving quest complete until you confirmed it," Robert explained. "So, this chest is my reward. Let's see what your village is worth."


Dungeon run complete: Rare chest awarded Chest contains:

One skill book (Alchemy) Five gold coins

One unlocked skill tokens One Rare Shop Token

Items added to user inventory. Thank you for visiting The Training Dungeon!

"A skill book!" Moromir exclaimed, his voice filled with awe and a touch of envy. "I've never even *seen* a skill book in person before. And Alchemy, no less? That's got to be worth a king's ransom – at least 50 gold pieces, if not significantly more. What a magnificent reward!" The treasure chest, having dispensed its bounty, promptly vanished, leaving no trace of the portal that had delivered it.

Robert, taking note of this, mused aloud, "Well, it seems there's no going back home until we resolve Elara's situation. The System is certainly making its intentions clear." "That decision isn't yours to make, Robert,"

Calla pointed out gently, reminding him of the gravity of the situation. "Oh, I'm fully aware of that," Robert replied quickly, his gaze shifting to Elara.

"I was merely thinking aloud. Elara," he continued, addressing the young girl directly, "the System has presented you with a choice, a significant fork in the road of your life. You can remain here, and I will provide the necessary funds – the gold – to send you to a larger city, where you can attempt to forge your own path. Alternatively, you can choose to come with me. I will do everything in my power to train you, to help you become a powerful mage, to unlock the potential that lies within you."

Elara, her voice barely above a whisper, summarized her options, highlighting the inherent risks in each. "So, my choices are to stay here, potentially ending up under the control of a family I might despise, or to go with you, a man I barely know, into the complete unknown." Robert nodded, acknowledging the stark reality of her dilemma. "I have a wife and three children back home."

"You would live with us for the next five months, after which we'll be transported to a random world, a destination unknown even to me. This is my destiny as a Forerunner. I'm telling you this upfront because I have absolutely no control over where we'll end up. It's entirely possible that you might be safer, even with a family you dislike, than venturing into the

absolute unknown with me."

Just then, Elara gasped, her eyes widening in surprise. "I... I just received a quest! I've never gotten a quest notification before." "It's titled 'Walk Your Path'," Elara continued, reading from the newly appeared quest information,

her voice tinged with confusion. "And it presents me with two options:

either go with you, Robert, or... not. The description says, 'Go with Robert and gain a teacher and protector, or stay and gain a ???'"

"What do those question marks signify?" Robert chuckled wryly. "That, Elara, signifies two things. First, that particular path leads to a completely uncertain future, a roll of the dice with unknown consequences. And second," he added with a touch of sarcasm, "it signifies that the System can be remarkably unhelpful, even cruel. But to put it plainly, the System has given you two paths: one with a clearly defined, positive outcome, and the other shrouded in complete mystery."

"Who in their right mind would choose the unknown, especially given your circumstances? The System, while appearing to offer a choice, has essentially steered you towards one." Calla, understanding the manipulation, agreed, "You're absolutely right. That was a decidedly unfair tactic." Robert smiled at Calla in acknowledgement, then turned back to Elara, his expression softening.

"I'm sorry to pressure you, Elara, but a decision needs to be made. The System is waiting." Elara sighed, a hint of resignation in her voice. "I

suppose there really isn't much of a choice, is there?" With that, she made her selection.


Hidden Quest Complete!


Level Up!

"My quest is complete!" Elara exclaimed, her voice a mixture of surprise and relief. "The reward is listed as 'a new teacher' – that's you, Master Robert – and... something else. But this second part is locked, inaccessible until I reach fifteen."

Robert smiled, acknowledging the System's often cryptic ways. "That's excellent news, Elara. Now, we should prepare to leave soon. Is there anything you need to retrieve from your home? Any personal belongings

you'd like to take with you?" "There isn't much," Elara replied, "but I would like to gather a few family mementos, things that remind me of them. May I go home to pack?" "Of course," Robert agreed. Calla, ever supportive, immediately offered, "I'll go with you, Elara, to help you carry things." The two of them then departed, leaving Robert alone with the village defenders.

Robert turned to Rhys, his mind already shifting to practical matters. "Regarding your village's immediate needs," he began, "do you have enough resources to purchase sufficient food from High Watch to sustain yourselves until the next harvest? It's crucial that you have enough provisions." Rhys sighed, a worried expression clouding his face.

"We could buy enough food, theoretically, but the cost would be substantial. We have fifteen families remaining, and each family would require approximately fifty silver pieces to cover their basic food needs. Then there's the added expense of transportation, which would likely be another fifty silver. In total, we're looking at around eight gold pieces." He shook his head dejectedly. "I honestly doubt we can gather more than two or three gold, even if we pool all our remaining resources."

"That won't be a problem," Robert stated calmly, reaching into his inventory. "Take the five gold pieces from the reward chest, and I'll add another three hundred silver to that. Consider it a contribution to the

village's recovery. Furthermore, I'm leaving my Healing Rod with you, just in case any further medical needs arise." Rhys was visibly stunned by Robert's generosity. "That's... that's far too much, Robert. You've already risked your life to save our village. We can't possibly accept such a significant donation." Robert waved off his concerns. "It's merely money, Rhys. I can always acquire more. It's of little consequence to me." Rhys persisted, "But the rod... that Healing Rod is a valuable artifact, worth several gold pieces on its own. We can't accept that either." Robert smiled reassuringly.

"The rod holds little value to me, personally. I've crafted several others similar to it. I can easily replace it." Rhys's eyes widened in surprise.

"Wait... you mean to say you're an enchanter?" Robert nodded modestly. "It's not as difficult as you might think. In fact, if you have any suitable oak

rods available, I could create a few more for you, or perhaps something else entirely, if you have a specific need."

If you're serious about enchanting, you should take the skill.

While your magic is powerful, the skill would let you stack your abilities and create even more potent items. Plus, you might be offered Enchanting as a profession, which would take your skills to the next level.

Robert swiftly scanned his available skill list, locating the "Enchanting" skill, and without a moment's hesitation, selected and acquired it. Almost immediately, the villagers presented him with a collection of plain oak rods and several sturdy staves. He began working on the rods first, meticulously imbuing two of them with the Healing spell. The newly acquired Enchanting skill, synergizing seamlessly with his existing magical knowledge, allowed him to enhance the rods far beyond their original capabilities, significantly increasing both their charge capacity and the potency of their healing effect.

Turning his attention to the staves, Robert opted for different enchantments, carefully selecting "Nature's Wrath" for one and "Earth Bind" for the other, tailoring each staff to a specific tactical purpose. Just as he completed the final enchantment, Elara reappeared, carrying several bags filled with her belongings. Robert, ever practical, took the bags and efficiently stored them within his inventory.

"Are you prepared, Elara?" he asked, his voice gentle but firm. "Keep in mind, we may never return to this village, so this is your opportunity to say your farewells." Elara, understanding the gravity of the moment, embraced each of the villagers in turn, offering heartfelt goodbyes. Once finished, she stood resolutely beside Robert.

"I'm ready," she declared. No sooner had the words left her lips than a shimmering portal materialized before them. Robert, in turn, shook hands with each of the remaining villagers, offering his thanks and well wishes, and then, with Elara by his side, stepped through the gateway, leaving the ravaged village behind.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 27‌

Upon stepping through the portal with Elara, Robert was met with a flurry of greetings from his family. "Robert! You're back!" Sara exclaimed, her voice a mix of relief and concern. "That felt like an eternity... And who is this young girl with you?" Before Robert could answer, Elara whispered, "Master, she's speaking strangely."

Robert smiled, "It's English, our language. I'll use my teaching skill to share it with you." Meanwhile, Stacey, Robert's daughter, piped up, "Daddy, you sound funny too! Are you speaking Pig Latin?" Robert chuckled, "No, princess. I'm speaking System Common, a primary language on System Worlds." Stacey, ever the blunt child, declared, "It sounds silly."

"Elara thinks English sounds silly too. I guess you two have something in common." Robert smiled in agreement, then turned to his wife. "Elara?" Sara questioned, prompting Robert to explain, "It's a long story. Let's sit down. I'll share English with Elara, and then I'll tell you everything." He placed his hand on Elara's head, activating his teaching skill.

"Master, it's asking if I want to learn English as a Language subskill at level

2. Is that okay?" Elara inquired. Robert affirmed, "Yes, Elara. Accept the skill." Once Elara had acquired English, Robert began his recounting of the events, describing the village, the battles, the families he couldn't save, and the System's ultimate offer to make him Elara's teacher.

The weight of the experience settled upon him as he spoke, and Sara, sensing his sorrow, moved to offer comfort. With the immediate tasks assigned – John moving items to make room for Elara and Stacey helping her unpack – everyone dispersed, leaving Robert and Sara alone in their office. Sara began, "Robert, what the System did, sending you there, was wrong. You didn't deserve that."

Robert, however, had come to a different understanding. "I don't believe it was malicious," he replied. "The attack was going to happen regardless. The System simply seized an opportunity, recognizing both my potential and

Elara's. I believe it has a plan for us." Sara, understandably skeptical, questioned, "What grand plans could the System possibly have for a child?"

Robert smiled. "I don't think it sees age in the same way we do. Consider this: I'm 51, hardly the typical age to embark on a new adventure." Sara paused, studying his face intently. "Hon, you don't look 51. You look more like you're in your early 40s." Intrigued, Robert examined his reflection in the bathroom mirror and returned, nodding.

"It's the stat changes. I put points into Constitution, pushing it above 20. I guess a side effect, along with increased longevity, is a more youthful appearance." Sara admitted, "I don't mind a younger you, but if this continues, the neighbors will start to notice. What happens when you look like you're in your thirties, or even twenties again?" Robert clarified, "It's too late to reverse the aging that dramatically. Hal said I won't appear

younger than my mid-thirties."

Sara retorted, "That's not funny, hon. People will notice." Robert chuckled, accepting the inevitability. "We knew this would happen eventually. And I think, in a few more levels, I'll be beyond anyone's reach here. I'll ensure you and the kids are protected." Later that evening, Robert, fulfilling his

role as Elara's master, sat with her in his office.

"Elara, you have the potential to learn four spheres of magic. Do you have any preferences?" He handed her a list of spheres he was familiar with, along with their associated spells. Elara studied the list, then looked up at him. "What do you think I should learn, Master?" Robert smiled gently. "That's not the question, Elara. The question is, what do you want to learn?"

"This is your future; these four spheres are your foundation. Take your time, but don't delay too long." After a moment of contemplation, Elara spoke. "I want to be able to protect others, to fight if necessary, and to heal the injured. Is that possible?" "Absolutely," Robert replied, pleased with her thoughtful response.

"Healing covers the healing aspect, and many elemental spheres, like Air, can be used for both protection and attack. Let's consider Healing, Air, and Light. Those three would fulfill your goals." He began to write on a sheet of

paper. "Now, you have one more sphere to choose. This one is for fun. What interests you?" Elara was confused. "Why for fun? Shouldn't I choose something practical?"

Robert explained, "Elara, I'm already more powerful than you, and I'll likely always have an advantage due to my experience. What's most important is that you're happy and capable. You've already selected three practical spheres. This last one is entirely yours to enjoy." He continued, "There are over 30 spheres of magic, and you can choose any one. I can unlock an extra sphere, but I won't have any pre-learned spells in it."

"However, the System often provides them, either through quests or the shop." Elara pondered for a moment, then her face brightened. "Mommy once told me stories about a mage who could create amazing illusions. I'd like to learn something like that." "Illusion, huh? That's an excellent choice," Robert said, genuinely impressed. "It could be useful for both of us. We can learn it together."

"Yes, please!" Elara exclaimed, her eyes shining with excitement. With that settled, Robert used his last skill point to unlock the Illusion sphere and shared it with Elara. "I got a feat!" Elara exclaimed, surprised. "It's called

Polymathic Prodigy. It gives me a 10% bonus to learning spells from my four spheres and a 5% bonus to skill experience in those spheres."

Robert chuckled. "That's a fantastic bonus. What level did you unlock the spheres at?" "Tier 1, level 9," Elara replied. "Good. With that bonus, we should be able to get three of those spheres to Tier 2 before we leave in five months. That will be a significant advantage." Finally, fulfilling the initial steps of his commitment as her teacher, Robert pulled out his Tier 1 spellbook and handed it to Elara.

“This book contains every Tier 1 spell for Air, Healing, and Light. Look through it and pick two spells from each school. I’ll review your choices

tomorrow. If I approve, you can start studying them. I’m not sure how that will work without full System access, though.”

She can study them fine, she just doesn't have access to her System Spellbook yet, but she can add spells to it, she

just cannot view it or use them yet.

"The good news," Robert said to Elara, "is that you can begin studying and learning spells. The only limitation is that your System Spellbook isn't

accessible yet. You'll gain full access when you turn fifteen." Elara checked her status screen. "According to my status, I have fourteen Earth days remaining until my fifteenth birthday," she confirmed.

"Perfect," Robert replied, a smile spreading across his face. "That gives us ample time to master a few dozen spells. And then the real fun begins." The following morning, Elara sat with Robert, indicating the spells she had selected. He was surprised to see she had chosen three healing spells and

three defensive ones, all centered around protection and support.

"Why these six?" Robert asked, genuinely curious about her reasoning.

"Father always said that the best defense is a strong defense," Elara replied, a hint of melancholy coloring her voice. "I want to follow his teachings." Robert nodded, understanding her grief and the depth of her respect. "Those are the words of a wise man," he said softly.

"You’ve honored him well with your choices. These six are an excellent foundation. Dedicate today and tomorrow to studying them. And remember, Elara, it's alright to grieve. If you ever need to talk, Sara and I are here, without judgment." Over the next few days, Elara diligently learned her first six spells, then selected another six, this time all focused on healing.

Robert didn't push her towards offensive magic, understanding her current priorities. He knew that in time, she would likely choose some offensive spells, but for now, there was no rush. He suspected she would soon surpass his own healing abilities, which he welcomed. He had a strong feeling the System would eventually require Elara to accompany him on dungeon runs, and he wanted her to be able to protect herself, and if needed, take over the healing role, so he can focus on their group defence and attack.

While Elara studied, Robert dedicated his free time to crafting items to sell to the System Shop, determined to accumulate enough funds to purchase

the spellbooks he needed. Five days after returning with Elara, it was time

for another dungeon run. As he stood before the shimmering portal, he bid his family farewell, instructing Elara to continue her studies.

"Robert, I'm scared," Elara confessed, her voice trembling. "What if it's like last time? What if it's too dangerous?" Robert placed a reassuring hand on

her shoulder. "One thing I've learned about the System," he said, his voice calm and steady, "is that it's firm but fair. I'll be challenged, certainly, but never by something I can't overcome with enough effort." With those reassuring words, he stepped through the portal.

Welcome, adventurer. You have entered Dungeon 7883667HG8776DE985762763FF7-1, currently known as The Training Dungeon. You are now on the Seventh Floor.

Wasting no time Robert went to the store and sold off all of the items he had crafted, 85 Rods of healing, 35 cloaks, and 10 staves, which earned him 138 gold coins. Moving to the items for sell he pulled up the list:
