"Hal, why is the Gravity book so much more expensive than the other Tier 1 books?" Robert asked.

Because Gravity is a rare Sphere of magic, one not many people learn. Because it's a rare book it commands a higher price.

Robert shook his head, purchased all the books, and exited the room. As soon as he stepped out, he found himself in a dense forest.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 28‌

The oppressive heat of the afternoon sun beat down on Robert's brow, each ray a tangible weight. He found himself, not in the expected confines of a structured dungeon, but amidst the vibrant chaos of a primeval forest, teeming with life both beautiful and deadly. The air hummed with the incessant buzz of insects, the chirping of unseen birds, and the rustling of leaves under the weight of hidden creatures.

Towering trees, their gnarled branches reaching skyward like the arms of ancient giants, cast long, dancing shadows that played tricks on the eye. The very air seemed to vibrate with a primal energy, a constant reminder that he was a stranger in a land ruled by tooth and claw. Every rustle of leaves, every snap of a twig underfoot, sent a jolt of adrenaline through him, a primal instinct honed by the constant threat of unseen dangers.

The wind, a fickle and capricious force, whispered through the leaves, carrying with it the scent of pine, damp earth, and something else... something wild and untamed. The branches of the ancient trees groaned and creaked under the wind's unseen hand, a chorus of mournful sounds that echoed through the silent forest.

His first encounter, a jarring reminder of this world's brutal reality, came swiftly. Three boars, far larger and more ferocious than any he had encountered in his hunting trips with his father back on Earth, charged out of the undergrowth, their tusks gleaming menacingly in the dappled sunlight. Their eyes, small and beady, were filled with a savage hunger.

Instinct, honed by his recent trials, took over.

Reacting instantly, Robert channeled his mana, weaving a shimmering wall of water before the charging beasts. The Water Wall spell, born of his newly acquired knowledge, erupted from the ground, a solid barrier of churning, swirling water. The boars, caught completely by surprise, slammed into the unexpected obstacle, their momentum broken, their formation scattered.

The sudden impact sent spray flying, momentarily obscuring the scene.

Seizing the opportunity, Robert quickly focused his will, shaping another spell. An Earth Bullet, a concentrated sphere of solidified earth, materialized in his hand. He hurled it with all his might, aiming for the head of a lone boar, momentarily separated from its companions. The projectile

flew true, guided by his intent, striking the boar directly in the eye.

It was a lucky shot, a testament to his growing skill and a desperate prayer answered. The force of the impact was devastating, penetrating the skull and killing the beast instantly. It collapsed in a heap, its lifeless eyes staring blankly at the sky. But there was no time for celebration, no time for reflection.

The remaining two boars, enraged by the death of their companion, regained their footing and charged again, their snorts of fury echoing through the trees. Robert, drawing his sword, met their attack head-on. He moved with a fluid grace, a deadly dance of parry and thrust, his blade flashing in the sunlight. He ducked under a wild swing, the boar's tusk narrowly missing his head, and riposted with a swift, precise thrust, his sword piercing the beast's thick hide.

The boar squealed in pain, but continued its attack, its rage undiminished. The battle was a whirlwind of motion, a desperate struggle for survival.

Finally, with a combination of skillful swordsmanship and well-timed spells, Robert managed to bring down the remaining boars, their bodies joining their fallen comrade on the forest floor.

He stood there, panting, his chest heaving, his muscles aching. Sweat dripped from his brow, mingling with the blood and dirt that stained his clothes. He looked around, his senses on high alert, ensuring that no other predators were lurking nearby, drawn by the sounds of the fight. Satisfied that he was, for the moment, alone, he knelt beside the fallen boars and began the grim task of looting their carcasses.

He recovered a single silver coin, surprisingly well-preserved, a pelt of

coarse boar skin, and roughly five pounds of boar meat from each animal. The meat, though raw, represented a valuable source of sustenance in this unforgiving environment. He stored the spoils in his inventory, a space

outside of normal reality, accessible only to him.

Continuing his trek deeper into the forest, Robert encountered his next adversary: a large, feline predator, resembling an oversized bobcat, its eyes glowing with a predatory intelligence. It moved with a sinuous grace, its muscles rippling beneath its sleek fur. Reacting quickly, Robert cast an Air Bullet, a concentrated blast of compressed air, striking the cat and inflicting minor damage, more of an annoyance than a serious wound.

The creature hissed, its fur bristling, and launched itself into the branches of a nearby tree, disappearing from sight. What followed was a tense, drawn- out game of cat and mouse, a deadly dance played out amidst the towering trees and dense undergrowth. Robert would strike at the cat with spells and sword, only to have it vanish into the canopy, its movements swift and silent.

Then, a moment later, it would reappear, attacking from a different angle, its claws extended, its teeth bared. This frustrating pattern continued for several minutes, testing Robert's patience and his reflexes. He realized that he needed to change his tactics. He couldn't afford to waste his mana on

ineffective attacks. Deciding on a new approach, Robert channeled his energy into a Minor Movement spell, enhancing his speed and agility.

He felt a surge of power, his muscles responding with newfound quickness. With his enhanced speed, he anticipated the cat's next attack, dodging its claws with ease. As the cat landed, momentarily vulnerable, Robert seized the opportunity. He cast Earth Bind, a spell that caused the very earth beneath the cat's paws to solidify, trapping it in place.

The creature struggled, its powerful muscles straining against the magical restraints, but it was held fast. With the cat immobilized, Robert unleashed a barrage of Earth Bullet spells, each projectile striking with unerring accuracy. The cat roared in pain and defiance, its struggles weakening with each impact.

Finally, with a final, shuddering breath, it succumbed, its body slumping to the ground. Robert approached cautiously, his sword still at the ready, and confirmed that the creature was dead. He looted the carcass, retrieving two silver coins and a surprisingly soft and well-preserved pelt.

The next encounter brought a renewed sense of danger. A group of five boars, even larger than the first, emerged from the thick undergrowth, their snorting and grunting a clear sign of their aggressive intent. Robert knew that a direct confrontation with such a large group would be suicidal. He needed to use his wits, to leverage the environment to his advantage.

He quickly scanned his surroundings, his eyes searching for any tactical advantage. He spotted a narrow passage between two ancient, towering trees, their trunks thick and gnarled, their roots intertwined like the limbs of embracing giants. It was a natural chokepoint, a perfect place to funnel the boars' charge.

He lured the boars towards the passage, taunting them with shouts and small, harmless spells. The enraged beasts, driven by instinct and fury,

charged towards him, their hooves pounding the earth. As they approached the narrow passage, Robert cast Wall of Earth, a solid barrier of rock and soil erupting from the ground, blocking their path.

The boars, unable to stop their momentum, slammed into the wall with a resounding thud, their charge halted abruptly. Confused and disoriented, they milled about, trapped in the confined space. Robert, taking advantage of their predicament, moved with swift precision. He used his sword, now a familiar extension of his arm, to dispatch the boars one by one, his movements efficient and deadly.

The narrow passage prevented them from flanking him, forcing them to face him head-on, a fatal disadvantage. After the brutal, close-quarters

battle, Robert stood amidst the carnage, his breath coming in ragged gasps. He looted the boars, collecting five silver coins, five pelts of boar skin, and a substantial twenty-five pounds of boar meat.

The weight in his inventory was growing, a testament to his hard-won victories, but also a reminder of the constant struggle for survival. He pressed on, his senses heightened, his body weary but his spirit unbroken. He soon encountered another formidable opponent: a large panther, its fur a deep, velvety black, absorbing the light, making it appear almost spectral in the dappled shade of the forest.

The panther moved with an unnerving silence, a predator perfectly adapted to its environment. It attacked with incredible speed and agility, its claws raking, its teeth snapping, a whirlwind of deadly grace. Robert, however, was no longer the naive newcomer he had been just hours before. He had learned, adapted, and grown stronger with each encounter.

He dodged the panther's initial attacks, his movements fluid and practiced, and countered with spells and sword strokes of his own. The battle was a

fierce exchange, a dance of death played out under the watchful eyes of the ancient trees. Finally, with a well-aimed Earth Bullet, striking the panther in a vulnerable spot, Robert managed to bring the beast down.

He looted the carcass, recovering three silver coins and a valuable panther pelt, its fur smooth and luxurious to the touch. As the day wore on, the wilderness seemed to test Robert with increasing fervor, throwing a gauntlet of fierce creatures his way, as if determined to break his spirit.

He found himself locked in combat with a snarling pack of wolves, their eyes gleaming with predatory hunger, their coordinated attacks forcing him to rely on his agility and quick thinking. Later, the piercing shriek and razor talons of a giant eagle, its shadow huge and imposing against the sky, forced him to duck and weave. And finally, the very earth trembled beneath the charge of a monstrous bear, a behemoth of muscle and fury, its roar a deafening challenge.

Each encounter was a brutal trial, pushing his skills, his endurance, and his magical reserves to their absolute limits. But with every foe vanquished, Robert's resolve hardened, his determination solidifying into an unbreakable will to survive. He was a solitary figure, pitted against the untamed wilds, refusing to yield, refusing to be broken.

After the final, exhausting fight with the bear, Robert found himself in a small, sun-drenched clearing, a rare patch of open space in the dense forest. He was utterly exhausted, his body bruised and battered, his muscles screaming in protest, his mana reserves nearly depleted. But he was victorious. He had faced the challenges of the wilderness, and he had prevailed.

He sank to the ground, leaning against a smooth, sun-warmed rock, and allowed himself a moment of respite. He closed his eyes, listening to the sounds of the forest, no longer feeling quite so threatened. He looked at the passing clouds, the endless blue above, the world seemed to have changed. He knew that his journey was far from over, that countless dangers still lay ahead, but he felt a sense of quiet confidence.

A certainty that he was ready for whatever challenges awaited him. After resting for a short while, allowing his body to recover and his mana to slowly replenish, Robert was jolted back to alertness by the sound of a distant, guttural growl. It was a low, menacing rumble that resonated through the trees, a clear indication that his respite was over.

The forest was not yet done with him. He knew that there were still many dangers lurking in the shadows, waiting for an opportunity to strike. He

rose to his feet, his muscles stiff and sore, but his resolve firm. He strapped on his sword, the familiar weight comforting, and set off once more, his senses on high alert, ready to face whatever came his way.

His next encounter, a grim reminder of the constant threat, was with a group of three boars, similar to the ones he had faced earlier. He dispatched them with a practiced efficiency, a combination of swordplay and well-aimed spells. He looted the carcasses, collecting the usual spoils: three silver coins, three pelts of boar skin, and fifteen pounds of boar meat.

Next, he encountered a large lynx, its fur a mottled pattern of browns and grays, blending seamlessly with the dappled shadows of the forest floor.

The lynx was a formidable opponent, quick and agile, its claws sharp and deadly. But Robert, honed by his previous battles, was able to anticipate its movements, to parry its attacks, and to counter with a series of well-placed Earth Bullets.

The lynx fell, its sleek body collapsing in a heap. He looted the carcass, gaining two silver coins and a valuable lynx pelt, its fur soft and luxurious. As the day wore on, and the sun began its slow descent towards the horizon, painting the sky with hues of orange and purple, the forest became a relentless arena, a proving ground that tested Robert at every turn.

He battled his way through a gauntlet of wild beasts, each encounter a desperate, life-or-death struggle. Wolves with eyes like burning coals, their howls echoing through the trees; bears of monstrous size, their roars shaking the very ground he stood on; and sleek panthers that moved like shadows through the undergrowth – all fell before his unwavering resolve, his growing skill, and his increasingly potent magic.

Every victory, hard-won and etched in sweat and blood, fueled his determination to survive, to push forward, to overcome the seemingly endless challenges of this untamed wilderness. He was no longer just surviving; he was adapting, evolving, becoming a force to be reckoned with. The sun beat down on Robert's brow as he pushed deeper into the heart of the forest.

The air grew heavy, almost suffocating, and the sounds of life had changed. It was a different type of sound and Robert was on edge. He continued to push on and the only sound was the rhythmic thud of his footsteps, now almost silent on the soft earth and the distant rustle of unseen creatures. A chill, unrelated to the temperature, ran down his spine as he crested a small, grassy hill, his eyes scanning the landscape before him.

He laid eyes on the clearing before him, and his breath caught in his throat. Lying in the middle of the clearing, bathed in the golden light of the setting sun, was the largest feline creature he had ever seen, dwarfing even the

panther he had faced earlier. It resembled a panther, but it was immense, easily ten feet long from the tip of its nose to the base of its powerful tail.

Its fur was a deep, lustrous black, absorbing the light, giving it an almost ethereal quality. It lay sprawled on the grass, seemingly unconcerned, its massive head resting on its paws. This was a creature utterly secure in its

power, a creature that knew it was the apex predator, the undisputed lord of its domain.

Robert, his heart pounding in his chest, carefully surveyed his surroundings. He searched for any sign of other creatures, any potential ambush, any hidden danger. He knew that confronting this beast head-on would be incredibly risky, bordering on suicidal. He needed to be cautious, to be strategic. He needed to use every advantage he could muster.

After a tense moment of observation, he concluded that the giant panther was, for the moment, alone. He began his attack with a carefully orchestrated combination of spells. First, he cast Greater Earth Bind, channeling a significant amount of his remaining mana into the spell, hoping to immobilize the beast, even if only for a few precious seconds.

As the earth beneath the panther's paws began to solidify, he followed up immediately with Nature's Wrath, a spell that summoned thorny vines and roots from the surrounding vegetation, further entangling the creature. The panther, startled by the sudden attack, struggled against the binding earth and the encroaching vines. Its muscles strained, its claws digging into the ground, its powerful body rippling with effort.

Robert knew he didn't have much time. The creature was incredibly strong, and it would soon break free. Wasting no time, he began to spam Flame Bolt spells, channeling his remaining mana into each fiery projectile. He hurled four bolts in rapid succession, each one striking the panther's flank, searing its fur and flesh.

The beast roared in pain and fury, its struggles intensifying. The sound was deafening, a primal scream of rage that echoed through the forest. With a mighty heave, the panther shattered the Earth Bind spell, the solidified earth crumbling around its paws. The Nature's Wrath vines, though still hindering its movements, were also beginning to give way.

The creature lunged at Robert, its claws outstretched, its eyes burning with a terrifying intensity. Robert, anticipating the attack, dodged with a speed honed by countless battles. He narrowly avoided the razor-sharp claws, feeling the wind of their passage against his skin. He countered with a powerful Earth Bullet, aiming for the beast's head. The projectile struck, but the panther's skull was thick, its hide tough.

The spell slowed it down, staggering it momentarily, but it didn't deliver a killing blow. The panther roared again, a sound filled with pain and unbridled rage, and charged once more. Robert knew he couldn't afford to let the creature get close. He needed to keep it at bay, to wear it down with spells.

He dodged another swipe of its claws, narrowly avoiding a potentially fatal blow, and cast Minor Movement, enhancing his speed and agility. He then unleashed a flurry of sword strikes, each one aimed at a vulnerable point – the joints, the eyes, the soft underbelly. The panther roared in pain with each successful hit, but it refused to give up, its resilience astonishing. It turned to face Robert, its eyes filled with hatred, its body a tapestry of wounds, both magical and physical.

Realizing that a prolonged battle would be his undoing, Robert decided on a desperate gambit. He quickly erected a Water Wall between himself and the panther, creating a temporary barrier, a momentary respite. The panther, momentarily confused, slammed into the wall, its momentum broken. This gave Robert the precious seconds he needed.

He recast Greater Earth Bind, channeling every last ounce of his remaining mana into the spell. The earth beneath the panther's paws solidified once more, trapping it in place, its struggles even more desperate than before.

With the beast immobilized, Robert, his body trembling with exhaustion, his mana reserves utterly depleted, unleashed four more Flame Bolt spells.

The fiery projectiles slammed into the panther, one after another, searing its flesh, burning its fur. The creature roared one last time, a sound filled with pain and defiance, before finally succumbing to its wounds. Its body slumped to the ground, its life extinguished. Robert stood there, swaying on his feet, his breath coming in ragged gasps, his body covered in sweat and blood, both his own and the creature's. He had done it. He had defeated the monstrous panther.


Level Up!

The familiar notification echoed in his mind, a small comfort amidst the exhaustion and the lingering adrenaline. He slowly approached the fallen beast, his sword still held loosely in his hand, and cautiously looted its carcass. He was surprised, and more than a little relieved, to receive 50

silver coins, a substantial amount compared to his previous spoils.

Dungeon run complete: Uncommon chest awarded.

Chest contains:

One Uncommon Oak Longbow Two gold coins

One skill token

Items added to user inventory. Thank you for visiting The Training Dungeon!

Looking around at the forest one last time he took a look at his status before he entered the portal and returned home.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 29‌

Dusty, weary, and bearing the invisible scars of countless battles, Robert stumbled through the shimmering portal, leaving behind the untamed wilderness of the dungeon and stepping back into the familiar embrace of his home. The transition was jarring; the cacophony of the forest – the rustling leaves, the growls of unseen beasts, the constant hum of magical energy – was replaced by a blessed, profound quiet, broken only by the

gentle ticking of the grandfather clock in the hallway.

His home, a modest but comfortable haven, stood in stark contrast to the brutal realities he had just faced. A wave of relief washed over him, a sense of peace he hadn't realized he'd been craving. Before he could even fully process the shift, his family – his wife, Sara, and their children, John, Richard, and Stacey – rushed to greet him, their faces a mixture of palpable relief and uncontainable joy.

Their hugs were tight, almost desperate, a tangible expression of their worry and their love. "You're back," Sara breathed, her voice a soft whisper against his ear, her eyes, wide and searching, scanning his form for any signs of injury, any hint of the dangers he had faced. Her touch was gentle, reassuring, a grounding force in the whirlwind of his life. "We were so worried. We always worry."

Robert smiled, a genuine, heartfelt smile that reached his tired eyes, and squeezed her hand, his calloused fingers intertwining with her delicate ones. "I'm fine, love," he reassured her, his voice hoarse but steady. "Just a bit tired. A little worse for wear, perhaps, but nothing I can't handle." He pulled back slightly, allowing her to fully see him, to reassure herself that he was truly unharmed.

Later, gathered around the warm glow of the fireplace, the crackling flames casting dancing shadows on the walls, Robert recounted his adventures, his words painting vivid pictures of the strange and wondrous creatures he had encountered in the dungeon's sprawling forest. He regaled them with tales of colossal boars, their tusks gleaming like polished ivory; of sleek,

shadow-like panthers that moved with an unnerving grace; and of monstrous bears whose roars shook the very ground he stood on.

He carefully omitted the more gruesome details, the moments of sheer

terror, the crushing weight of loss, focusing instead on the wonder and the challenge. He even produced a few photographs, taken with his cell phone, of the towering, ancient trees, their branches reaching towards the sky like supplicating arms, and of some of the less threatening creatures, their forms both familiar and strangely alien.

Stacey, his youngest, listened with wide, captivated eyes, her small hand clutching his arm, her imagination ignited by the tales of a world so

different from their own, a world of magic and danger, a world her father had bravely ventured into. The older children, John and Richard, listened with a more discerning ear, asking questions about strategy, about the mechanics of magic, their minds already grappling with the complexities of the System.

The following days settled into a comfortable, productive rhythm, a whirlwind of focused activity punctuated by moments of quiet family connection. Robert dedicated himself to crafting, his hands, surprisingly adept despite his relative inexperience with the System, moving with a newfound proficiency. He fashioned rods of healing, their smooth surfaces imbued with the power to mend wounds and soothe pain, and spell staffs, each one a conduit for specific magical energies, their intricate designs reflecting the complex forces they channeled.

He also began to formally train Elara, his student, in the basics of magic.

Her enthusiasm was infectious, a bright spark that rekindled his own

burgeoning passion for the arcane arts. He found himself enjoying the role of mentor, guiding her through the fundamental principles, patiently correcting her mistakes, and celebrating her small but significant victories. Watching her grasp the concepts, seeing the wonder in her eyes as she manifested her first, flickering spell, filled him with a profound sense of satisfaction.

He remembered his first successes with magic and how it had filled him with that same wonder. But beneath the surface of this domestic tranquility,

a shadow of sadness lingered. Robert couldn't shake the knowledge that his time with his family was finite, that in a few short months, he would be forced to leave them, to venture out into the vastness of the multiverse, a journey from which there might be no return.

The System's demands were absolute, its rules unyielding. The only solace he could find was in the knowledge that he was working tirelessly to ensure their future, to provide them with the resources and the skills they would need to thrive in his absence. He was building a legacy, a foundation of security, brick by painstaking brick. He would do everything in his power to provide a good life for his family.

During this period of intense preparation, he also focused on rapidly expanding his family's knowledge base. He utilized his System-granted skill 'Teaching', a form of accelerated knowledge transfer, to impart the fundamentals of Geometry to his wife and children. This wasn't traditional teaching; it was a direct infusion of understanding, bypassing the usual lengthy process of lectures and exercises.

Within a remarkably short time, they possessed a working knowledge of geometric principles, a foundation upon which he planned to build. He intended to use the same skill to impart knowledge of Calculus in two weeks, providing them with a strong mathematical foundation crucial for navigating many aspects of the System-influenced world. He focused the

knowledge transfer in the way he had designed to best suit their chosen life paths.

Four days later, driven by the relentless pressure of the System's timetable, Robert returned to the Dungeon, steeling himself for the challenges that awaited. He completed floor eight, a stark contrast to the previous verdant landscape. This floor was a more traditional cave system, a labyrinth of twisting tunnels and echoing chambers, the air thick with the smell of damp earth and something else… something acrid and unpleasant.

The inhabitants were equally uninviting: goblins, their eyes gleaming with malice; orcs, their brutish strength a constant threat; and bats, their screeching cries echoing through the darkness. He navigated the treacherous passages, his senses on high alert, his spells and sword his only

companions. Hal, the AI companion residing within his mind, provided constant tactical analysis and warnings, a silent, ever-present partner in his struggles.

He was still getting use to Hal's comments and it startled him at times. The System shop, a constant beacon of opportunity, offered new items after he cleared the floor. Among them were Tier 2 spellbooks in Illusion and Gravity, powerful additions to his growing magical arsenal. After carefully assessing his finances, and selling the crafted items he had painstakingly created during his time at home, he was able to afford both books.

This significant investment cost him a hefty 120 gold coins. The acquisition of these new spells represented a major step forward in his magical development, expanding his tactical options and enhancing his overall

power. The use of the new spells was demonstrated by Hal who showed him how to best use them. Completing the eighth floor run also earned him

another level, pushing him closer to the significant milestone of level 17.

The chest at the end of the floor, a gleaming, ornate container that materialized out of thin air, proved to be a rare find. It contained several items, including a robe of exceptional quality. He immediately recognized its potential value to Elara. The robe was not only aesthetically pleasing, with its intricate embroidery and flowing design, but it also provided significant protection and, more importantly, increased the wearer's mana recovery rate by a remarkable 2%.

This would be a crucial advantage for a budding mage, allowing her to cast spells more frequently and recover her magical energy more quickly. He hoped that she would find great use of the robes. As he continued his rigorous training regimen, both within the dungeon and during his brief periods at home, Robert, despite his relatively short time within the System – a mere few weeks – noticed a marked improvement in his abilities.

His control over the five elemental spheres of magic – fire, air, water, earth, and enchantment – had reached a surprising level of proficiency. He could

now weave spells with greater speed and precision, shaping the raw magical energy with an almost intuitive understanding, a testament to his natural

talent and Hal's constant guidance, accelerating his learning curve far beyond what a normal human could achieve.

His swordsmanship, while still rudimentary compared to seasoned warriors, had also advanced significantly, thanks in part to the System's skill enhancements and Hal's strategic advice during combat. He had achieved a basic mastery over the long sword, his movements becoming more fluid and economical, his strikes gaining power and accuracy. He felt a growing, albeit cautious, confidence in his ability to face whatever challenges the System threw at him, a confidence born of hard-won experience and the unwavering support of his AI companion.

This cycle of dungeon runs and home-based training continued for the next week, a relentless but rewarding grind. Robert conquered three more floors of the dungeon, each one presenting unique challenges and dangers. He acquired a Tier 2 spellbook in the Sphere of Destruction, broadening his

offensive capabilities, and a coveted Tier 3 book in Healing, significantly enhancing his ability to mend wounds and restore vitality.

The System shop continued to be his primary source of income; selling crafted items and looted treasures earned him a total of 190 gold, of which he spent 170 gold on the new spellbooks, a testament to their value and his commitment to maximizing his magical potential. He also found a new set of Rare Tier Leather Armor for himself, replacing the old, worn-out armor he had been using.

It was a much-needed upgrade. His new armor, crafted from the hide of a rare creature known as a Wyvern, was a significant upgrade. The armor, designated as "Rare Wyvernhide," was not only nearly twice as strong as

his previous set, providing superior protection against physical attacks, but it also possessed a self-repair enchantment.

This magical property, explained in detail by Hal, meant that minor damage to the armor would automatically mend itself over time, a crucial advantage in the heat of battle, significantly increasing its longevity and reducing the need for costly repairs. A significant milestone was reached as Robert finally attained level 20, a pivotal moment in his System journey.

Reaching this level unlocked the opportunity to choose his first profession, a specialization that would define his future path and grant him access to a whole new set of skills and abilities. After careful consideration and

extensive consultation with Hal, his ever-present AI companion, who provided detailed analyses of each option, he narrowed down his choices to two Legendary options: Grand Arcane Engineer and Mythic Enchanter of

the Healing Light.

Each profession offered a unique and powerful path, representing the

pinnacle of magical achievement in their respective fields. The decision weighed heavily on him, the implications far-reaching, the choice shaping the very core of his identity within the System. The future depended on the choice he made now. This was a lot to take in for someone so new to the system.


Profession Name

Profession Rarity

Profession Description


Grand Arcane Engineer


Legendary

Arcane Engineers are a rare breed of individuals who combine technical expertise with magical prowess. They design and construct intricate magical devices, from simple automatons to colossal war machines. Their creations are often imbued with powerful enchantments, making them highly sought after by both military and civilian organizations.

Core Skills: Enchanting, Engineering, Alchemy,

Fire Magic, Earth Magic

(Grants 1 points to Int/Wis per level, 1 point to both Dex/Str per level, and 1 free point)

Mythic Enchanter

of the Healing Light(U)

Mythical

A Mythic Enchanter of the Healing Light is a highly revered and skilled individual who specializes in creating powerful healing artifacts.

They possess a deep understanding of both magic



and medicine, allowing them to infuse objects with life-giving energy. The role of a Master Enchanter of the Healing Light is crucial in

maintaining balance and healing the world. They are often sought after by kings, queens, and heroes alike, and their creations are prized possessions.

Core Skills: Healing, Enchanting, Light

(Grants 2 points to Int/Wis per level, 2 points to Dex per level, and 3 free points)

"So, Hal, what's your take on this?" Robert asked, a thoughtful frown creasing his forehead. "It's a tough call."

Indeed, it presents a significant dilemma, your background as an engineer is deeply ingrained, a core part of your identity for many years. However, you've also explicitly stated your commitment to prioritizing protection – your own, and now Elara's. Given that unwavering priority, the Mythic Enchanter of the Healing Light is the logically

superior choice.

"Hmm, there are other options, though, right? Even if they're not as powerful..." Robert trailed off, a hint of uncertainty in his voice. "And why 'Unique'? What does that even signify in this context?"

That is correct, alternative paths exist, but selecting one would demonstrably weaken your overall capabilities, hindering your stated objective. As for 'Unique,' in the context of Legendary and higher-tier classes and professions, especially those intrinsically linked to a specific individual, like your Creation-based class and the Healing Light profession, it denotes exclusivity. There can only be one 'Grand Archmagi of Creation' at any given time, just as

there can only be one 'Mythic Enchanter of the Healing Light'.

"Okay, so I'm basically irreplaceable in this specific role until I... well, until I'm gone. That's a bit daunting, but good to know, I guess," Robert said, a nervous chuckle escaping his lips. He took a deep breath. "You're right, Hal.

Protection is paramount." He straightened his shoulders, a newfound

resolve hardening his gaze. "Enchanter it is." With a decisive nod, he made his selection. As his updated status sheet flashed before his eyes, his eyebrows shot up in surprise. "Whoa! Is it just me, or are my stats about to go through the roof?"

As we previously discussed, Robert, your Mythic classification signifies a substantial power differential, the gap between you and the majority of System users will be considerable. Be grateful for this advantage; it significantly increases your chances of survival and your capacity to safeguard those under your protection.

"Right, protection. That's the key," Robert replied, his voice firm, the initial shock giving way to a renewed sense of purpose.


Profession Unlocked!


Ability Unlocked!


Profession Ability: Enchanting Touch of the Master Healer

Description: A unique and powerful ability that allows the Enchanter to imbue healing properties into objects. This enchantment can be applied to weapons, armor, or even

consumable items. When activated, the enchanted item will not only provide its base function but also emit a gentle healing aura,

restoring health to the user or nearby allies over time. Additionally, the Enchanter can enhance the healing properties of existing

potions and salves, making them more potent and effective.

Limitations: The Enchanter cannot imbue a property that is greater than what is known to him

"Hal," Robert began, his voice tinged with apprehension, "I've been giving this a lot of thought. Do you think I've finally reached a point where I could start revealing my abilities to others... without, you know, attracting unwanted attention or putting myself in unnecessary danger?" He trailed

off, the unspoken fear hanging in the air.

The probability of a safe reveal has significantly increased, however, to further mitigate potential risks, I would strongly advise raising your Constitution to a minimum of 30. Your unallocated stat points allow for this adjustment.

Robert nodded slowly, considering Hal's suggestion. He trusted the AI's judgment implicitly. Accessing his status screen, he redistributed his points. Four points flowed into Constitution, bringing it to a robust 31, providing a substantial boost to his resilience and overall health. He allocated two points to Strength, raising it to a respectable 15, improving his physical capabilities. The remaining four points he held in reserve, a contingency for future needs, a buffer against the unknown.

Satisfied with the adjustments, a sense of cautious optimism began to replace his apprehension. He decided it was time. Later that afternoon,

gathered around the familiar comfort of the dinner table, the aroma of Sara's cooking filling the air, Robert began to explain his new profession and the

burgeoning scope of his abilities. As he had anticipated, John, with his sharp, analytical mind, was the quickest to grasp the full implications.

"Dad," John exclaimed, his eyes wide with excitement, "this is incredible! You can enchant anything to have healing properties, even objects you didn't personally craft! The possibilities are... limitless!" The rest of the family, though perhaps not fully understanding the technical nuances, echoed John's enthusiasm, their faces reflecting a mixture of pride and awe.

They unanimously agreed that Robert had made the right choice, embracing the path that best suited his skills and his protective instincts. The conversation then shifted, becoming more strategic, more focused. They began to discuss the practicalities of his newfound abilities, brainstorming how to proceed, how to gradually, carefully, reveal this extraordinary information to others, navigating the potential risks and maximizing the potential benefits.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 30‌

“So, how do we break this news?” Robert asked, gathering his family around the dinner table. John chuckled, “Maybe we could just shoot some fireballs at a news crew. That’d certainly make headlines.” Robert smiled. “While that would be quite a spectacle, I think a more subtle approach is needed. If the whole world knew about the future, it could lead to mass

panic or a religious frenzy.” Sara nodded. “Exactly. We need to be cautious. Gradual disclosure is the key.”

Elara, confused, piped up, “Why tell anyone at all?” "Well, for one, I want to ensure our family's safety and future. And to do that, we'll need substantial resources. Plus, there are things the world can do to prepare. We have centuries, but societal change takes time." Richard pondered. "Perhaps we should start small. Invite the grandparents and everyone else. We can

make it a family gathering and break the news together."

“A family meeting, huh?” John mused. “Kind of like a family intervention, but instead of addiction, it’s the end of the world.” Robert chuckled. “Something like that, I suppose. We’ll need to be delicate. We don’t want to scare them or overwhelm them.” “And what about the rest of the world?”

Sara asked. “When do we tell them? And how?” “That’s the million-dollar question,” Robert admitted. “We could start with close friends and trusted associates. Build a small, reliable circle. Then, as we gain more control and understanding, we can slowly expand our circle of influence.”

"I'll call my parents, and you can call yours," Sara suggested. "Since your family lives close together, it might be easier to visit them in person rather than trying to gather them here." Robert considered this. "That's a good idea. You get your mom and brother on board, and we'll fly up to South Carolina." "Sounds like a plan, I'll call them shortly," Sara said.

Over the next few days, the family prepared for their trip. Sara's mother and brother were excited about the family gathering, and Robert's family was looking forward to the visit. The only hiccup was Robert's appearance.

After boosting his Constitution, he looked much younger than his actual age. Realizing the potential issues with airport security, they decided to drive instead.

In the meantime, Robert visited a pawn shop in Tampa to sell some of his gold coins. Despite some initial curiosity about the strange inscriptions on the coins, the shop owner was impressed with the gold's quality. Robert managed to sell twenty coins for a substantial sum, providing the family with a comfortable financial cushion with Robert no longer working.

Before the trip, Robert decided to run another dungeon, a challenging cave system teeming with giant ants. While his physical weapons were

ineffective against these creatures, he relied on his growing Tier 2 magical arsenal, including Earth Spear and Fire Lance, to overcome the challenge.

Thinking about his spell books, his Tier 3 healing included a lot more powerful spells including the more powerful version of the Tier 1 Valicar's spells that he had. As soon as he had time he was going to start using those for his healing items.

Four days later, they loaded up the family SUV and hit the road. The ten- hour drive to Robert's parents' house was uneventful, and they arrived on time. Sara went to pick up her family from the airport, while Robert entertained his own family, who were curious about his youthful appearance. Once everyone had arrived, they gathered around a large

outdoor table. As the kids played, the adults engaged in lively conversation. Robert decided to seize the moment.

"Before we begin, I know I've kept you all in suspense, but I'll answer one question first. The young woman with us is Elara. She's under my care after her family was tragically killed. I'll explain more later, but first, I have a question for you all." Robert's expression turned serious.

"Dad, do you still enjoy smoked boar?" he asked. "Oh yeah, I can smoke a boar like nobody's business," Thomas replied, a nostalgic smile on his face. Elizabeth chuckled. "The last time your father smoked a boar, the whole neighborhood could smell it. We had an impromptu block party." Michael laughed. "Good times. Those were the days."

Robert looked around at his family: his parents, Thomas and Elizabeth; his older brother, Michael; his younger brother, David; and his younger sister, Emily. He shook his head and pulled four five-pound slabs of boar meat from seemingly thin air. "Think you could handle this? I've got about fifty pounds more." A stunned silence filled the room. Then, David stood up.

"Where did that come from? You couldn't have hidden that under the table!"

Robert grinned. "Same place I got this," he said, pulling out a Wyvernhide armor set. The table erupted in excited questions and demands for explanations. Robert simply smiled and returned the items to their invisible source, knowing a full explanation would take some time.

He raised his hand to silence the room. "About a month ago, I received

some information that has changed my life and, eventually, the lives of all of you. In time, this information will change the world." With that, he

pulled up the first few system messages from his log and displayed them for his family to read. "Robert, what is that?" Emily asked, her eyes wide with curiosity. "That, little sister, is what changed everything."

A heavy silence fell over the table as everyone absorbed the information. Thomas was the first to break the silence. "So, what does this all mean, son?" Robert took a deep breath. "For now, not much changes for you all. The significant changes won't occur for centuries. However, our future family members will be well-prepared. I plan to leave our family with the resources and knowledge needed to lead when the time comes."

"I know a lot about magic, though I've only mastered the weaker spells so far. Before I leave, I'll learn much more. I plan to leave you all books

containing these spells and guides on the System, including a breakdown of my journey. This will help our descendants earn feats and quests early, giving our future family a significant advantage." David grinned. "Magic,

huh? I'd call you crazy, but it's hard to ignore what I've just seen. Are you serious? You really know magic?" Robert smiled at his younger brother. "I do, little bro. But we should probably keep this a secret from the kids for now."

With that, Robert spent the next hour going over everything that had happened, telling them about his abilities, his skills, and spells. He talked

about the dungeon runs, and how he met Elara. He went over crafting and what he could make and showed them some of the other items he had and even the coins he had collected. His father interrupted him while he was talking about his enchanting abilities with a question, "Son you do know how these items could change the world right?"

"Yes, Dad, I do," Robert replied. "While I can't regrow limbs or replace missing parts yet, I can heal nearly all diseases and cure most poisons. I can even infuse these abilities into objects." He pulled out a Rod of Healing. "This rod can heal almost any injury sustained today, from broken bones to gunshot wounds. I believe I could even create a rod to cure cancer. The only limitation is the number of uses."

Emily, a nurse, interjected. "Robert, as a Nurse Practitioner, I know how many people die because we can't stabilize them fast enough. These rods would be invaluable."

Robert nodded. "I understand, Emily. The problem is, that this rod can only be used fifteen times before it's depleted. I could leave you hundreds, but it wouldn't be enough. The issue lies in Mana. It's an exotic particle that doesn't currently exist in our universe. The System generates Mana and provides it to me. Once the System fully integrates our universe, it will

introduce Mana, which will then spread rapidly. Until then, no one here can recharge or create these items."

Jennifer, David's wife, asked, "So if we had access to Mana, could we use magic too?"

"Not quite," Robert explained. "Humans don't naturally have the ability to use Mana. The System provides a shortcut, allowing us to use it without fully understanding it. Over time, humans could potentially learn to use

Mana without the System's help, but it would take centuries of practice for minimal results."

"So, what's the next step?" Robert asked. "I'll continue preparing, but what do we do, and who do we tell?" Thomas was the first to respond. "Son, for every person you tell, a dozen more will find out. How long before the government starts asking questions?" Robert considered this. "I know, but

should we withhold information from the government? While I want to

ensure our family leads the way, I also want our nation to lead. I served my country for a reason, and it wasn't just for the paycheck."

"The problem with involving the government is that they'll never be satisfied," Michael warned. "They'll want more and more, and I can see them locking you in a room and draining you of all your knowledge." Robert smiled. "I don't think they can do that. My Constitution is 31, which not only boosts my health significantly but also extends my lifespan to around 200 years. I'm stronger, faster, and have abilities that could easily

neutralize anyone who tries to harm me." "So that's why you look younger,"

Emily realized. "Your lifespan is increasing, and your body is getting stronger."

"Exactly," Robert confirmed. "With the System, I could eventually live for 500 years or more. From what Hal tells me, there are beings out there who are thousands, even tens of thousands of years old." "That's hard to imagine," his mother said. "Most people in System worlds are ordinary, with average power levels," Robert explained.

"Gaining power requires taking risks and facing danger. While you can level up through daily life, combat is the fastest way to grow. Stats are crucial, and most people end up with common or uncommon classes and professions, limiting their potential. Even with optimal stat allocation, they might reach level 50 or 60 in their lifetime."

"So, with a Mythical class and profession, you'll far surpass others?" David asked. "Absolutely," Robert replied. "Let's compare. At level 10, a common class gains 30 stat points. A Mythical class, like mine, gains significantly more. Even ignoring profession bonuses, I'll have double the stats. As we level up, this gap widens. At level 30, a common class might have around 160 stat points, while I'll have over 300. Most of my stats will be in

Intelligence and Wisdom, but I'll also have a massive Mana pool compared to others. By level 50, my Constitution will grant me a lifespan of 400 years, and it scales from there.

With my current growth rate, I'll likely reach 60 or 65 in Constitution before I leave, giving me a lifespan of 500 to 550 years. It's mind-boggling."

"I've noticed you haven't been investing in Charisma," Emily observed. "What does it actually do?" Robert pulled up his stat sheet and consulted Hal for more details.

Charisma influences social abilities and personal magnetism. It affects things like persuasion, deception, leadership, intimidation, diplomacy, and performance. Emily is right, you should probably add some points. It'll help you interact with others more effectively.

He paused, considering his options. "Actually, I have four spare points. I think I'll add them to Charisma now." No one objected, so Robert added the points to his Charisma stat. The kids returned at that moment so everyone agreed to stop here and think about any questions to ask later that night when the kids all went to bed.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 31‌

Later that evening, after tucking the kids in, the adults gathered in the family room to continue their discussion. "Robert," Emily inquired, "are these items the best you can do?" "Not even close," Robert replied. "The issue lies in the materials. Oak has its limitations. I'd need more exotic

materials and gemstones to amplify the power. Unfortunately, I don't have access to the right resources."

"What about the gemstones?" Emily asked. "Do they have to be real? Would glass work?" "No, they must be genuine," Robert explained.

"Different stones are better suited for different types of magic. For instance, Blue Topaz or Aquamarine would be ideal for enchanting using magic from the Sphere of Healing, while Yellow Topaz or Chrysoberyl would be better for spells from the Sphere of Light." "That sounds quite expensive," Emily mused. "Is it worth the cost?"

Robert pulled out his phone and began researching. "I'm not certain," he said. "A 1-carat Blue Topaz, for example, would cost around $400.

However, I have no idea how many charges it would provide, and Aquamarines are even more problematic. Chrysoberyls seem like a more promising option. I can get a 1.3-carat stone for about $260, which might be a good starting point for testing."

"What about Sapphires?" His mother asked, "I have that old ring I don't

wear anymore, it's got that gaudy stone on it, can we use it to test?" Robert thought about it for a second, "I remember that, It was grandma's ring, the stone is large enough if I remember." His mother continued, "Ya it's a little over a carat. How long would it take you to enchant something?"

Robert thought about it, "I'd have to take the stone off the ring, I don't have the right tools nor the skill to engrave the runes on the ring, but I could mount it on a rod, better yet, silver." Robert got quiet for a few minutes, lost in thought. "I would have to mount the stone to a rod, and then if I carved

the runes in silver and attached them to the stone, I would get a much better

result. I can melt a few of my silver coins and use those and I have a few good pieces of Oak rods."

Robert continued, "Okay so I'll try it tomorrow, I might need to run to a hardware store and get a few things so I can melt the silver, but this is doable." Elizabeth left the room for a moment and returned with the ring, "Here you go, this is exciting, I hope it works."

The next day, Robert headed to a hardware store, purchasing a stone crucible and a blowtorch for melting the silver. Back home, he first

removed the stone from its setting and selected an unused rod. Carefully, he carved the runes for his Tier 3 healing spell into the wood, followed by a cavity to house the gemstone. Placing ten coins in the crucible, he ignited

the torch and melted the silver.

Once molten, he slowly poured the silver into the carved runes, connecting them to the cavity. Finally, he encased the stone in silver, securing it with a silver strap. With the physical preparations complete, Robert began the enchanting process. Immediately, he noticed the increased Mana cost.

While his previous rods required around 250 Mana, this one demanded a staggering 2000. As he finished the enchantment, he examined the completed rod, a surge of anticipation coursing through him:


Name: Silver Enhanced Oak Rod of Healing

Tier: 4

Rank: Epic

Description: This rod was made by an expert enchanter who used silver inlays and a Sapphire stone in its creation. and when used will expend 1 charge to heal up to 75 health points.

Charges: 100


Feat Unlocked!

Robert pulled up his new feat:

Name: Architect of the Arcane Description: First person to create an enchanted item, of Epic Quality and at least

Tier 4. Tier 5 is required for enchanting or Tier 4 for both the Enchanting Skill and the Sphere of Enchanting.

Effect: +4 levels to your enchanting skill, or if you have both +2 to each of your enchanting Skill and Sphere. You have a +5% chance of any item you enchant being 1 tier higher in rarity.

"Hal, what do you think the System would pay for this rod?" Robert pondered.

Based on the previous one, I'd estimate around 9 gold.

Robert's eyes lit up. "Even considering the cost of the stones, I could potentially craft eight of these from the money I would get from that. That's a gold mine!"

For now, yes. But remember, Tier 5 Enchanters have been honing their craft for 15 to 20 years. They're nearly masters. To them, 9 gold isn't much. You've created a Tier 4 Epic healing item, something many Enchanters can't do. A Tier 5 version might fetch 25 to 30 gold. Good Enchanters live comfortably; Great Enchanters swim in wealth.

"So, once I reach that level, I won't have to worry about money?" Robert asked, hopeful.

The average worker on most System worlds earns 2 to 3 gold a year and lives decently. A high-level worker might make 5 to 6 gold annually and live quite well. A skilled

professional with their own shop could earn 20 to 30 gold a year. At your current pace, you could leave Earth with a few hundred gold. Ask Elara about the cost of items on her world to get a better idea.

"Well, that's reassuring. I'll never starve," Robert said, gathering the rod. "I'll go show the others." Finding his family gathered outside at the table, he put the new rod on the table. "Robert it's beautiful," Emily said. "The question is, is it better?"

With a smile, Robert pulled out a sheet of paper where he had written both the old rod's description as well as the new rod's.


Name: Oak Rod of Healing

Tier: 1

Rank: Uncommon

Description: This rod was made by an expert enchanter and when used will expend 1 charge to heal up to 12 health points.

Charges: 20


Name: Silver Enhanced Oak Rod of Healing

Tier: 4

Rank: Epic

Description: This rod was made by an expert enchanter who used silver inlays and a Sapphire stone in its creation. and when used will expend 1 charge to heal up to 75 health points.

Charges: 100

"Well, these new rods are definitely an upgrade," Emily laughed. "But those stones are a bit pricey, close to $2000 each." Robert smiled. "Don't worry,

they're a solid investment. The System Shop will pay 8 or 9 gold coins per rod, which is roughly $16,000 each. Even if I buy five stones at a time, that's a $6,000 profit per rod. Enchanters can make a killing." The room fell silent. "Son, if we ordered 10 stones, could you finish the rods before your next dungeon run?" Thomas asked. "Not a chance," Robert replied. "It'll

take weeks to get the stones. But once they arrive, I can make two rods a day, so six to eight per run."

David stepped in. "I've got the money to order 20 stones. Just pay me back." Robert chuckled. "I'll give you 40 gold coins from the sale. Double your money back seems fair." Emily pondered. "Even with that, you'd still make over $200,000. You're right, it's a moneymaker." "Yes, but time is the issue," Robert explained. "It'll take 12-13 days to make 20 rods, including dungeon runs. After that, we'll make another 10 for the family. Hopefully, I'll learn something new and create something more powerful, like limb replacements." Emily's eyes widened. "Robert, if you could create limb replacements, we could help countless people. Forget money, we'd make millions!"

David set his phone down. "Good news! I found a gemstone shop in Atlanta. They have plenty of the stones we need. I’ll drive over tomorrow and pick them up. You should be able to start tomorrow afternoon." Robert grinned. “That’s fantastic! I’ll grab some extra oak rods and get everything ready. I should be able to make five rods before my next run, so I can pay you back. But it’ll be the run after that before you see a profit.” David shrugged. “No rush.”

The family spent the rest of the day discussing their future. A few hours later, Thomas asked, "Son, you said Constitution makes you tougher, right?" Robert pondered. "Yes, it increases physical resistance. I’m currently at 7.” “What does that mean? Are you bulletproof?” Thomas inquired.

Not quite. A 7 means you can withstand physical attacks like punches, but bullets are a different story. To stop most handguns, you’d need a score of 10. For rifles, you’re looking at 15. To get to 10, you’d need a Constitution of 50. For 15, it’s 90.

“So, not quite bulletproof yet,” Robert continued. “I could probably win a boxing match, but for handguns, I’d need about 21 more levels, or 10 with some strategic point allocation. For rifles, it’s 30 levels away.” Thomas nodded, understanding. “So, we keep this to ourselves until you reach that

10. Even if you can’t stop a rifle round, your high health would probably let you survive, right?” Robert laughed. “You’re probably right. And you could always heal me up.”

The next day David left early to head to Atlanta and Robert went to the

hardware store to get more Oak Rods. Later that afternoon, he was able to start working again on the new rods. This continued for the next three days. By the time Robert's next run had arrived he had created 5 new rods to sell.

On the day of Robert’s next run, the kids were at Michael’s house, and the adults gathered at Robert’s parents’. Dressed in his armor and clutching his sword, Robert walked into the room. “Damn, Robert, looking mighty

medieval,” Emily teased. Thomas shook his head. “So, what’s the plan,

son?” Robert glanced at his father. “It’s time to tell Hal,” Robert informed Hal he was ready, and a portal materialized in the corner of the room.

Everyone’s eyes were fixed on the swirling portal. “So, that’s how it

works?” David asked, surprised. “You just walk into that thing?”Robert chuckled. “Yep. Not sure how long this will take, but expect several hours, maybe even a full day.” With that, he stepped into the portal.

OceanofPDF.com

‌Chapter 32‌

Welcome, adventurer. You have entered Dungeon 7883667HG8776DE985762763FF7-1, currently known as The Training Dungeon. You are now on the Twelfth Floor.

Not wasting time, Robert went to the System Shop and sold the six rods he had earning him 49 gold and 80 silver. "Looks like you were right on the money, a little over 8 gold per rod. Switching over to the items for sale, he pulled up the list:
